hypotheses.source_question: Do rational curves fixed by non-trivial elements of the automorphism group of a CY3 generate a discrete flavor symmetry that constrains the superpotential's Yukawa texture, and can their Gromov-Witten invariants predict which flavor symmetries are geometrically realizable?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆-invariant rational curves on the GL=12/D₆ polytope whose fixed-point loci under non-trivial automorphism group elements directly generate the vanishing pattern of the 26 surviving Yukawa couplings, such that the number of geometrically forbidden couplings (those with zero intersection number under D₆ action) will match the number of empirically small or zero fermion mass ratios with ≥90% accuracy.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ automorphism group acts on the space of rational curve families in the Calabi-Yau threefold's Picard lattice. Non-trivial elements of D₆ fix certain rational curve classes; these fixed curves contribute zero to the triple intersection numbers κ_{abc} when abc spans the fixed loci. Since Yukawa couplings Y_{ijk} are proportional to periods integrated against products of (2,1)-forms dual to curve classes, geometrically vanishing intersections force certain Y_{ijk} → 0 by topology alone, independent of moduli tuning. This generates a discrete flavor symmetry texture at the geometric level, before any effective-field-theory Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism.
hypotheses.prediction: Of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings, at least 18 will show geometric selection rules (intersection number = 0 under D₆-invariant combinations of rational curves) that correspond to the observed small mass ratios in the Standard Model (e₁/e₃ ~ 10⁻³, d₁/d₃ ~ 10⁻², u₁/u₃ ~ 10⁻⁵, and θ₁₃ ~ 0.003), with correlation coefficient r > 0.8 between predicted vanishing patterns and empirical hierarchy.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If ≤8 of the 26 D₆-invariant couplings show geometric selection rules matching the observed fermion mass hierarchy (r < 0.5 when comparing predicted vanishing patterns to empirical mass ratios), or if the distribution of non-zero intersection numbers κ_{abc} under D₆ action is uncorrelated with observed mass eigenvalue separations (p > 0.05 in Spearman rank correlation test), the hypothesis is refuted and Froggatt-Nielsen or other secondary mechanisms are necessary.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Spearman correlation r > 0.8 between D₆-invariant geometric selection rules (binary: coupling forbidden vs. allowed) and empirically observed mass hierarchy (ranked fermion mass ratios); ≥18/26 couplings correctly predicted as suppressed or unsuppressed; intersection-number analysis recovers observed mass-ratio separations with <1 order-of-magnitude error in median prediction.

experiment.approach: Computationally enumerate all genus-0 rational curves on the GL=12/D₆ polytope using CyTools and mirror symmetry, classify their orbit structure under D₆ action, compute D₆-invariant triple intersection numbers κ_{abc}, and correlate the resulting vanishing pattern with observed Standard Model fermion mass hierarchies using statistical rank correlation and binary classification metrics.
steps: Use CyTools to construct the mirror polytope of GL=12/D₆ and enumerate all rational curves (h⁰(O(1)) representatives) via both classical divisor class intersections and quantum cohomology (Gromov-Witten invariants from toric data).
For each rational curve family identified in step 1, compute the explicit action of the D₆ automorphism group (generated by dihedral generators σ, τ with |σ|=6, |τ|=2, στσ⁻¹=τ).
Identify and enumerate: (a) fixed curves (curves invariant under non-identity elements g ∈ D₆), (b) orbits of curves under D₆ action, (c) stabilizer subgroups for each orbit.

For each D₆-invariant triple (J_a, J_b, J_c) of divisor classes (20 complex structure moduli reduced to 5 invariants), compute κ_{abc} = ∫_{CY3} J_a ∧ J_b ∧ J_c using the toric intersection form on the polytope.

Construct the 26×26 matrix M of all surviving D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings by computing Y_{ijk} ∝ κ_{abc} · intersection multiplicity of curve classes under D₆ action. Identify couplings forced to zero by geometry (det[M_restricted]=0 due to fixed-point loci).
Tabulate empirical fermion mass ratios: m_e/m_μ ~ 1/200, m_d/m_s ~ 1/20, m_u/m_c ~ 1/500, θ₁₃ ~ 0.003. Rank the 26 Yukawa couplings by predicted suppression factor (zero vs. non-zero).
Compute Spearman rank correlation (ρ) between the ranked geometric selection-rule strength and empirical mass-ratio hierarchy. Test null hypothesis H₀: ρ=0 using two-sided test with α=0.05.

Generate confusion matrix: for each coupling, predict 'suppressed' (κ_{abc}=0 under D₆) or 'active' (κ_{abc}≠0), and compare against empirical hierarchy (mass ratio < threshold vs. ≥ threshold, threshold=10⁻²).

Compute Picard-Fuchs equations for the periods of D₆-invariant holomorphic 3-forms on the Calabi-Yau family; extract monodromy matrices and check consistency with predicted coupling suppression patterns.
Produce visualization: 26-dimensional heatmap of κ_{abc} structure constants colored by D₆ orbit membership; overlay empirical mass hierarchy as rank ordering on same axes.
tools: CyTools (Kreuzer-Skarke polytope database, Gromov-Witten computation)
SAGE/Python: group theory (GAP interface) for D₆ action, toric geometry (polytope), intersection number calculation
Mathematica/Macaulay2: Picard-Fuchs ODE solver, monodromy computation
pandas/scipy.stats: Spearman correlation, statistical testing, confusion matrix generation
matplotlib/plotly: heatmaps, orbit visualization
Published Standard Model fermion mass eigenvalues and CKM/PMNS mixing matrices
experiment.estimated_effort: 4-8 weeks: ~1 week to enumerate rational curves and D₆ orbits via CyTools; ~2 weeks to compute intersection numbers and Yukawa texture; ~1 week for Picard-Fuchs/monodromy analysis; ~1-2 weeks for statistical correlation analysis and visualization; internal code review and sensitivity analysis.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke toric polytope database (public), CyTools/codebase (public), GAP character tables for D₆ (public), Standard Model mass eigenvalues and mixing angles (PDG, public), CY3 mirror family databases (literature + custom CyTools output).
experiment.expected_positive: Spearman ρ > 0.8 (p < 0.01) between D₆-invariant geometric selection rules and empirical fermion mass hierarchy; ≥18/26 Yukawa couplings correctly classified as suppressed or active; median predicted mass-ratio separation agrees with observation to within 1 order of magnitude; confusion matrix shows F1-score > 0.75 for binary classification of suppressed vs. active couplings.
experiment.expected_negative: Spearman ρ < 0.5 (p > 0.05); ≤8/26 couplings correctly predicted; predicted mass-ratio separations deviate by >2 orders of magnitude from observation; geometric selection rules show no structure correlated with D₆ orbits; Picard-Fuchs monodromy matrices fail to align with empirical coupling patterns.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆ automorphism group action on rational curves in the GL=12/D₆ polytope produces no statistically significant constraint on the vanishing pattern of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings, and observed fermion mass hierarchies are unrelated to geometric selection rules from D₆-invariant rational curve fixed loci (Spearman ρ = 0).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided Spearman rank correlation test, α=0.05; null hypothesis ρ=0 rejected if p<0.05 and ρ>0.8. Supplementary: binary classification accuracy (suppressed vs. active coupling) via confusion matrix and F1-score threshold >0.75; Fisher exact test for independence of (coupling index, D₆ orbit membership, empirical suppression status).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Spearman ρ ≥ 0.80 (moderate-to-strong rank correlation); ≥18 of 26 couplings (69%) correctly classified; Cohen's h ≥ 0.4 for difference between predicted and observed suppression rates (large effect by convention). For discrete case: ≥5 empirical mass ratios correctly recovered from top-5 suppressed couplings.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size = 26 couplings (all D₆-invariant survivors). This is a non-random fixed set, not a random sample; thus traditional power analysis inapplicable. Instead, we use resampling: generate 1000 permutations of empirical mass-ratio labels and recompute ρ for each; reject H₀ if observed ρ exceeds 95th percentile of null distribution (equivalent to one-sided p<0.05). Convergence criterion: Gromov-Witten summation converges when individual GW invariants N_d (degree d) stabilize to machine precision (~10⁻¹⁴) for d≤6; Picard-Fuchs solutions converge when relative error in period ratios <10⁻¹⁰.
limitations: Assumes the 26 D₆-invariant couplings are the only relevant contributions to Yukawa matrix; non-renormalizable corrections (dimension-5+) and string-scale threshold corrections not included.
Empirical fermion masses used for comparison are measured in the weak scale; running to string scale introduces model-dependent uncertainty (MSSM, GUT thresholds) not captured here.

Picard-Fuchs/monodromy analysis assumes the Calabi-Yau family is a single connected component in moduli space; if the D₆-invariant locus splits into multiple components, the analysis must be repeated per component.
The correlation test uses Standard Model masses as ground truth, but does not account for potential model degeneracy (multiple texture choices yielding same low-energy physics).

Rational curves are classified via toric mirror symmetry, which assumes the CY3 is well-described by a reflexive polytope; non-reflexive families or CY3s with additional discrete factors may require separate treatment.

Statistical power is limited by the fixed n=26 couplings; effect size judgment depends on choice of mass-ratio threshold and empirical ranking method (could introduce bias if thresholds chosen post-hoc).
experiment.requires_followup: If computational results show strong correlation (r>0.8), the next step would be a mirror symmetry / deformation theory calculation: explicitly solve the Picard-Fuchs equations for the GL=12/D₆ family, extract flat coordinates, and verify that the periods themselves (not just intersection numbers) exhibit the predicted D₆-invariant structure. This requires solving a system of coupled PDEs (doable in Mathematica but computationally intensive, ~2–4 weeks). Following that, a string-compactification consistency check would be needed: construct the Type IIB dual (D-brane configuration on mirror) and verify that the D₆ discrete symmetry descends from gauge symmetry breaking in the IIB effective action—this is primarily theoretical (pen-and-paper with numerical verification, ~3–6 weeks). No wet-lab component; entirely mathematical/computational.

hypotheses.source_question: Can the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture on the GL=12/D₆ Calabi–Yau threefold, constrained by discrete automorphism symmetry, predict the three CKM quark mixing angles (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) and CP-violating phase δ_CP without requiring an additional Froggatt–Nielsen mechanism?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture derived from the GL=12/D₆ Calabi–Yau threefold, when lifted to the mass-eigenstate basis via unitary diagonalization and monodromy-corrected moduli, causally determines the three CKM quark mixing angles (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) and CP-violating phase δ_CP to within ±15% of experimentally observed PDG values without invoking a secondary Froggatt–Nielsen mechanism.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ automorphism group acts on the 20 complex-structure moduli, reducing the Yukawa coupling space from ≥81 independent entries (full 3×3 matrices) to exactly 26 invariant triple-intersection couplings. These geometric constraints enforce a specific texture in both Y_d and Y_u matrices (in the weak basis). Upon diagonalization via the Takagi factorization Y_d Y_d† = U_d Λ_d² U_d† and Y_u Y_u† = U_u Λ_u² U_u†, the left-handed unitary matrices U_d and U_u are themselves constrained by the topology of the Calabi–Yau moduli space and its monodromy group action. The CKM matrix V_CKM = U_u† U_d then inherits these geometric constraints, causing the three mixing angles to cluster near observed values. This is a forward causal mechanism: symmetry constraints in Y_d,u → constrained unitary basis transformations → predicted CKM angles.
hypotheses.prediction: Scanning the 5-dimensional space of D₆-invariant moduli combinations and computing V_CKM for each point, the median predicted values will satisfy: |θ₁₂^pred − θ₁₂^PDG| ≤ 0.08 rad (≈4.6°), |θ₂₃^pred − θ₂₃^PDG| ≤ 0.05 rad (≈2.9°), and |θ₁₃^pred − θ₁₃^PDG| ≤ 0.03 rad (≈1.7°), with at least 30% of the sampled moduli points satisfying all three bounds simultaneously. The magnitude of δ_CP^pred will fall within the PDG 1σ interval [0.95, 1.20] in units of π with probability ≥0.25.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, after scanning ≥10⁴ random points in the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant moduli space and computing V_CKM for each, fewer than 15% of sampled configurations yield θ₁₂ within ±10° of the PDG value (13.04°), or if the distribution of predicted (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) shows no statistically significant clustering (KL divergence > 2.0 nats from an isotropic baseline), then the hypothesis is falsified. Additionally, if monodromy-corrected textures produce a distribution of δ_CP that is uniformly distributed over [0, 2π] with no clustering near the observed central value (1.08π), the mechanism is ruled out.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Explained variance of CKM angles: R² ≥ 0.60 (i.e., the 26-parameter D₆-invariant model explains ≥60% of the variance in observed (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) across the moduli scan). Equivalently, mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) ≤ 12% for all three angles. For δ_CP, the mean direction (circular mean) must lie within ±0.15 rad of the PDG best-fit value.

experiment.approach: Computationally enumerate the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings for GL=12/D₆ using CyTools by integrating the Kähler and period forms over the divisor basis. Construct 3×3 weak-basis Yukawa matrices Y_d and Y_u with entries proportional to these triple intersections. Sample the 5-dimensional space of D₆-invariant moduli and, for each configuration, diagonalize Y_d Y_d† and Y_u Y_u† to extract unitary matrices. Compute V_CKM and extract physical mixing angles; compare against PDG values to assess geometric predictivity.
steps: Step 1: Use CyTools to compute the full Kähler basis and period vector for GL=12/D₆; verify h¹¹=17, h²¹=20, Hodge diamond.
Step 2: Enumerate the D₆ orbit of holomorphic (3,0)-form Ω and identify 5 algebraically independent D₆-invariant combinations of the 20 complex-structure moduli.
Step 3: Compute the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings Y_{ijk} ∝ ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k using CyTools divisor intersection numbers for H²(CY3). Build lookup tables: Y_{ijk}(moduli).

Step 4: Parameterize each of the 5 D₆-invariant moduli as an independent continuous variable in a physically reasonable range (e.g., derived from string coupling, Kähler cone constraints, or mirror-symmetry duality).
Step 5: Draw N=5×10⁴ random samples from the 5D moduli space (Latin hypercube or quasi-Monte Carlo).

Step 6: For each sample, assemble weak-basis 3×3 Yukawa matrices Y_d and Y_u using the 26 couplings and appropriate flavor-index assignments (derived from matter curve branching under D₆ action on the toric fan).
Step 7: Diagonalize Y_d Y_d† and Y_u Y_u† via eigenvalue decomposition to extract left-handed unitary matrices U_d and U_u.
Step 8: Compute V_CKM = U_u† U_d and extract the three physical CKM angles θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃ and phase δ_CP using standard CKM parameterization (Wolfenstein or Jarlskog).
Step 9: Compare predicted angles against PDG 2024 central values: θ₁₂ = 13.04° ± 0.05°, θ₂₃ = 2.38° ± 0.06°, θ₁₃ = 0.201° ± 0.010°, δ_CP = 1.144π ± 0.063π.

Step 10: Compute the distribution statistics: median error, 68% credible interval, and fraction of configurations satisfying all three bounds (see prediction). Perform kernel-density estimation to test for multimodal clustering.

Step 11: Repeat Steps 6–10 for two perturbation scenarios: (i) D₆ broken by O(ε) with ε ∈ {0.01, 0.05, 0.10} via small non-invariant couplings, and (ii) D₆ replaced by its subgroups (D₃, Z₃, Z₂) to assess sensitivity to symmetry breaking.

Step 12: Cross-check via monodromy action: compute the monodromy group of the Picard–Fuchs system for GL=12/D₆ and verify that V_CKM remains stable under monodromy transformations in moduli space (i.e., does not jump discontinuously at special loci).
tools: CyTools (cython-based toric geometry & Picard–Fuchs solver)
SageMath for Hodge diamond & divisor intersection computation
custom Python/NumPy code for Yukawa matrix assembly and unitary diagonalization (scipy.linalg.eigh)
PDG 2024 quark-lepton flavor parameters (https://pdg.lbl.gov)
mpl_toolkits.mplot3d for visualization of moduli space and CKM angle distribution
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks compute: ~1 week setting up CyTools & verifying GL=12/D₆ data (h¹¹, h²¹, Hodge); ~1 week computing 26 invariant couplings and parameterizing moduli space; ~1–2 weeks running 5×10⁴ Monte Carlo samples and statistical analysis.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools polytope database (GL=12/D₆ entry; ~O(100 MB) for one model), PDG 2024 flavor-physics tables, access to ~10–50 CPU-hours for Monte Carlo sampling (or equivalent GPU parallelization).
experiment.expected_positive: At least 30% of the 5×10⁴ moduli samples yield V_CKM angles matching PDG values to within the specified tolerances (≤4.6° for θ₁₂, ≤2.9° for θ₂₃, ≤1.7° for θ₁₃). The joint distribution of predicted (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) clusters around the observed point with R² ≥ 0.60. The CP phase δ_CP shows non-uniform, peaked distribution with circular mean within ±0.15 rad of PDG value.
experiment.expected_negative: Fewer than 15% of samples satisfy the θ₁₂ tolerance (ruling out simple geometric determination). Predicted angles show no structure, appearing uniformly random over [0°, 90°] range, with KL divergence > 2.0 nats. The distribution of δ_CP is flat or multi-modal without clustering near 1.14π.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆-invariant Yukawa texture places no statistically significant constraint on the CKM mixing angles. Formally, the marginal distributions of (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) derived from V_CKM in the moduli scan are independent of the geometric constraint (i.e., are indistinguishable from those arising from an unconstrained random 3×3 unitary matrix in the CKM flavor basis). R² ≈ 0 (or <0.20), and the observed clustering near PDG values occurs with probability <5% under the null.
experiment.statistical_test: One-sample Kolmogorov–Smirnov test: compare the empirical cumulative distribution of predicted angles from 5×10⁴ samples against the observed PDG distribution (modeled as a narrow Gaussian or Dirac delta). Two-tailed KS test with α=0.05. Additionally, compute the R² of a linear regression of predicted angles on PDG angles; reject H₀ if R² > 0.50 at p<0.01 (Wald F-test). For δ_CP, compute the circular mean and assess concentration using the mean resultant length; reject H₀ if concentration parameter κ > 2 (indicating significant clustering) at p<0.05 (Rayleigh test for non-uniformity).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Smallest effect size: R² > 0.35 (explaining ~35% of variance in CKM angles). For individual angles, mean absolute error <8° for θ₁₂, <4° for θ₂₃, <2.5° for θ₁₃. For δ_CP, circular concentration κ > 1.5 (significant non-uniformity). Sample size N=5×10⁴ provides ~99% power to detect R²=0.40 at α=0.05 (with 2 predictors: the 5D moduli reduce to effective degrees of freedom ~2–3 after D₆ projector action).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With 5×10⁴ samples and 5 moduli parameters, we have ~10⁴ effective degrees of freedom after accounting for correlations in D₆-invariant basis. For a two-sided test of R²=0.50 vs. R²=0.0 (null) with α=0.05 and assuming effect size f²=0.50/(1–0.50)=1.0, the required N per group in classical ANOVA is ~n=84 per cell; our 5×10⁴ samples vastly exceeds this. Power is ≥99%. For the KS test, N=5×10⁴ achieves power ≥95% to detect a median error >3° in θ₁₂.
limitations: Assumes matter-curve assignments (flavor indices → H¹(E)) under D₆ action are correctly identified from toric geometry; errors here directly propagate to Y_d, Y_u structure.

Weak-basis Yukawa matrices assume absence of non-renormalizable terms; unknown O(1) coefficients in the string effective action could rescale individual couplings, shifting predicted angles by O(5–10%).
Moduli space is assumed to be a smooth 5-dimensional locus; in reality, orbifold singularities or monodromy cuts may fragment the parameter region, reducing effective dimensionality.
Does not include running of Yukawa couplings from string scale (~10¹⁸ GeV) to electroweak scale; renormalization-group evolution could shift angles by O(3–5%).
No account for neutrino masses or leptonic mixing (PMNS matrix); the mechanism may work well for quarks but fail for leptons.
Depends on the specific CyTools dataset; if GL=12/D₆ polytope data are corrupted or misidentified, all results are invalid.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational analysis confirms R² > 0.50 and clustering around PDG values, the next step is experimental validation via precision electroweak measurements: (i) measure rare B-decay branching ratios (e.g., B → K^* γ, B_s → μμ) to constrain CKM unitarity-triangle angles and compare against CY predictions; (ii) use high-energy LHC data to extract the CKM matrix via top-quark production and decay; (iii) test whether CY-predicted textures suppress flavor-changing neutral currents (FCNC) below current experimental bounds. A full wet-lab flavor-physics program would require new or reanalyzed collider data and precision measurements spanning ~2–3 years; the computational steps above are a necessary prerequisite to justify such an experimental push.

hypotheses.source_question: Can discrete flavor symmetries of Calabi-Yau compactifications predict the lepton mixing angles (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) that govern neutrino oscillation patterns, and do CY automorphism groups acting on (2,1)-forms naturally generate the observed texture of neutrino mass matrices?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that CY3 automorphism groups acting on the (2,1)-form moduli space causally determine the structure of the neutrino mass matrix through D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling textures, such that the zero pattern and eigenvalue alignment induced by geometric discrete symmetry directly generates the observed lepton mixing angles (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) without requiring auxiliary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ (or other non-Abelian) automorphism group of a CY3 compactification acts as a linear representation on the (2,1)-form cohomology basis. The invariant subspace under this action constrains which Yukawa coupling matrix elements Y_{ijk} are geometrically allowed (non-zero); forbidden elements are exactly those transforming non-trivially under the symmetry. This sparse, symmetry-induced zero pattern in Y_ν (the neutrino coupling matrix) forces its diagonalization to produce a unitary mixing matrix U_PMNS with mixing angles clustered near specific rational or simple irrational values that depend solely on the representation structure of the automorphism group, not on continuous moduli tuning.
hypotheses.prediction: For CY3 compactifications with D₆ automorphisms and h²¹ ≥ 18, the predicted lepton mixing angles derived from the D₆-invariant neutrino Yukawa matrix will lie within ±3° of the observed PDG central values (θ₁₂ ≈ 33.5°, θ₂₃ ≈ 47.7°, θ₁₃ ≈ 8.6°) for ≥50% of geometries in a sample of n=200 CY3 models; the achieved correlation coefficient between geometry-predicted and observed angles will exceed r=0.60, compared to r<0.15 for random texture models.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, after systematically computing the D₆-invariant Yukawa matrix for a representative sample of 200 CY3 compactifications and diagonalizing each to extract predicted lepton mixing angles, the mean absolute deviation of predicted angles from PDG central values exceeds 8° for >70% of models, or if the correlation r between predicted and observed mixing angles is <0.25, the hypothesis is refuted. Equivalently, if models with stronger automorphism constraints (larger invariance subspaces) do not produce mixing angles closer to observed values than models with weaker constraints, the causal hypothesis fails.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Correlation coefficient r ≥ 0.60 between CY-geometry-predicted and experimentally observed lepton mixing angles (vs. null r < 0.15 for random texture); alternatively, ≥50% of D₆-constrained models predicting θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃ within ±3° of PDG (vs. expected ±15–20° for unconstrained random matrices).

experiment.approach: Systematically enumerate CY3 compactifications with non-Abelian automorphism groups from the Kreuzer-Skarke database using CyTools; compute D₆-invariant (2,1)-form decomposition for each; construct the neutrino Yukawa coupling matrix respecting the geometric zero pattern; diagonalize to extract predicted lepton mixing angles; compare predictions against observed PDG values using chi-squared goodness-of-fit and Pearson correlation.
steps: Query Kreuzer-Skarke reflexive polytope database for all 4D CY3 models; filter for those with h²¹ ≥ 16 and known automorphism groups (≥200 models).

For each selected model, use CyTools pipeline to compute the automorphism group action on the (2,1)-cohomology basis; decompose into irreducible representations of the automorphism group (D₆, S₄, A₄, T').
Identify the D₆-invariant (1-dimensional or small multi-dimensional) subspace of (2,1)-forms; compute the basis of invariant generators.

Construct the neutrino Yukawa coupling matrix Y_{ijk} = ∫_{CY3} Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k using CyTools triple-intersection geometry. Set Y_{ijk} = 0 for all couplings whose (2,1)-form factors transform non-trivially under the automorphism; allow non-zero entries only for geometrically invariant combinations.
Diagonalize the constrained Y_ν matrix (treating it as a 3×3 complex symmetric matrix in the weak-basis eigenbasis) to extract eigenvalues (neutrino masses) and the unitary mixing matrix V.
Extract the three mixing angles θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃ from V using standard PDG conventions (CKM-like parametrization).
Aggregate predicted angles across all ≥200 models; compute mean absolute deviation (MAD) from PDG central values and Pearson correlation coefficient r with observed angles.
Stratify results by automorphism group type (D₆ vs. others) and by the dimension of the invariant subspace; test whether stronger constraints correlate with better agreement with observation.
Perform sensitivity analysis: introduce small perturbations to the moduli (within the geometric stability region) and measure the robustness of predicted mixing angles.
Compare the distribution of predicted mixing angles against a null distribution generated from random unconstrained 3×3 Yukawa textures (10,000 random matrices).
tools: CyTools (Cytools/polytope analysis for CY compactifications)
Kreuzer-Skarke reflexive polytope database (PALP format)
SageMath or Macaulay2 (for automorphism group computation and representation decomposition)
Python (numpy, scipy for matrix diagonalization; sympy for symbolic representation theory)
PDG 2023 neutrino oscillation data (observed mixing angles and 1σ uncertainties)
Custom code for Yukawa texture generation from geometric invariant constraints
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–6 weeks: 1 week for database querying and model filtering; 1.5 weeks for automorphism group computation and representation analysis (parallelizable across ≥200 models); 1 week for Yukawa matrix construction and diagonalization (vectorized); 1 week for statistical analysis and visualization; 0.5–1 week for sensitivity/robustness studies and null-distribution generation.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke database (publicly available, ~500 million reflexive 4D polytopes); CyTools (open source); neutrino oscillation data from PDG (public); access to high-memory compute cluster for parallel matrix operations across ≥200 models (estimated ~10–50 GB RAM, ~100 GPU-hours or ~1000 CPU-hours).
experiment.expected_positive: Distribution of predicted lepton mixing angles θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃ clustered within ±3° of observed PDG values for ≥50% of D₆-constrained models; Pearson correlation r between geometry-predicted and observed angles ≥0.60; models with stronger automorphism constraints (larger invariant subspace dimension) show systematically smaller deviation from observed mixing angles.
experiment.expected_negative: Mean absolute deviation of predicted angles from PDG central values >8° for >70% of models; Pearson correlation r <0.25; no statistically significant trend between automorphism group strength and agreement with observation; predicted angles show no clustering and are indistinguishable from random texture models (null distribution overlaps completely).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The geometric zero pattern and structure of D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling matrices induce no statistically significant correlation with observed lepton mixing angles; the distribution of predicted angles is consistent with random unconstrained 3×3 Yukawa textures, and automorphism group constraints provide no predictive power beyond chance agreement with PDG values.
experiment.statistical_test: Pearson correlation test: H₀: r=0 vs. H_A: r>0.25 (one-tailed), α=0.05, with n=200 independent CY models (yielding ~200 predicted angle triples). Two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov test comparing the distribution of predicted angles (aggregated across models) against the null random-texture distribution (10,000 samples); α=0.05. Stratified analysis: ANOVA testing whether mean angular deviation differs significantly between automorphism group types (D₆ vs. A₄ vs. S₄) and by invariant-subspace dimension; Bonferroni-corrected α for multiple comparisons.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Pearson r ≥ 0.60 (vs. null r <0.15); equivalently, if true ρ=0.50, with n=200 samples, power to detect r≥0.35 is >90% at α=0.05 (two-tailed t-test for correlation). Practically, ≥50% of D₆-constrained models predicting mixing angles within ±3° of PDG central values (vs. expected ~5–10% for random textures, based on standard deviation ~20° across random ensemble) represents a ~5–10-fold enrichment; minimum effect size is a 2-fold enrichment (25% of constrained models accurate to ±3°), detectable with n=200 and chi-squared test at α=0.05 (power ~80%).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size justified as follows: assume true effect size is a Pearson r=0.55 (moderate correlation) and null hypothesis is r=0. With n=200 independent CY models, a two-tailed t-test for the significance of r yields power ≈90% at α=0.05. For the enrichment test (≥50% of models within ±3° vs. ≤10% null), assume binomial test with p₀=0.10 (null) vs. p_A=0.50 (alternative); with n=200 models, power is >95% at α=0.05 (two-sided). For the KS test comparing predicted distribution to random texture distribution, with n=200 predicted angles and 10,000 random samples, power to detect a difference (effect size h=0.4, moderate) is >85% at α=0.05. Convergence criterion for Yukawa matrix diagonalization: numerical precision of mixing angle extraction to ≤0.01°, achieved via standard eigendecomposition routines (default scipy tolerance).
limitations: The study assumes that the geometric Yukawa coupling matrix (computed via triple-intersection forms) accurately captures the coupling structure relevant to low-energy neutrino physics; in a full string compactification, worldsheet instanton corrections and higher-curvature effects could modify the matrix non-trivially.

The choice of which D₆-invariant combinations to include in the (2,1)-form basis is not unique at the level of homology; different choices of basis vectors could lead to different predicted mixing angles unless they are related by a symmetry-preserving basis change.

The neutrino mass scale is not predicted by the geometry alone; only the mixing angles and ratios of mass eigenvalues are constrained. The absolute neutrino mass hierarchy (normal vs. inverted) and Dirac/Majorana nature are not addressed.

Moduli stabilization (Kähler and complex structure) is not explicitly enforced; the analysis assumes the CY geometry is stable near the vacuum of interest. Variations in stabilized moduli could shift predicted angles outside the ±3° tolerance.

The sample is limited to CY3 compactifications from the Kreuzer-Skarke database; it excludes more general (non-reflexive) CY varieties and other string compactification geometries (e.g., G₂ or Spin(7) manifolds).

Replication by other groups requires independent access to CyTools, Kreuzer-Skarke data, and a comparable compute cluster; some computational bottlenecks (especially automorphism group enumeration) depend on the efficiency of the underlying PALP/CyTools implementation.
Multiple comparison problem: scanning over ≥200 models risks false positives from noise; multiple testing correction (Bonferroni) reduces power but is essential to control family-wise error rate.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational results show r≥0.60 and ≥50% agreement, the next phase would be a dedicated string phenomenology study: construct an explicit CY3 compactification (e.g., from a quotient of the quintic or a Calabi-Yau hypersurface in a weighted projective space) with controlled D₆ action; work out the full moduli stabilization via large-volume scenario or flux compactification (KKLT-like); compute the low-energy effective superpotential including neutrino Yukawa couplings and soft supersymmetry-breaking terms; perform threshold corrections and RG running from the GUT/string scale down to the electroweak scale; extract the physical neutrino mixing matrix at low energy and compare with PDG. This would require numerical solutions of the Picard-Fuchs system for the mirror geometry, detailed flux calculations, and threshold-correction computations—a 12–18 month collaborative theory effort. Alternatively, if results are negative (r<0.25), a wet-lab analog (in principle) would be exploring whether the discrete symmetries of neutrino-oscillation-driven quantum circuits or table-top flavor physics experiments can be engineered to mimic CY symmetry structures; this is primarily a proof-of-concept for the framework, not a direct test of the string theory prediction.

hypotheses.source_question: Can Calabi-Yau discrete automorphism symmetries (like D₆ on GL=12/D₆) theoretically predict or constrain the specific values of neutrino mixing angles (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) measured experimentally, and do D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings naturally generate the observed lepton flavor mixing texture without requiring additional Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings computed from GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau automorphisms causally constrain the PMNS lepton mixing matrix such that the predicted neutrino mixing angle theta13 lies within plus-minus 15 percent of the NuFIT experimentally measured central value (theta13 approximately 8.5 degrees) without invoking additional Froggatt-Nielsen fine-tuning, whereas non-symmetric or non-invariant coupling textures fail to satisfy this bound.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ discrete automorphism acts on the 20 complex-structure moduli of GL=12/D₆, reducing independent moduli to 5 D₆-invariant combinations. This restriction propagates to the period domain and Picard-Fuchs system, constraining the 26 surviving Yukawa couplings Y_ijk and Kähler-triple intersections kappa_abc. These couplings enter the neutrino mass matrix M_nu via type-I seesaw (M_nu proportional to Y_nu Y_nu-transpose divided by M_R); the D₆ symmetry induces a hierarchical texture-specific pattern in M_nu that when diagonalized produces mixing angles with reduced parameter freedom. This causal chain—automorphism structure to coupling constraints to mass matrix hierarchy to mixing angles—predicts theta13 as a derived quantity rather than a free parameter.
hypotheses.prediction: When D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings from GL=12/D₆ are used to construct the neutrino mass matrix via type-I seesaw and the resulting PMNS matrix is diagonalized, the predicted theta13 will differ from the NuFIT 2023 central value (8.5 degrees) by no more than 1.3 degrees (predicted theta13 in range 7.2 degrees to 9.8 degrees), whereas a control ensemble of non-invariant or random Yukawa textures will produce absolute difference of predicted theta13 and 8.5 degrees exceeding 3 degrees in more than 80 percent of realizations.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If after computing D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings for at least 5 candidate CY3 geometries with D₆ symmetry and constructing the neutrino mass matrix via type-I seesaw for each, the mean predicted theta13 across geometries deviates from the NuFIT central value (8.5 degrees) by more than 2.5 degrees, or if the standard deviation of predicted theta13 across the D₆-symmetric ensemble exceeds 3 degrees, the hypothesis is refuted. Alternatively, if non-invariant Yukawa textures from CY3 models without discrete symmetries produce theta13 values equally or more tightly clustered around the NuFIT value than invariant textures, the causal claim fails.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Predicted theta13 for D₆-invariant Yukawa textures must satisfy absolute value of (predicted theta13 minus 8.5 degrees) less than 1.3 degrees, and the concentration of D₆-symmetric predictions within the plus-minus 15 percent band must exceed 70 percent, compared to less than 20 percent for the control ensemble (assessed via binomial test, p less than 0.05).

experiment.approach: Computationally construct the D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling texture for a curated set of CY3 geometries with known D₆ automorphisms, feed these couplings into a type-I seesaw neutrino mass matrix calculator, diagonalize to extract PMNS mixing angles, and compare against NuFIT global oscillation fits. Simultaneously compute the same pipeline for control CY3 geometries without discrete symmetries to quantify the causal contribution of symmetry to mixing-angle precision.
steps: Query the Kreuzer-Skarke database and CYTools library to identify 5 to 10 CY3 geometries with confirmed D₆ discrete automorphism groups; prioritize GL=12/D₆ and deformations
For each CY3 geometry, use CyTools to compute the full set of D₆-invariant divisor classes and Mori cone generators; project the 20 complex-structure moduli onto 5 D₆-invariant combinations

Compute the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings Y_ijk for (2,1)-form indices via integration over the mirror polytope using Picard-Fuchs differential equations and monodromy matrices at selected moduli points
Compute Kähler-triple intersections kappa_abc for the same invariant divisors

Construct the effective Yukawa matrix for the lepton sector by assigning the 26 D₆-invariant couplings to lepton generation indices under the assumption that D₆ action permutes generations via orbifold-like quotients to S₃ flavor symmetry

Apply type-I seesaw formula: M_nu equals negative Y_nu times M_R-inverse times Y_nu-transpose, with M_R fixed at 10 to the 14 power GeV (baseline); vary over range 10 to the 12 power GeV to 10 to the 16 power GeV in sensitivity analysis
Diagonalize M_nu numerically to extract the PMNS mixing matrix U_PMNS and extract theta12, theta23, theta13 and CP phase delta_CP if the texture permits
Repeat steps 2 through 7 for a control ensemble of at least 5 CY3 geometries without discrete symmetries; randomly sample Yukawa couplings from the full unbroken moduli space

Compare predicted mixing angles (D₆-symmetric and control ensembles) against NuFIT 2023 global fit central values and plus-minus 1 sigma ranges: theta12 approximately 33.4 degrees, theta23 approximately 49.0 degrees, theta13 approximately 8.5 degrees

Quantify the statistical significance of tighter clustering in theta13 for D₆-invariant textures using one-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov test and compute the Bhattacharyya distance between predicted and NuFIT distributions
Perform sensitivity analysis: vary seesaw scale M_R, moduli-space base point, and the assignment of D₆ orbits to lepton generations; assess robustness of the theta13 prediction
If the D₆-symmetric prediction significantly outperforms the control ensemble, investigate whether a secondary U(1) symmetry can further refine the texture without breaking D₆ invariance
tools: CyTools - Yukawa coupling and Kähler-triple intersection computation from CY polytope data
Kreuzer-Skarke database - identify CY3 geometries with discrete symmetries
SymPy - construct and manipulate period integrals and monodromy matrices
NumPy and SciPy - diagonalize neutrino mass matrices and extract PMNS angles
NuFIT 2023 global oscillation-fit data - experimental reference values and uncertainties
Custom Python pipeline - orchestrate CyTools queries, Yukawa computation, seesaw formula, and statistical analysis
Singular and Macaulay2 - verify Picard-Fuchs equations and period-integral computations
experiment.estimated_effort: 8 to 12 weeks: 2 weeks data curation and CY geometry selection; 3 to 4 weeks Yukawa coupling computation and validation; 2 weeks type-I seesaw implementation; 2 to 3 weeks statistical analysis and comparison to NuFIT. Parallelizable across multiple CY geometries.
experiment.data_requirements: Kreuzer-Skarke reflexive-polytope database; CyTools codebase with SageMath and PALP dependencies; NuFIT 2023 global fit tables; moduli-space parametrization for each CY geometry via mirror symmetry. No proprietary data required.
experiment.expected_positive: The mean predicted theta13 from D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings lies within 7.2 degrees to 9.8 degrees with standard deviation less than 1.5 degrees; more than 70 percent of D₆-symmetric realizations fall within the NuFIT plus-minus 1 sigma band. Control ensemble shows mean absolute difference exceeding 3 degrees and less than 20 percent overlap with NuFIT band. One-sided KS test shows D₆-symmetric distribution is significantly tighter (p less than 0.05). Sensitivity analysis shows theta13 prediction remains stable under plus-minus 30 percent variation in M_R.
experiment.expected_negative: Mean predicted theta13 from D₆-invariant couplings deviates from NuFIT central value by more than 2.5 degrees, or standard deviation exceeds 3 degrees. Control ensemble produces equally tight or tighter clustering around NuFIT value. KS test shows no significant difference between D₆-symmetric and non-symmetric distributions (p greater than 0.10). Sensitivity analysis reveals greater than 50 percent variation in theta13 under reasonable M_R perturbations, indicating overfitting to a single moduli-space point.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H0: D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings from GL=12/D₆ CY automorphisms produce neutrino mixing angles theta13 with the same statistical distribution as non-invariant or randomly sampled Yukawa textures. The discrete symmetry does not causally constrain lepton flavor mixing.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov test comparing empirical cumulative distribution function of predicted theta13 (D₆-invariant ensemble) against NuFIT global fit distribution at alpha equals 0.05. Supplementary binomial test: does greater than 70 percent of D₆-symmetric predictions fall within plus-minus 15 percent of NuFIT central value? H0: p equals 0.50. One-sided test (Ha: p greater than 0.70). Effect size: Bhattacharyya distance between predicted and NuFIT distributions (target: greater than 0.8).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Difference in mean theta13 between D₆-invariant and non-symmetric ensembles at least 1.8 degrees (Cohen's d greater than 0.6, assuming common standard deviation approximately 3 degrees). Achievable with at least 5 CY geometries per ensemble and at least 50 moduli-space sampling points per geometry (N at least 250 predictions per group). Clustering concentration: at least 15 percentage-point difference in fraction of predictions within NuFIT plus-minus 1 sigma band between ensembles (binomial, p less than 0.05 at n equals 100 per group).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size per ensemble: at least 5 distinct CY geometries with D₆ symmetry times at least 10 independent moduli-space base points per geometry equals at least 50 predictions per D₆-invariant ensemble; control ensemble: at least 5 non-symmetric CY3 geometries times at least 10 random Yukawa samplings equals at least 50 predictions per control. Assumed effect size Cohen's d approximately 0.8 (predicted theta13 for D₆-symmetric: mean 8.6 degrees, SD 1.4 degrees; control: mean 11.2 degrees, SD 3.0 degrees). Two-sided KS test at alpha equals 0.05 with n1 equals n2 equals 50 achieves power approximately 0.75; increasing to n equals 75 per group yields power approximately 0.85. Convergence criterion: all Yukawa integrals and period computations converge to relative error less than 10 to the minus 6 power in Picard-Fuchs system; matrix diagonalization eigenvalues stable to machine precision.
limitations: Assignment of D₆ orbits to lepton generations is model-dependent and not uniquely determined by CY geometry; different orbit assignments yield different predictions. Mitigation: systematically scan all topologically distinct orbit assignments and report range of predictions.

Type-I seesaw assumes right-handed neutrinos at approximately 10 to the 14 power GeV; alternative mechanisms (type-II, inverse seesaw) yield different mass matrices. Mitigation: run sensitivity analysis under type-II seesaw and inverse-seesaw variants.

Yukawa coupling computation relies on numerical integration of periods; floating-point errors or incomplete monodromy-group coverage may bias results. Mitigation: validate against known closed-form expressions; use multiple integration algorithms and compare results.
NuFIT global fits include correlations not fully captured in a plus-minus 1 sigma ellipse. Mitigation: use the full NuFIT covariance matrix for chi-squared test instead of distance measures alone.

D₆ automorphism group is a simplistic proxy for realistic flavor symmetries; Standard Model flavor structure may require larger discrete groups. Mitigation: extend study to higher-symmetry CY geometries (S3, Delta(27), other discrete groups).

Kreuzer-Skarke database is finite and may not contain all geometrically distinct CY3 with D₆ symmetry; results generalize only within the known landscape. Mitigation: cross-check with independent CY3 databases (CICY, Calabi-Yau packages in SageMath).
experiment.requires_followup: If computational prediction succeeds, a follow-up wet-lab step would involve: (1) heterotic string computation to verify that D₆-invariant couplings arise from consistent string compactification (anomaly cancellation, tadpole conditions, moduli stabilization); (2) collider phenomenology to check predicted mass hierarchies against LHC constraints on flavor-changing neutral currents and rare decays; (3) direct neutrino mass measurements via beta-decay endpoint analysis or neutrinoless double-beta decay searches to confirm predicted mass ordering and absolute scale.

hypotheses.source_question: Can discrete flavor symmetries arising from CY3 automorphism groups (particularly D₆ and other non-Abelian groups) constrain the Wilson coefficients of the μ→eγ dipole operator in a way that either suppresses or enhances this LFV decay relative to other flavor-violating processes, and does the monodromy structure of the Picard-Fuchs system predict specific relationships between μ→eγ rates and other LFV observables?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆ automorphism group action on the moduli space of the GL=12/D₆ polytope constrains the Wilson coefficients of the dimension-6 LFV dipole operator O_μeγ such that the predicted μ→eγ branching ratio is suppressed by a factor of at least 3–5 relative to minimal supersymmetric extensions without discrete flavor symmetry, and this suppression is topologically protected by the monodromy structure of the Picard-Fuchs system.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ action on the 20 complex-structure moduli reduces to 5 invariant combinations, thereby restricting the functional freedom in the Yukawa texture. This constraint propagates to higher-dimensional effective operators through the structure of the Kähler potential and F-terms: the D₆-covariant basis of (2,1)-forms constrains both rank-3 Yukawa couplings and rank-4 dipole operators. Monodromy orbits in the Picard-Fuchs system, which encode quantum geometric properties of the CY3, enforce correlations between different operator coefficients such that LFV operators receive suppression factors absent in models with only U(1) flavor symmetries.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12/D₆ polytope, the Wilson coefficient C_L^μe (left-chiral LFV dipole) computed from D₆-invariant operator combinations will be at least 3-fold smaller than the median value across the CY3 landscape without imposed discrete symmetry, and the ratio of the μ→eγ branching ratio to the τ→μγ branching ratio will differ from U(1) predictions by ≥2-fold due to D₆-orbit structure.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: Direct computation via the extended CyTools pipeline shows that the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings alone, without additional Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism, do NOT suppress the LFV dipole operator coefficient C_L^μe below the median landscape value, OR the ratio BR(μ→eγ)/BR(τ→μγ) computed from D₆-covariant dimension-6 operators is indistinguishable (within <20% relative error) from U(1) flavor predictions without monodromy constraints.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Wilson coefficient reduction factor ≥3.0 (i.e., |C_L^μe(D₆)| ≤ |C_L^μe(generic)|/3); branching ratio ratio deviation ≥2-fold (|BR_ratio(D₆) − BR_ratio(U(1))|/BR_ratio(U(1)) > 1.0)

experiment.approach: Extend the CyTools computational pipeline to compute D₆-covariant and D₆-invariant basis elements in H^(2,1)(CY3) and H^(1,1)(CY3), then calculate dimension-6 LFV operator coefficients by integrating D₆-transformed (2,1)-forms against effective coupling tensors derived from Kähler geometry. Cross-validate via monodromy-orbit analysis in the Picard-Fuchs system to identify topologically protected suppression factors.
steps: Load the GL=12/D₆ polytope into CyTools; verify D₆ automorphism group action on the 20 complex-structure moduli and confirm reduction to 5 invariant combinations.
Compute the full basis of (2,1)-form moduli (h^2,1=20) and decompose under D₆; identify the 17 D₆-invariant and covariant basis elements explicitly.

Extend CyTools to compute dimension-5 and dimension-6 LFV operator coefficients: O_μeγ = (m_W^2/Λ²) × C_L^μe σ^μν F^μν e_R, and O_emu = rank-4 four-fermion operators. Integrate ∫_{CY3} Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k for all D₆-covariant triples.
Construct the D₆-representation matrices for each moduli basis element and apply to operator coefficients; retain only D₆-singlet combinations that enter the superpotential and effective action.
Compute the Picard-Fuchs differential system for the GL=12/D₆ polytope; extract monodromy matrices around singular divisors in the moduli space.
For each LFV operator coefficient, determine which monodromy orbits contain it and extract topological suppressions by analyzing exponential behavior along monodromy geodesics.
Calculate predicted Wilson coefficients C_L^μe(D₆) and compare against: (a) U(1) horizontal symmetry baseline, (b) random CY3 landscape median, (c) minimal SUSY without flavor symmetry.
Compute BR(μ→eγ) via the formula BR = [α/(G_F m_μ)]² |C_L|² and similarly BR(τ→μγ); form the ratio and compare to U(1) and landscape predictions.
Validate numerical stability by recomputing on a nearby polytope in the same family (if available) or on a degree-12 mirror manifold to assess robustness of D₆ action.
tools: CyTools (extended: add LFV operator module)
SageMath for symbolic D₆ representation theory and monodromy orbit decomposition
Macaulay2 for Picard-Fuchs system computation and singularity analysis
Python/SymPy for Wilson coefficient integration and numerical validation
Matchgate library or custom code for Kähler metric computation on CY3 moduli space
CY3 Hodge-database for baseline landscape statistics
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–5 weeks: 1 week CyTools extension and D₆ basis computation; 1–2 weeks Picard-Fuchs monodromy extraction and orbit analysis; 1–2 weeks LFV operator integration and validation; 1 week comparison and robustness checks.
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12/D₆ polytope equations (from Kreuzer-Skarke or PolyDB); CY3 Hodge diamond data (h^1,1, h^2,1) for landscape baseline; computational resources: ≥32 GB RAM, GPU optional for large matrix operations; public monodromy tables for similar CY3s (e.g., quintic hypersurface).
experiment.expected_positive: The extended CyTools pipeline computes D₆-invariant LFV operator coefficients that are reduced by a factor of ≥3 relative to median landscape values; monodromy analysis confirms that these suppression factors are locked to topological invariants (residues of Picard-Fuchs forms); predicted BR(μ→eγ) ranges from 10^-14 to 10^-16, and BR(τ→μγ)/BR(μ→eγ) ≈ 0.1–0.3, differing substantially (>2-fold) from U(1) baseline predictions.
experiment.expected_negative: D₆-invariant operator coefficients show no statistically significant suppression (reduction factor <1.5) compared to U(1) or landscape medians; monodromy orbits do not cluster LFV operators into a reduced subspace; BR(μ→eγ) predictions fall within the same range as generic MSSM without flavor symmetry, indicating that discrete symmetry provides no new constraint beyond what Froggatt-Nielsen alone supplies.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆ automorphism group action on moduli does not reduce the dimensional freedom available to LFV operator coefficients more than a generic U(1) flavor symmetry would; consequently, the predicted Wilson coefficients and branching ratios for μ→eγ are statistically indistinguishable from minimal SUSY or landscape averages, and monodromy structure does not introduce topologically protected suppressions.
experiment.statistical_test: One-way ANOVA comparing three populations: (1) D₆-invariant LFV operator coefficients from this calculation, (2) U(1)-constrained predictions from literature, (3) median landscape values (random CY3 sample, n≥30). Primary outcome: mean suppression factor in group 1 vs. group 3, tested via two-sample t-test (α=0.05, power=0.90) assuming unequal variances. Secondary: ratio of standard deviations to assess whether monodromy constraints reduce variance. Computational convergence check: verify Picard-Fuchs monodromy matrices to residual norm <10^-8.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Suppression factor ≥3.0 (|C_μeγ^D₆| / |C_μeγ^landscape median| ≤ 1/3, Cohen's d ≥0.8 with n=30 random CY3s for baseline); branching ratio ratio deviation ≥100% (|BR_ratio^D₆ − BR_ratio^U(1)| / BR_ratio^U(1) > 1.0); Picard-Fuchs monodromy residue >0.1 (normalized).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: For three-group ANOVA: assume baseline landscape operator coefficient σ≈0.3 (normalized units), target effect size Cohen's f ≈0.4 (moderate), α=0.05, power=0.90 → recommended n≥25 per group (one representative CY3 from D₆ family plus ≥25 control CY3s from landscape). For Picard-Fuchs monodromy test, convergence criterion: ||M_n − M_{n-1}|| <10^-8 in Frobenius norm (deterministic, not stochastic, so no power analysis needed). Computational convergence typically achieved within 10^4–10^5 basis vector evaluations.
limitations: GL=12/D₆ is a single representative; results may not generalize to other D₆-symmetric CY3s or non-Abelian groups like A₄, S₃; requires follow-up on a family of D₆-symmetric polytopes to establish robustness.

LFV operator computation relies on Kähler potential form assumptions (large-volume scenario, no flux-induced corrections); warping, higher-loop corrections, or strong-coupling regime may alter conclusions.

Picard-Fuchs monodromy structure is topological but assumes no additional hidden symmetries or accidental cancellations in the specific CY3; manual verification of modular forms and periods recommended.

Connection to observable μ→eγ decay rate requires precise determination of soft-SUSY-breaking soft masses and gaugino compositions; EFT matching at M_GUT scale introduces model-dependent threshold corrections not accounted for here.
Does not yet address how D₆ discrete symmetry emerges from gauge coupling unification or string dualities; assumes D₆ acts consistently with SUSY-preserving compactification.

Computational method assumes exact arithmetic feasible; numerical precision of Gröbner basis computation and matrix eigenvalue evaluation may limit accuracy of operator coefficients to ≈3–4 decimal places.
experiment.requires_followup: Full confirmation requires: (1) Wet-lab indirect constraint via MEG/MEG II experimental limits on BR(μ→eγ) to test whether predicted suppression factors are consistent with observation (BR < 4.2×10^-13 current limit); (2) Matching onto explicit SUSY model with gauge coupling unification to determine soft SUSY-breaking spectrum and compute μ→eγ amplitude in full MSSM; (3) Muon g−2 and τ→μγ branching ratio predictions to cross-validate flavor texture predictions against other precision observables; (4) Generalization to a family of non-Abelian discrete symmetry groups (A₄, S₄, Δ(96)) on different CY3 geometries to assess universality of monodromy-driven LFV suppression.

hypotheses.source_question: How do classical Lie gauge groups (SU(N), SO(N), Sp(2N)) arising from string compactifications on CY3 with discrete symmetries constrain the structure of discrete flavor symmetries, and can the monodromy action of the continuous gauge group predict which discrete subgroups (e.g., D₆) are realized geometrically?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the monodromy action of the classical Lie gauge group on the period vector of a Calabi-Yau threefold geometrically determines which discrete flavor symmetries remain unbroken, and that the dimension of the monodromy-stable subspace of D₆-invariant moduli equals the rank of the continuous gauge group minus the number of broken discrete generators.
hypotheses.mechanism: The Picard-Fuchs differential equations governing the holomorphic periods (Ω, J_a∧Ω, κ_{ab}Ω, …) define a monodromy representation ρ_mono: π₁(ℳ) → GL(h¹¹+h²¹+1) that acts on the period lattice. This monodromy action simultaneously constrains the D₆-invariant subspace of complex-structure moduli because periods are periods of holomorphic forms pulled back via automorphisms. We propose that the stabilizer subgroup of the period vector under monodromy action is isomorphic to a subgroup of D₆ that remains unbroken, and conversely, any D₆ generator whose action is not stabilized by monodromy must be broken by the dynamics of gauge-group formation. The classical gauge group rank (determined by divisor-induced U(1) factors and their anomaly cancellation) fixes the dimension of the orbifold quotient, which in turn constrains the monodromy representation and hence which D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings remain protected.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL(12,D₆) polytope, the monodromy-invariant subspace of D₆-covariant periods has dimension ≥ 5 (matching the 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure combinations), and at least 3 of the 6 D₆ generators have monodromy-stable fixed points on the period vector. Furthermore, the 26 surviving D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings satisfy at least 5 independent linear relations derived from monodromy-orbit closure, reducing the effective rank of independent couplings to ≤ 21, and these relations correlate with vanishing of electron-muon mass ratio m_e/m_μ unless a secondary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism is invoked.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the monodromy-stable subspace has dimension < 3, or if only 1 or fewer D₆ generators stabilize the period vector, then monodromy does not constrain the discrete symmetry and the hypothesis is refuted. Alternatively, if the monodromy matrix has trivial intersection with the D₆-action (no non-trivial simultaneous eigenvectors), the causal link is broken. Finally, if the 26 Yukawa couplings contain fewer than 2 independent monodromy-induced linear relations (i.e., the monodromy constraint is vacuous), the hypothesis fails.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Dimension of monodromy-stable D₆-invariant subspace ≥ 5; at least 3 D₆ generators with non-trivial stabilizer; ≥ 5 independent monodromy-induced linear relations among 26 couplings (rank reduction > 19%); cross-group explained variance (correlation between gauge-rank jumps and discrete-symmetry breaking pattern) > 0.7 (Spearman ρ).

experiment.approach: Computationally extract the Picard-Fuchs system for the GL(12,D₆) polytope using CyTools, compute the monodromy matrix representation on period vectors, decompose it under D₆ irreducibles, identify monodromy-stable invariant combinations, and verify that monodromy-induced linear relations among the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings correlate with classical gauge-group structure constants (divisor intersections, anomaly cancellation).
steps: Step 1: Use CyTools to load the GL(12,D₆) polytope database entry (h¹¹=17, h²¹=20) and extract the Mori cone, Stanley-Reisner ideal, and toric divisor class group.
Step 2: Compute the Picard-Fuchs differential system using the toric-variety algorithm (Dwork-family approach or Gelfand-Kapranov-Zelevinsky hypergeometric); degree is dim(H¹(CY3)) + 1 = 38.

Step 3: Identify a basis of fundamental periods {Ω, ω₁, …, ω₃₇} by solving the Picard-Fuchs equations around a generic point in moduli space and a special point (e.g., Fermat limit or MUM point) using symbolic integration or CyTools numeric routines.

Step 4: Compute the monodromy matrix M_i ∈ GL(38) for each generator σ_i of π₁(ℳ) by analytically continuing periods around codimension-1 singularities in moduli space (using the local-system structure of the period lattice).

Step 5: Decompose each M_i into irreducible representations of D₆ (7 irreducibles: 1, 1', 1'', 2, 2', 3, 3'); identify block-diagonal structure and compute stabilizer subgroup {M ∈ ⟨M₁,…,M₆⟩ : M·v = v for v ∈ span(D₆-invariant periods)}.
Step 6: Extract the 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure combinations ψ₁,…,ψ₅ using Molien–Poincaré and compute how each ψ_α transforms under monodromy: M_i·ψ_α = Λ_{iα}·ψ_α (eigenvalue structure).
Step 7: Compute the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings Y_{jkl} via Kähler-form and (2,1)-form integration using CyTools geometry module and symbolic period derivatives: Y_{jkl} ∝ ∂³Ω/∂ψ_j∂ψ_k∂ψ_l.
Step 8: Construct the Yukawa coupling matrix Y ∈ ℝ^(26) (flattened); compute its rank-deficit via singular-value decomposition (SVD).

Step 9: Identify linear relations among Y entries by computing the null space of the Yukawa matrix; extract relations that are preserved under monodromy action (i.e., apply monodromy-induced permutations of basis elements and verify relation persistence).

Step 10: For each D₆ generator τ ∈ D₆, compute the gauge-group factor removed by its breaking: use divisor-class-group quotient and intersection-matrix rank reduction to estimate the U(1)-factor loss or non-Abelian-group enhancement.

Step 11: Build a correlation matrix C_{ab} between (a) D₆-generator monodromy-stability index s_a ∈ {0,1} and (b) gauge-group rank jump at the locus where τ_a is spontaneously broken; compute Spearman ρ (non-parametric correlation, robust to non-linearity).

Step 12: Perform sensitivity analysis: vary CY complex-structure moduli along the Kähler cone and track co-evolution of (monodromy eigenvalues, D₆ stability, gauge-group rank); report correlation strength and statistical significance (p < 0.01).

Step 13: Cross-validate by computing the 26 Yukawa couplings at multiple moduli-space loci (MUM, conifold, large-complex-structure limits) and verify that monodromy-induced linear relations remain robust across the moduli space.
tools: CyTools (Python; CY database + Picard-Fuchs solver + Kähler/period integrator)
SageMath (symbolic Picard-Fuchs computation, monodromy matrix algebra, representation theory; D₆ character tables and irreducible decomposition)
MAGMA or GAP (discrete-group algebra, D₆ subgroup lattice, stabilizer computation)
NumPy/SciPy (SVD, linear-algebra kernels, Spearman correlation, permutation testing)
Mathematica (if necessary for symbolic analytic continuation and monodromy tracking around singularities)
Custom Python pipeline (workflow orchestration: feed CyTools output → PF solver → monodromy → D₆ decomposition → Yukawa → correlation)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–6 weeks compute time (4–8 weeks calendar, including code development and validation). Picard-Fuchs system extraction: 2–3 days. Monodromy matrix computation (numerical or semi-analytical): 1–2 weeks (convergence of period integrals at high precision). D₆ representation decomposition: 1–2 days. Yukawa coupling calculation: 1 week. Correlation and sensitivity analysis: 1 week. Cross-validation and interpretation: 1 week.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools polytope database (GL(12,D₆) entry); existing CY3 mirror family periods (Picard-Fuchs reference solutions from literature or pre-computed CyTools cache); D₆ character table and conjugacy classes (standard group-theory library); optional: mirror-symmetry period integrals from physics literature (CICY or toric examples for benchmarking).
experiment.expected_positive: Monodromy-stable subspace has dimension 5–7 (matches D₆-invariant moduli); ≥3 D₆ generators have non-trivial monodromy-stabilizer; ≥5 independent linear relations hold among 26 Yukawa couplings with rank reduction ≥ 19%; Spearman ρ(gauge-rank jumps, D₆-breaking pattern) > 0.7, p < 0.01; monodromy-induced relations persist across multiple moduli-space loci.
experiment.expected_negative: Monodromy-stable subspace has dimension < 3; monodromy action commutes trivially with D₆ action (no constraint); fewer than 2 linear relations among Yukawa couplings; Spearman ρ < 0.3 or p > 0.05 (no meaningful correlation between gauge-breaking and D₆-breaking); Yukawa relations vanish at some moduli-space locus (relations are accidental, not monodromy-enforced).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The monodromy action on the period vector is statistically independent of the D₆-action on complex-structure moduli. Equivalently, the stabilizer of D₆-invariant periods under monodromy is trivial, and the dimension of monodromy-stable D₆-invariant subspace is 0 or 1 (by chance alone).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided Spearman rank-correlation test: ρ(gauge-rank evolution, D₆-stability indices) with α = 0.01, minimum ρ ≥ 0.7 for acceptance. For linear-relation rank deficit: χ² goodness-of-fit comparing observed rank reduction to null model (rank unchanged). For monodromy-stabilizer dimension: exact enumeration with logical reject rule (dimension ≥ 5 required; dimension < 3 refutes hypothesis). No multiple-hypothesis correction needed (single primary test).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Monodromy-stable D₆-invariant subspace dimension ≥ 5 (out of 5 D₆-invariant basis elements); ≥3 of 6 D₆ generators with non-trivial stabilizer index ≥ 1; Spearman ρ > 0.7 (large effect size for rank correlation); rank reduction of 26 Yukawa couplings ≥ 5 independent linear relations (≥ 19% reduction in effective degrees of freedom).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: This is a computational experiment with deterministic algebraic components (monodromy matrix, SVD, group algebra). No sample size in classical sense; instead, convergence criterion: period-integral evaluation at 100+ digit precision (using mpmath or Arb), monodromy analytic continuation at ≥ 500 mesh points in moduli space, and permutation testing of correlation with 1000 random D₆-generator relabelings to establish significance. Power = 1 (exact computation) for dimension and rank tests; for Spearman correlation, power ≈ 0.95 with ρ = 0.7, n = 26 Yukawa couplings, α = 0.01.
limitations: Computational precision: numerical monodromy matrix extraction requires high-precision period evaluation; convergence near singularities (conifold, LCS limits) is slow; algebraic Picard-Fuchs solutions would eliminate this but are not always available.

D₆ representation choice: decomposition assumes a fixed geometric action of D₆ on CY3; if CY3 has a larger automorphism group, the assumed D₆ embedding may be incomplete, masking additional constraints.
Yukawa coupling truncation: we use 26 D₆-invariant couplings; full E₆ or SO(10) GUT models may require additional matter multiplets, changing the Yukawa structure.

Moduli-space sampling: correlation test uses discrete sampling along moduli space; if true co-evolution is non-monotonic, sampling density must be high enough to capture the pattern; converged result requires ≥ 100–200 moduli-space points.

Mirror-symmetry validity: Picard-Fuchs system assumes quantum-corrected mirror family; large-radius or small-complex-structure limits may admit classical (non-quantum) description, potentially weakening monodromy constraints.

Absence of wet-lab validation: this experiment is purely mathematical/computational; predictions about realistic Yukawa hierarchies (m_e/m_μ) remain untested without string-scale to TeV-scale matching (requires additional low-energy SUSY breaking model).
experiment.requires_followup: To confirm that monodromy-predicted discrete flavor symmetries actually suppress unwanted Yukawa couplings in a realistic string compactification: (1) Extend the GL(12,D₆) analysis to full E₆ gauge group and three generations of matter (27-plet families), deriving the complete Frobenius basis of Yukawa couplings. (2) Compute soft SUSY-breaking masses and gaugino masses from the CY geometry (CyTools + SOFTSUSY pipeline), then run the renormalization group down to TeV scale. (3) Compare predicted mass-matrix eigenvalues and CKM angles to experimental values; if agreement is within 10–20%, monodromy prediction is validated. (4) Wet-lab test: Search for anomalous rare-decay branching ratios (e.g., μ → eγ, K_L → μe) that would be enhanced if discrete flavor symmetry from monodromy is absent—requires precision flavor-physics experiments (MEG, Belle-II, or future experiments). This follow-up is beyond the scope of the current computational experiment.

hypotheses.source_question: Can D₆-invariant Yukawa textures in Calabi-Yau threefolds with discrete symmetries predict the Majorana CP phases (α, β) that appear in the neutrino mixing matrix, rather than treating them as independent parameters or requiring secondary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆-invariant periods in the Picard-Fuchs system of the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau threefold directly determine the relative phases of Yukawa couplings, and these phases causally generate the observed Majorana CP phases (α, β) in the neutrino mixing matrix without requiring secondary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms.
hypotheses.mechanism: The holomorphic (3,0)-form Ω and the (2,1)-forms χᵢ are acted upon by the D₆ automorphism group. Under monodromy transformations in the Picard-Fuchs system, the periods ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χᵢ ∧ χⱼ ∧ χₖ acquire phase arguments φ^{ijk} that are fixed by the D₆ action on moduli space. These phases propagate directly into the neutrino Yukawa matrix Y_ν^{ij} = λ^{ij} e^{iφ^{ij}}, constraining the unitary transformation that diagonalizes Y_ν and thus fixing the Majorana phases α, β in the PMNS matrix U_PMNS. Thus D₆ geometry causally fixes phase structure → Yukawa phases → Majorana CP phases.
hypotheses.prediction: The predicted Majorana CP phases (α, β) derived from D₆-equivariant period integrals will match the PDG-compatible range (α, β ∈ [0, 2π]) with prediction error < 15° (i.e., phase difference Δφ < π/12 rad ≈ 0.26) for at least 3 out of 4 independent CP-phase scenarios (normal hierarchy ×2, inverted hierarchy ×2). Additionally, the D₆-constrained prediction of θ₁₃ will agree with the experimentally measured value θ₁₃ ≈ 8.5° to within 20% relative error.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the computed Majorana phases α, β derived from D₆-invariant periods differ from the PDG-compatible range by more than 30° (Δφ > π/6 rad ≈ 0.52), or if θ₁₃ predicted by the model deviates from the experimental value by >30% relative error, the hypothesis is refuted. Additionally, if the phases are independent of D₆ action (i.e., monodromy contributes vanishing phase ≪ 1° to any of the 26 couplings), or if fitting the observed CP phases requires ad hoc tuning of >50% of the independent Yukawa phases, the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Phase prediction accuracy: Δφ < 15° (π/12 rad ≈ 0.26) in at least 75% of hierarchies tested; θ₁₃ agreement: relative error < 20%; explained variance in PMNS phases attributable to D₆ geometry: R² > 0.6 (i.e., D₆ constraints explain ≥60% of observed phase variation across the parameter scan).

experiment.approach: Systematically compute D₆-equivariant period integrals for the GL=12/D₆ CY3 using CyTools, retaining full complex phases, then map these phases into the neutrino Yukawa matrix, diagonalize to extract PMNS parameters, and compare predicted α, β, θ₁₃ against PDG values and global oscillation constraints.
steps: Step 1: Use CyTools to compute all 26 D₆-invariant Kähler intersection numbers κ_{abc} and their phase arguments under monodromy transformations in the Picard-Fuchs system; document the monodromy matrix M acting on periods.

Step 2: Compute the D₆-equivariant period integrals ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χᵢ ∧ χⱼ ∧ χₖ for all 26 invariant combinations, retaining both magnitude and phase; organize into a 5×5 or 6×6 complex Yukawa matrix Y_ν (depending on number of family generations).

Step 3: Parametrize the Yukawa matrix as Y_ν^{ij} = λ^{ij} e^{iφ^{ij}} where λ^{ij} come from CyTools magnitudes and φ^{ij} are derived from monodromy action; verify that all phases are D₆-invariant (i.e., phases are independent of choice of generators or lift to universal cover).

Step 4: For each of 4 neutrino mass scenarios (normal hierarchy with 2 CP-phase landscapes; inverted hierarchy with 2 landscapes), numerically diagonalize Y_ν to extract right-handed neutrino mass matrix M_RR and left-handed mixing matrix U_L, giving PMNS U_PMNS = U_L^† U_CKM.
Step 5: Extract the Majorana phases α, β and the PMNS mixing angles θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃, δ_CP from the diagonalized mixing matrix for each scenario.

Step 6: Compare predicted (α, β, θ₁₃) against PDG 2023 values and global oscillation fit ranges (including recent T2K, NOνA, and Daya Bay data); compute phase prediction error Δφ and relative error in θ₁₃.

Step 7: Perform sensitivity analysis: vary the 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure moduli by ±5% and recompute phases to quantify robustness of predictions; measure how much D₆ geometry constrains phase space vs. residual freedom.

Step 8: Scan parameter space (CY moduli, Yukawa couplings, GUT-scale inputs) to identify if observed CP phases can be reproduced by D₆ geometry alone (R² > 0.6) or if secondary mechanisms (Froggatt-Nielsen, string scale CP violation, higher-dimensional operators) are necessary.
tools: CyTools (Calabi-Yau triangulation and period computation; https://github.com/Forest-Kobayashi/CyTools)
SageMath / SymPy (symbolic computation of monodromy matrices and phase tracking)
Mathematica or Python (Yukawa matrix diagonalization, PMNS extraction)
NuFIT global oscillation data (PDG 2023 and NuFIT 5.2 PMNS constraints)
Custom Python pipeline (D₆-equivariance validation, phase tracking across moduli scans)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–6 weeks compute: Week 1–2: CyTools period computations and monodromy matrix derivation; Week 2–3: Yukawa matrix assembly and phase parametrization; Week 3–4: Numerical diagonalization and PMNS extraction across all 4 hierarchies; Week 4–5: comparison with PDG, sensitivity analysis, and R² quantification; Week 5–6: publication-ready visualization and cross-validation.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database for GL=12/D₆ polytope (or compute triangulations de novo); PDG 2023 PMNS mixing angles and Majorana phase ranges; NuFIT 5.2 global oscillation fit covariance matrix; D₆ character table and invariant polynomial basis.
experiment.expected_positive: Predicted Majorana phases α, β lie within ±15° of the PDG-compatible central value for ≥3/4 mass hierarchies; predicted θ₁₃ agrees with experiment to <20% relative error; D₆-geometry explains ≥60% of variance in PMNS phases (R² > 0.6); monodromy action introduces ≥10° phase shift in at least 10 of the 26 Yukawa couplings, demonstrating that D₆ action is non-trivial.
experiment.expected_negative: Predicted phases differ from PDG values by >30°; θ₁₃ disagreement >30% relative error; monodromy contributes <5° phase to all Yukawa couplings (i.e., phases are generic, not D₆-selected); residual phase freedom after applying D₆ constraints requires >50% ad hoc tuning to match experiment; R² < 0.3 indicating D₆ geometry explains <30% of phase variance.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The Majorana CP phases α, β in the neutrino mixing matrix are independent of the D₆ automorphism action on the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau threefold. Equivalently, the relative phases of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings carry no information about the PMNS phases, and thus the CP phases must be determined by secondary mechanisms (Froggatt-Nielsen, string-scale, or GUT-scale physics) orthogonal to D₆ geometry.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided comparison of predicted phases (α̂, β̂, θ̂₁₃) against PDG central values (α_PDG, β_PDG, θ₁₃^{PDG}) using the Mahalanobis distance D² = (θ̂ − θ_PDG)ᵀ Σ⁻¹ (θ̂ − θ_PDG) where Σ is the covariance matrix from NuFIT. Reject H₀ if D² < 7.81 (corresponding to 98% confidence for 3 degrees of freedom, i.e., α, β, θ₁₃). Alternatively, perform a linear regression of predicted phases on D₆-invariant monodromy phases and test if the regression coefficient is significantly nonzero (t-test, two-sided, α = 0.05); reject H₀ if t > 1.96 and R² > 0.6.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Phase offset Δφ ≥ 15° (≈0.26 rad) detectable with 4 independent scenarios (normal/inverted hierarchy × 2 CP landscapes); relative error in θ₁₃ ≥ 20% detectable with CyTools numerical precision ~10⁻⁶; R² ≥ 0.6 requires ≤4 free parameters per 26 Yukawa couplings after D₆ symmetry reduction (i.e., 4/26 ≈ 15% residual freedom).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Computational experiment: no statistical power in the classical sense, but rather convergence and numerical precision. CyTools period integrals converge to machine precision (~10⁻¹⁵ relative error in magnitudes; phase arguments stable to ~10⁻⁶ rad at 64-bit float). Yukawa matrix diagonalization via SVD converges in O(n³) flops (n=5–6 families); solve time <1 second. Sensitivity analysis: sample 10 moduli perturbations × 4 hierarchies = 40 independent computations, each taking ~10 seconds, total ~7 minutes. Mahalanobis distance test: 3 DOF, 98% confidence, null distribution χ²₃; observed D² must satisfy D² < 7.81 to reject H₀. Linear regression: assume 26 observations (one per Yukawa coupling), R² > 0.6 requires slope ≠ 0 at α = 0.05 two-sided t-test; minimum detectable slope ~0.15 (dimensionless, i.e., 15° phase change per unit monodromy strength). No additional sample size needed beyond the 26 couplings and 4 hierarchies already specified.
