limitations: CyTools computes periods numerically to finite precision; phase arguments φ^{ij} are only meaningful to ~10⁻⁶ rad precision, so very small phase differences (<0.1°) cannot be resolved.

The GL=12/D₆ polytope is a single Calabi-Yau example; results may not generalize to other CY manifolds or other discrete symmetry groups (e.g., Z₃, S₃, S₄). Validation across >3 independent CY examples would strengthen the claim.

Neutrino Yukawa matrix is 3×3 at low energy, but embedding in GUT (e.g., SO(10)) requires 5×5 matrices; choice of GUT model affects extracted Majorana phases. Results depend on which GUT completion is assumed.
Comparison with PDG/NuFIT assumes that the GL=12/D₆ model can be meaningfully matched to the Standard Model at low energies (requires explicit string-GUT matching, not done here).

Monodromy matrix M in Picard-Fuchs is computed for the full complex-structure moduli space; projecting onto D₆-invariant directions may introduce additional phase constraints not captured by the naive period integral.

No experimental input from oscillation data is used to constrain CY moduli; predictions are pure theoretical extrapolations. Feedback loop (tuning moduli to match oscillation data) could artificially inflate apparent agreement.
experiment.requires_followup: No wet-lab follow-up required. However, to fully validate this hypothesis, a subsequent computational step would be to embed the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau in an explicit GUT model (e.g., heterotic E₆ or type IIA SU(5) flux compactification) and compute the matching between CY moduli and GUT-scale Yukawa matrices, ensuring that D₆-invariant phases survive the descent to the Standard Model neutrino sector. Additionally, a global string-landscape scan over >100 CY manifolds with discrete symmetries would assess whether D₆-like constraints on Majorana phases are generic (supporting the hypothesis) or special to this polytope (weakening generalizability).

hypotheses.source_question: How do D-brane configurations on D₆-symmetric Calabi-Yau threefolds constrain the discrete flavor symmetry group, and can the choice of D-brane wrapping numbers lift or break the D₆ invariance of Yukawa couplings?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D-brane wrappings on non-D₆-invariant divisors of the GL=12/D₆ polytope causally break the D₆ geometric symmetry by introducing selection rules that forbid a subset of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings, thereby reducing the effective coupling rank and naturally generating the observed quark-lepton mass hierarchy without secondary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms.
hypotheses.mechanism: D-brane configurations wrapping homology cycles couple to the Yukawa triple intersection through worldvolume fermion zero modes (index theorem). When D-branes wrap non-invariant divisors, their configuration breaks the D₆ symmetry explicitly, which propagates to the open-string sector via tadpole-cancellation constraints and Chan-Paton multiplicity rules. This selectively forbids certain (i,j,k) triplets in the Yukawa coupling Y_{ijk} ∝ ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k, reducing the 26 couplings to a smaller viable subset whose rank structure reproduces realistic fermion masses and mixing angles.
hypotheses.prediction: Among the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings, a tadpole-consistent D-brane stack wrapping at least one non-invariant divisor will selectively zero out ≥6 couplings (>20% reduction) while preserving a rank-≤3 effective texture in the quark sector and rank-≤2 in the lepton sector, achieving an up/down mass ratio ≥10 and θ₁₃ ≲ 0.005 without additional symmetry assumptions.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, for all tadpole-consistent D-brane wrappings on the GL=12/D₆ polytope, non-invariant divisor stacks either: (a) preserve all 26 couplings unchanged (no selection-rule reduction), OR (b) reduce the quark/lepton Yukawa rank to ≤2 and ≥4 respectively (inverting our prediction), OR (c) produce a quark up/down mass ratio <3 (failing to approach realistic ~40–100 hierarchy) — then the hypothesis is refuted, and secondary mechanisms are necessary.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥6 forbidden couplings (20% reduction of 26); quark sector Yukawa rank ≤3; lepton sector rank ≤2; m_u/m_d > 10 (mass ratio); θ₁₃ < 0.01 (mixing angle consistency with CKM).

experiment.approach: Computationally enumerate all divisors of the GL=12/D₆ polytope, identify D₆-invariant vs. non-invariant cycles, then systematically compute Yukawa coupling reduction induced by D-brane wrappings via index-theorem zero-mode multiplicity. Cross-validate with CyTools cohomology and monodromy constraints, then assess whether the resulting Yukawa matrix reproduces realistic fermion mass hierarchies.
steps: Step 1: Use CyTools to extract the full divisor basis (Mori generators and toric geometry) of the GL=12/D₆ polytope; identify the ~5 D₆-invariant linear combinations via character decomposition under the dihedral action.
Step 2: For each divisor (invariant and non-invariant), compute its Hodge numbers h^{1,1} and pairing data; validate against known h^{1,1}=11 constraint.
Step 3: Enumerate all physically distinct D-brane wrapping types (D3, D5, D7 on the GL=12/D₆ base and mirror dual); for each, classify by invariance under D₆.

Step 4: For each wrapping configuration, compute the worldvolume fermion zero-mode index via Atiyah–Singer index theorem on the wrapped divisor; tabulate multiplicity of massless open-string states contributing to Yukawa terms κ_{abc} and Y_{ijk}.
Step 5: Impose tadpole-cancellation constraints (total RR charge = 0) and consistency with the D₆ action; enumerate all consistent brane stacks.
Step 6: For each tadpole-consistent stack, map the selection rules onto the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings; record which (i,j,k) triplets are forbidden (multiplicity = 0).
Step 7: For each non-trivial stack (≥1 non-invariant wrapping), construct the resulting Yukawa matrix (26×26 → reduced), compute its rank and eigenvalue spectrum.
Step 8: Extract the effective quark and lepton Yukawa textures; compute mass ratios (m_u/m_d, m_c/m_s, m_t/m_b), CKM mixing angles (especially θ₁₃), and compare to empirical values.

Step 9: For all stacks that achieve quark rank ≤3 and lepton rank ≤2 with realistic mass ratios, compute the residual flavor symmetry group as the intersection of D₆ with the stabilizer of the surviving couplings.
Step 10: Cross-check divisor invariance and wrapping selection rules against Picard-Fuchs monodromy constraints via CyTools period computations; verify consistency with the mirror CY geometry.
tools: CyTools (toric geometry, divisor enumeration, Hodge numbers, period computations)
SageMath / Macaulay2 (character decomposition, D₆ representation analysis)
Custom index-theorem calculator (worldvolume fermion zero modes on divisors)
PALP / polytope-enumeration code (wrapping classification, tadpole constraints)
GAP (discrete symmetry group algebra, residual group computation)
Python/NumPy (Yukawa matrix rank, eigenvalue spectrum, mass hierarchies)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–6 weeks (full divisor enumeration ~1 week, zero-mode index calculations ~1.5 weeks, tadpole consistency + wrapping classification ~1 week, Yukawa reduction + mass-ratio extraction ~1.5 weeks, monodromy validation ~1 week).
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12/D₆ polytope definition (toric coordinates); CyTools output (divisor basis, Hodge diamond, periods); D₆ character table; empirical fermion mass data (PDG); CKM/PMNS mixing angles.
experiment.expected_positive: At least one tadpole-consistent D-brane stack wrapping a non-invariant divisor forbids ≥6 of the 26 couplings; the reduced Yukawa matrix has quark rank ≤3 and lepton rank ≤2; the effective mass ratios satisfy m_u/m_d ∈ [10, 100], m_c/m_s ∈ [15, 30], m_t/m_b ∈ [40, 60]; the predicted θ₁₃ lies within ±2σ of the empirical value (θ₁₃ ≈ 0.0046). The residual symmetry is a proper subgroup of D₆.
experiment.expected_negative: All tadpole-consistent wrappings either: (i) preserve all 26 couplings with no selection-rule suppression, implying D-branes do not break D₆ in the Yukawa sector; OR (ii) reduce the quark/lepton ranks to inverting predictions (rank_q ≥ 4 or rank_ℓ ≤ 1); OR (iii) yield m_u/m_d < 3 or m_t/m_b < 20, failing to approach realistic hierarchies. In any case, D-brane wrapping alone cannot explain the mass hierarchy without additional mechanisms.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: D-brane wrappings on the GL=12/D₆ polytope do not causally constrain the Yukawa coupling rank or selection rules. Equivalently: for all tadpole-consistent D-brane stacks, the set of non-zero Yukawa couplings remains the full 26 D₆-invariant set, independent of the choice of invariant vs. non-invariant divisor wrappings.
experiment.statistical_test: Combinatorial enumeration with exhaustive case analysis: (i) count the number of tadpole-consistent D-brane stacks that induce ≥6 forbidden couplings; (ii) for each such stack, record the resulting Yukawa rank and compute mass ratios; (iii) assess agreement with empirical data via χ² goodness-of-fit test (empirical mass ratios vs. predicted, assuming ±10% theoretical uncertainty). Rejection of H₀ requires ≥1 stack with >20% coupling reduction AND χ² p-value > 0.05 for at least one mass-ratio comparison (indicating agreement within uncertainty).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: A single D-brane configuration that forbids ≥6 couplings (>20% of 26) and reduces quark Yukawa rank from 5 to ≤3 (≥40% rank reduction). This is a deterministic, discrete-structure outcome with no statistical noise, so any wrapping that satisfies both conditions constitutes detection.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: This is a computational enumeration, not a statistical study. The sample space is finite (all tadpole-consistent wrappings); exhaustive enumeration guarantees 100% power if the effect exists. Convergence criterion: all D-brane stacks generated by brute-force search over wrapping matrices satisfying (i) total RR charge = 0, (ii) Bianchi identities, and (iii) anomaly cancellation have been classified. Computationally, this scales as O(N_divisors^N_branes) ≈ O(100^5) ≈ 10^10 configurations; pruning via symmetry (D₆ orbits) and physical consistency reduces this to ~10^3–10^4 distinct stacks.
limitations: Computation assumes the geometric D₆ action is the only symmetry; additional worldsheet discrete symmetries (e.g., from orientifold projections) are not modeled and could further constrain wrappings.
Index-theorem zero-mode counting assumes generic point in moduli space; certain special loci (e.g., points of enhanced gauge symmetry) are not analyzed.
The predicted Yukawa texture is tree-level; loop corrections and nonperturbative effects (gaugino condensation, instantons) are neglected.
Empirical fermion masses contain renormalization-group uncertainty (~5–10%); theoretical predictions are matched at the GUT scale with assumed threshold corrections.
The assumption that D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings define the leading-order Superpotential W_0 requires that higher-dimensional operators (∝ M_Pl^{-n}) are suppressed; this is not explicitly verified.
Mirror symmetry and the validity of the mirror CY's Picard-Fuchs system are assumed without independent verification on this polytope.
experiment.requires_followup: After confirming a selection-rule mechanism computationally, the next step would be a phenomenological fit of the effective Yukawa matrix to empirical fermion data, including renormalization-group evolution from the GUT scale (e.g., MSSM RGE) to the weak scale. This would require input from particle physics (Weinberg operator suppression, proton decay, neutrino masses via seesaw) but can be performed without new wet-lab experiments. A full string-model realization would also require: (i) explicit construction of the mirror CY and its moduli stabilization (e.g., via flux + nonperturbative terms), and (ii) numerical validation of the Calabi-Yau metric to verify the index-theorem assumptions. These are computational but require specialized CY-metric solvers (e.g., using Kähler-Einstein metrics or numerical Gröbner basis techniques).

hypotheses.source_question: Does the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture generated by CY3 discrete symmetries naturally enforce gauge coupling unification at the GUT scale, or must gauge unification be imposed independently of the geometric constraints?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture encoded in the GL(12)/D₆ Calabi-Yau geometry causally determines one-loop gauge coupling unification at the GUT scale (M_GUT ≃ 2×10¹⁶ GeV), such that the 26 surviving D₆-invariant couplings and their matter multiplicities (from divisor cohomology) induce beta-function relations that predict unified couplings without additional external constraints, and that breaking D₆ to proper subgroups systematically destroys this unification.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ automorphism group acts simultaneously on the moduli space (constraining 20 → 5 independent complex-structure deformations) and on the effective superpotential via its action on (2,1)-forms. This action determines both the Yukawa texture κ_{ijk} and the matter multiplicities N_rep entering the one-loop beta functions dα_i/dt = (b_i⁰ + Σ b_i^rep N_rep)α_i²/2π. Geometric constraints on D₆-invariant couplings reduce the parameter freedom in β-functions such that α₁(M_GUT) = α₂(M_GUT) = α₃(M_GUT) emerges as a natural consequence of the moduli geometry, rather than as an imposed boundary condition.
hypotheses.prediction: The geometric prediction of the unification scale M_GUT (computed from the height of the CY moduli space and the Picard-Fuchs system) will match the low-energy precision requirement M_GUT within ±15% (approximately 1.7–2.3×10¹⁶ GeV), and the running couplings α_i(M_GUT) computed using D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings will satisfy |α₁(M_GUT) − α₂(M_GUT)|/α₂ < 2% and |α₂(M_GUT) − α₃(M_GUT)|/α₂ < 2%; moreover, breaking D₆ to a proper subgroup will increase this splitting by at least 50% (to >3%).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the geometric M_GUT prediction (from CY monodromy/Picard-Fuchs analysis) differs from the low-energy precision requirement by >20%, or if the D₆-invariant couplings produce one-loop gauge coupling deviations |α_i(M_GUT) − α_j(M_GUT)|/α_avg > 5% at the predicted unification point, or if breaking D₆ to a proper subgroup (e.g., Z₃ ⊂ D₆) does not increase coupling splitting measurably (change <30%), the hypothesis is refuted. Specifically: if the minimum variance in the three running couplings at the geometric M_GUT is greater than the minimum variance achieved by imposing unification as an external constraint, the causal claim is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Geometric M_GUT prediction within ±15% of low-energy precision value (1.7–2.3×10¹⁶ GeV); coupling unification splitting at geometric point: |α_i − α_j|/α_avg < 2%; subgroup breaking increases splitting by ≥50% (to ≥3%); explained variance in beta-function relations by D₆ invariance structure: R² > 0.85.

experiment.approach: A purely computational study combining CyTools (for D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings and moduli geometry), Picard-Fuchs analysis (for geometric M_GUT), and beta-function integration (RGE running) to test whether the GL(12)/D₆ geometry predicts unified gauge couplings without external fine-tuning.
steps: Step 1: Use CyTools to compute the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings κ_{abc} via Kähler triple intersections on the GL(12) polytope and Y_{ijk} via (2,1)-form integrals, extracting the Yukawa matrix structure and its rank, condition number, and eigenvalue distribution.

Step 2: Extract divisor multiplicities and matter content (number of families, Higgs doublets, vector-like pairs) from cohomology H¹(CY3, 𝒪(D_i)) for each divisor class invariant under D₆, using CyTools divisor analysis or direct Picard lattice computation.

Step 3: Compute the geometric unification scale M_GUT from the Picard-Fuchs system: solve the PF differential operators L_i(∇)Π = 0 for the periods Π(ψ), extract the monodromy point (Hilbert modulus or fundamental domain boundary) corresponding to maximum symmetry (D₆ fixed point), and translate to log M_GUT via the modular form parameterization ψ(M).

Step 4: Construct the one-loop beta-function system for the three gauge couplings: dα_i⁻¹/dt = −b_i/(2π), where b_i = b_i⁰ + Σ_rep b_i^rep N_rep, with b_i⁰ (GUT group dependent) and b_i^rep (representation Dynkin indices) tabulated for SU(5) or SO(10). Use matter multiplicities from Step 2 and Yukawa coupling values from Step 1 to seed the RGE.

Step 5: Integrate the RGE system (using standard ODE solver, e.g., scipy.integrate or custom Mathematica routine) from M_Z = 91.2 GeV to the geometric M_GUT from Step 3, tracking α₁(E), α₂(E), α₃(E) and their mutual deviations |α_i − α_j|/α_avg as functions of energy E.

Step 6: Compute the unification quality metric: Δα_unif = max_i,j{|α_i(M_GUT) − α_j(M_GUT)|}/α_avg(M_GUT). If Δα_unif < 2%, record the result as 'geometric unification success.' Compare against benchmark: forcing unification externally (setting all α_i equal at M_GUT) and running backward to M_Z to see whether the low-energy result matches precision data (sin²θ_W, α_s(M_Z)).

Step 7: Break D₆ to proper subgroups (Z₃, Z₂, identity) by removing the corresponding symmetry constraints on couplings: recompute the allowed Yukawa texture with reduced symmetry, recompute matter multiplicities if divisor class structure changes, and repeat Steps 4–6. Measure the change in Δα_unif (should increase by ≥50% if hypothesis holds).

Step 8: Perform sensitivity analysis: compute how small perturbations in the 5 independent D₆-invariant moduli (δψ_a, a=1..5) affect M_GUT and Δα_unif; construct a Jacobian matrix relating moduli perturbations to unification quality, and extract the 'unification manifold' (the subspace in moduli space where Δα_unif < 2%).

Step 9: Cross-check against existing GUT phenomenology: compare the predicted low-energy coupling values (sin²θ_W, α_s(M_Z)) obtained by running the geometric RGE backward from M_GUT against precision SM measurements (PDG 2023 values); compute χ² goodness-of-fit.

Step 10: Generate a summary report with: (a) M_GUT prediction ± uncertainty; (b) Δα_unif before and after D₆ breaking; (c) R² of fit to SM precision data; (d) visualization of RGE running with and without geometric constraints.
tools: CyTools (for Yukawa couplings, Picard lattice, divisor cohomology on GL(12) polytope)
Picard-Fuchs solver (Magma, Mathematica, or custom Python via sympy)
SARAH/SoftSUSY (for GUT beta functions and RGE running) or custom RGE integrator (scipy.integrate.odeint)
HepData/PDG 2023 (for precision low-energy coupling measurements)
SymPy/Mathematica (for symbolic manipulation of D₆ group action, cohomology calculations)
Visualization: Matplotlib/Plotly (for RGE running curves, moduli space projections, unification quality heatmaps)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks compute and analysis. CyTools Yukawa computation: 2–3 weeks (depends on polytope size and available hardware; triangulation already known for GL(12)). Picard-Fuchs analysis: 1–2 weeks (symbolic algebra). RGE integration and sensitivity analysis: 2–3 weeks. Interpretation, cross-checks, and report writing: 2–3 weeks.
experiment.data_requirements: Public CyTools database (GL(12) polytope, triangulation data); Picard-Fuchs period database (available in arXiv:1503.00796 or reconstructible from CY mirror symmetry); standard GUT coupling data (available in SARAH/SoftSUSY package); precision measurements (PDG 2023 online); optional: CY moduli space datafiles from the Kreuzer-Skarke database.
experiment.expected_positive: Geometric M_GUT prediction matches low-energy precision requirement within ±15% (1.7–2.3×10¹⁶ GeV); D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings and matter multiplicities produce coupling unification Δα_unif < 2% at the geometric point without external fine-tuning; breaking D₆ to subgroups increases Δα_unif by ≥50%; running backward from geometric M_GUT produces sin²θ_W and α_s(M_Z) within 3σ of PDG values.
experiment.expected_negative: Geometric M_GUT differs from low-energy precision value by >20%; D₆ couplings fail to unify (Δα_unif > 5%) at the geometric point; breaking symmetry does not significantly worsen unification (increase <30%); running backward from geometric M_GUT produces couplings that deviate by >5σ from precision measurements; unification manifold is measure-zero or disconnected in moduli space, indicating fine-tuning.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆-invariant Yukawa texture and matter content derived from the GL(12)/D₆ Calabi-Yau geometry do not causally determine gauge coupling unification; instead, the three running couplings remain independent, and unification must be imposed as an external constraint or emerges only by accident with probability ≤ 5%.
experiment.statistical_test: One-sided goodness-of-fit test: compute the probability that a random assignment of matter multiplicities and Yukawa couplings (respecting the CY geometry but ignoring D₆ invariance) would produce Δα_unif < 2% at the geometric M_GUT. Estimate this via Monte Carlo sampling of the moduli space (n_samples ≥ 10⁴ random points in the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant moduli space) and measure the fraction f achieving Δα_unif < 2%. H₀ predicts f ≤ 0.05; reject H₀ if f > 0.50 (i.e., if ≥50% of random points achieve <2% unification). Alternatively, compare the variance of {Δα_unif} at D₆-symmetric points vs. random points using F-test (two-sided, α = 0.05).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Explained variance R² > 0.85 in the linear regression of Δα_unif against D₆-invariance structure (measured as the fraction of couplings forced to zero by D₆); geometric M_GUT prediction error < ±15% (approximately ±3×10¹⁵ GeV); coupling splitting reduction from breaking symmetry > 50% (|Δα_unif|_broken / |Δα_unif|_D₆ > 1.5).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: This is a computational experiment; 'power' translates to convergence of numerical solutions and sensitivity of RGE integration. Use ODE solver with absolute tolerance ≤ 10⁻¹⁰ and relative tolerance ≤ 10⁻¹² to ensure precision in coupling running. For Monte Carlo sampling in Step 8, use n_samples ≥ 10⁴ to achieve margin of error ≤ ±3% in estimating the fraction of moduli achieving unification. For beta-function uncertainty from unknown higher-loop corrections, report results assuming one-loop only but flag the ±5–10% systematic uncertainty typical of GUT matching conditions.
limitations: Assumes one-loop RGE; two-loop and threshold corrections at M_GUT can shift unification scale by ±5–10% and modify coupling ratios by ~1%, potentially weakening the match to precision data.

Matter content (family multiplicities, vector-like pairs) extracted from divisor cohomology may be incomplete if Higgs doublet/triplet splitting or additional exotic matter arises from non-geometric string theory effects (e.g., Kaluza-Klein tower).

CyTools computation of Yukawa couplings relies on numerical intersection theory; expected precision ~1–2% from floating-point arithmetic and triangulation dependence, which propagates into beta-function coefficients.

Picard-Fuchs solution at the monodromy point (D₆ fixed point) may be singular or poorly conditioned, complicating the extraction of M_GUT; alternative regulators (e.g., winding numbers, special coordinates) may be needed.

CY moduli space has finite Kähler radius; beyond this radius, effective field theory description breaks down and predictions lose validity; unification manifold may lie outside the regime of validity.

External GUT group (SU(5) vs. SO(10) vs. E₆) is not determined by the CY geometry alone; choice of GUT affects beta-function coefficients b_i⁰, potentially disrupting unification; requires additional model input.

Comparison to precision SM data assumes no additional physics between M_Z and M_GUT (e.g., no extra vector-like fermions beyond those from CY geometry); threshold corrections from massive string modes are neglected.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational results show promising unification (Δα_unif < 2% at geometric M_GUT), the next step is a full string theory compactification study: (1) verify matter multiplicities via explicit heterotic or Type II B/A dual string worldsheet analysis; (2) compute two-loop RGE to assess stability of unification; (3) perform moduli stabilization (e.g., via Kähler uplift or KKLT) to check whether moduli fixing preserves D₆ invariance and unification; (4) study phenomenological implications: compute proton decay rates, double-beta decay, and rare process rates to test against experiment. If unification fails (Δα_unif > 5%), the string vacuum must be reconsidered or additional symmetry breaking (e.g., Froggatt-Nielsen) imposed externally. No immediate wet-lab experiment is needed for the primary hypothesis test, but precision measurements of α_s(M_Z), sin²θ_W, and m_t (which feed into the RGE boundary conditions and M_GUT extraction) should be updated as new data arrives.

hypotheses.source_question: Given a quintic hypersurface with a discrete automorphism group G acting on its moduli, does the mirror quintic inherit a dual discrete symmetry, and can monodromy in the mirror's periods predict which G-invariant Yukawa couplings vanish on the original?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the monodromy action of the mirror quintic's period vector around singular loci causally determines which D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings vanish on the original quintic, and that periods annihilated by monodromy elements correspond exactly to coupling positions κ_{abc} or Y_{ijk} that are forbidden by the discrete symmetry.
hypotheses.mechanism: Discrete automorphisms of a quintic hypersurface induce constraints on its mirror's Picard–Fuchs operator and monodromy representation. When the mirror's period vector is analytically continued around singular loci (conifold, large-complex-structure), monodromy matrices M ∈ Aut(H³_{dR}) either permute or annihilate period components. A period that is invariant under monodromy can contribute to G-invariant couplings; one that is permuted or nullified by a monodromy element conjugate to a generator of G cannot. This creates a causal link: monodromy structure → symmetry-allowed period subspace → non-zero Yukawa couplings. The mechanism is bidirectional in principle (automorphisms determine monodromy; monodromy predicts automorphism action), but the causal direction for prediction flows from mirror geometry back to the original.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL(12; D₆) polytope with 20 complex moduli reduced to 5 D₆-invariant directions: at least 18 out of the 26 observed D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings will be correctly predicted (sign and vanishing) by monodromy analysis of the mirror quintic's periods around large-complex-structure and conifold limits. Specifically, if monodromy predicts a coupling Y_{ijk} should vanish (period annihilated or forbidden by D₆ irrep constraint), direct CyTools computation will confirm Y_{ijk} = 0 with agreement rate ≥ 70% (≥18/26 couplings).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If monodromy analysis correctly identifies ≤8 out of 26 coupling vanishing patterns (i.e., <35% agreement), or if the monodromy-predicted zero couplings do not overlap with CyTools-computed zeros at >60% recall, the hypothesis is refuted. In particular: if a period predicted to vanish by monodromy (period component annihilated by M or projected to zero by D₆-irrep filter) corresponds to a coupling Y_{ijk} that is computed to be non-zero and of order ≥10⁻² in CyTools, the causal mechanism is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Prediction accuracy ≥70% (≥18 out of 26 D₆-invariant couplings); equivalently, false-negative rate <15% (monodromy predicts zero but CyTools finds non-zero, with |Y_{ijk}| >10⁻² in normalized coordinates). This threshold distinguishes predictive power (>70%) from noise or random agreement (~50%).

experiment.approach: Computationally extract the Picard–Fuchs operator and monodromy matrices for the mirror of a D₆-symmetric quintic (or a simpler test case with smaller discrete symmetry); decompose monodromy irreps and identify period components that are annihilated or permuted by D₆-conjugate monodromy elements. Compare monodromy-predicted vanishing patterns for the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings against CyTools direct computation.
steps: Step 1: Select or construct a quintic hypersurface X with explicit D₆ automorphism action on its 20 complex moduli (use published examples, e.g., Klein quartic or Fermat quintic with automorphism data from MAGMA/Macaulay2).

Step 2: Compute the Picard–Fuchs operator for the mirror quintic M(X) using CyTools toric/Dolgachev–Nikulin coordinates; extract the PF equation system and its monodromy representation around singular points (conifold, LCS limit).

Step 3: Compute the period vector Π(t) = (π₀, π₁, π₂, π₃) as a function of the mirror modulus t near singular loci using local solutions to the PF equation (Frobenius method or Gauss–Manin connection).
Step 4: Extract monodromy matrices M_γ for loops γ around each singular point; decompose M_γ into irreducible representations of D₆ using character theory.

Step 5: Identify period components π_i that are: (i) fixed by all monodromy loops (globally invariant), (ii) permuted by specific D₆-conjugate monodromy elements, or (iii) annihilated by projections onto D₆ irreps.

Step 6: For each of the 26 known D₆-invariant couplings Y_{ijk}, determine which (2,1)-form integrals (constructed from periods via Griffiths transversality) contribute to Y_{ijk}. Predict vanishing if the corresponding period component is annihilated by monodromy.
Step 7: Run CyTools to directly compute all 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings using κ_{abc} (Kähler intersection) and Y_{ijk} ∝ ∫ Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k (holomorphic 3-form + (2,1)-forms).

Step 8: Compare predictions (Step 6) with direct computations (Step 7); compute precision (fraction of non-zero couplings predicted to be non-zero), recall (fraction of zero couplings predicted to be zero), and overall agreement rate.
tools: CyTools (cython polytope algebra, Picard–Fuchs solver, monodromy computation)
MAGMA or SageMath (character theory, D₆ irrep decomposition, group actions on polytope)
Macaulay2 (Gröbner basis for quintic equations, automorphism group computation)
Mirror symmetry databases (Dolgachev–Nikulin mirror construction, toric fan data)
NumPy/SciPy (numerical monodromy matrix computation, eigenvalue decomposition, period vector approximation near singularities)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–8 weeks: 1 week (quintic selection and mirror computation), 2 weeks (PF operator extraction and monodromy calculation), 1 week (character decomposition and period identification), 1 week (CyTools coupling computation), 1 week (comparison, validation, sensitivity analysis).
experiment.data_requirements: Published or CyTools-generated data for a quintic with known discrete automorphism group (D₆ or smaller); access to CyTools source code and Picard–Fuchs solvers; mirror coordinates (toric fan or Dolgachev–Nikulin data); character tables for D₆.
experiment.expected_positive: Monodromy analysis predicts vanishing for ≥18 out of 26 D₆-invariant couplings with >70% overall agreement. Predicted-zero couplings match CyTools-computed zeros with >85% precision; predicted-nonzero couplings are confirmed as non-zero by direct computation (|Y_{ijk}| > 10⁻² in normalized units). Monodromy irreps align with the D₆-module structure of the period space.
experiment.expected_negative: Monodromy predictions fail to match CyTools results in >15 out of 26 cases (agreement <62%). Many periods predicted to vanish are instead non-zero; or monodromy decomposition shows no structure consistent with D₆ irreps. This would indicate that monodromy alone does not determine the D₆ action on Yukawa couplings, and a secondary mechanism (e.g., Froggatt–Nielsen layer or hidden-sector constraints) is necessary.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The monodromy group of the mirror quintic's period vector is independent of the discrete automorphism group acting on the original quintic, and monodromy-based predictions of vanishing Yukawa couplings have no better than random accuracy (expected agreement ≈50% under a null model of symmetric vanishing).
experiment.statistical_test: Comparison of proportions using binomial test: count number of correct predictions out of 26 couplings; test H₀: p_correct = 0.5 vs. H₁: p_correct > 0.7 at significance level α=0.05. Exact binomial test (n=26, k=18, p_null=0.5) yields p_value ≈ 0.0006 if k≥18, well below α=0.05. Precision, recall, and F1-score for zero/nonzero predictions; report 95% confidence intervals via Wilson score interval.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: A prediction accuracy of ≥70% (≥18/26 couplings correctly identified as zero or nonzero) is the minimum threshold to claim the hypothesis is supported. This is substantially above random (50%) and requires a genuine correlation between monodromy structure and Yukawa vanishing patterns. Effect size: Cohen's h ≈ 0.41 (p₁=0.70, p₀=0.50), requiring n≥26 individual coupling tests; power ≈0.90 at α=0.05 one-sided.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: This is a computational study on a fixed set of 26 couplings (not a sample from a population). Statistical power is achieved by using exact binomial test: if true agreement is 70%, the probability of observing ≥18 successes in 26 trials is ~99%. If true agreement is 60%, probability drops to ~73%. The study is powered to detect a shift from 50% (null) to ≥70% (hypothesis) with high sensitivity. No sample-size adjustment needed; the 26-coupling dataset is exhaustive for the GL(12; D₆) polytope.
limitations: The test case (GL(12; D₆) polytope) is a single family of quintics; generalization to other polytopes with different symmetries (e.g., Z₃ × Z₃, E₆) requires separate validation.
Monodromy computation relies on accurate Picard–Fuchs operator extraction; numerical errors in PF solver or period vector approximation near singularities could propagate to monodromy matrices.

The interpretation of 'period annihilation' as coupling vanishing assumes a direct map from (2,1)-form integrals to Y_{ijk}; intermediate algebraic relations (e.g., syzygies among holomorphic 3-form cohomology) could complicate the link.

D₆ irrep decomposition is unambiguous, but the assignment of each Yukawa coupling to a specific D₆ irrep component requires explicit construction of (2,1)-forms χ_i, which may be sensitive to basis choices.

Mirror symmetry predictions are exact in the large-complex-structure limit; finite-distance effects in moduli space could weaken the correlation between monodromy and actual Yukawa texture at generic points.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational predictions succeed (>70% agreement), the next step is to construct explicit (2,1)-forms χ_i on the original quintic using Hodge-theoretic methods and verify that integrating χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k ∧ Ω against the monodromy-forbidden period indeed yields Y_{ijk}=0 numerically (wet-lab analog: symbolic algebra over the defining polynomial equations of the quintic). If predictions fail, follow-up should investigate whether additional discrete symmetries (acting on the Picard lattice or transcendental lattice) are required, or whether the Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism operates independently of monodromy.

hypotheses.source_question: Can non-Abelian discrete gauge symmetries emerging from CY3 automorphisms generate realistic flavor hierarchies without additional Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms, and does the decomposition into Abelian subgroups preserve the textures of the parent non-Abelian symmetry?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that non-Abelian discrete gauge symmetries arising from CY₃ automorphisms generate realistic quark-lepton mass hierarchies through geometric constraints on Yukawa couplings that are not reproducible by any single Abelian subgroup, and that the breaking of the non-Abelian group into its maximal Abelian subgroups strictly increases the number of allowed non-zero Yukawa couplings, thereby destroying mass texture uniqueness.
hypotheses.mechanism: The non-Abelian automorphism group (e.g., D₆) acts on both the moduli space and the holomorphic (3,0)-form Ω simultaneously. This dual action forbids certain Yukawa couplings Y_ijk through representation-theoretic selection rules on the (2,1)-form basis. When decomposed into maximal Abelian subgroups, only a subset of these selection rules persist; couplings that vanish under the full non-Abelian symmetry become allowed under subgroups because the reduction loses off-diagonal interferences between irreducible representations. This causes an expansion of the allowed Yukawa texture, increasing rank and breaking the hierarchy pattern.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12/D₆ polytope: exactly 3 to 7 of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings that are zero under full D₆ symmetry will become non-zero under at least one maximal Abelian subgroup (Z₂×Z₂, Z₃, Z₆, or Z₂). The resulting Yukawa matrix under subgroup symmetry will have rank increased by at least 1 compared to D₆-symmetric texture, and the lepton mixing angle θ₁₃ predicted by subgroup textures will deviate from D₆-constrained value by greater than 0.05, falling outside the 3-sigma experimental range of 0.145 to 0.155.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If 2 or fewer Yukawa couplings that are zero under D₆ become non-zero under subgroups, OR if the rank of the Yukawa matrix remains invariant under all maximal Abelian decompositions, OR if θ₁₃ predictions under subgroup symmetries remain within 0.03 of the D₆-constrained value for 3 or more independent CY₃ examples, the hypothesis is refuted. Non-Abelian symmetry must act as a strict restrictor of the coupling space.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: M greater than or equal to 3 Yukawa couplings must transition from zero to non-zero upon Abelian reduction; rank change Δrank_Yukawa greater than or equal to 1 between D₆-symmetric and subgroup textures; absolute value of Δθ₁₃ greater than or equal to 0.05 in lepton mixing prediction. For CyTools: minimum detectable coupling magnitude greater than or equal to 10^-3 in normalized units.

experiment.approach: Computationally extract Picard-Fuchs systems and automorphism actions for the GL=12/D₆ polytope and 5 to 9 comparison CY₃ models with known discrete symmetries. For each geometry, compute Yukawa couplings Y_ijk invariant under the full non-Abelian group, each maximal Abelian subgroup, and the trivial group. Compare coupling patterns and predicted lepton mixing angles across all symmetry levels to identify non-Abelian-unique constraints.
steps: Extract the Picard-Fuchs system for GL=12/D₆ polytope using CyTools and compute monodromy matrices around singularities. Verify that D₆ lifts faithfully to the automorphism group acting on H^(2,1)(CY₃).
Enumerate all maximal Abelian subgroups of D₆: Z₂×Z₂ (Klein four), Z₃, Z₆ (cyclic), and Z₂ (two conjugacy classes). For each subgroup H, extract the H-invariant subalgebra of the (2,1)-form space.
Compute Kähler triple intersections κ_abc using CyTools intersection number algorithm for all D₆-invariant divisor classes.

Compute Yukawa couplings Y^D₆_ijk restricted to D₆-invariant forms. Numerically integrate over the Calabi-Yau 3-fold and identify the set of vanishing couplings within integration error of plus or minus 10^-4.
Repeat Yukawa computation for each maximal Abelian subgroup H. Record the expansion set N^H of couplings allowed by H but forbidden by D₆.
Compute Yukawa matrix rank for each symmetry level. Verify that rank(Y^H) minus rank(Y^D₆) is greater than or equal to 1 for at least one H.
Use Yukawa matrices to predict lepton mixing angles via Frobenius diagonalization. Compare deviations absolute value of Δθ₁₃ against experimental 3-sigma range.
Repeat steps 1 through 7 for 5 to 9 comparison CY₃ models with diverse automorphism groups: A₄, S₃, Z₃×Z₃, Z₂×Z₂×Z₂.
Aggregate results across all models. Test hypothesis using binomial test: H₀: E[|N^H|]=0 versus H₁: E[|N^H|]>0.
Cross-check geometric validity: verify that each coupling in N^H corresponds to genuine moduli directions by checking divisor class products in Kähler cone interior.
tools: CyTools Python package for Calabi-Yau moduli and Picard-Fuchs computation
SageMath and GAP for discrete group representation theory and subgroup enumeration
Mathematica or Wolfram Language for numerical integration of form wedge products
Kreuzer-Skarke polytope database and CICY threefold database for comparison models
Custom Python or Julia scripts for Yukawa texture rank computation and lepton mixing angle extraction
experiment.estimated_effort: 3 to 4 months: approximately 2 weeks per CY₃ example (Picard-Fuchs extraction and monodromy approximately 5 days; Yukawa computation across subgroups approximately 7 days; rank and mixing angle analysis approximately 3 days). Total compute: approximately 100 to 200 GPU-hours for numerical integration; approximately 10 CPU-hours for group-theoretic decomposition.
experiment.data_requirements: Picard-Fuchs systems and monodromy matrices for GL=12/D₆ and 5 to 9 comparison CY₃s; explicit coordinates for reflexive polytopes; (2,1)-form basis for H^(2,1)(CY₃); experimental quark-lepton mass ratios and lepton mixing angles from PDG 2023.
experiment.expected_positive: For GL=12/D₆: absolute value of N^H greater than or equal to 3 couplings become non-zero under at least one Abelian subgroup; rank(Y^H) greater than or equal to rank(Y^D₆) plus 1 for Z₂×Z₂ or Z₃; absolute value of Δθ₁₃ greater than 0.05 for at least 2 subgroups. Across 10 models: greater than 70 percent exhibit absolute value of N^H greater than or equal to 2 and Δrank greater than or equal to 1, confirming that non-Abelian structure enforces flavor texture uniqueness.
experiment.expected_negative: For GL=12/D₆: absolute value of N^H less than or equal to 2 for all H, or rank(Y^H) equals rank(Y^D₆) across all subgroups, or absolute value of Δθ₁₃ less than 0.03 for all H. Across models: less than 50 percent show absolute value of N^H greater than or equal to 2. This would refute the mechanistic claim that non-Abelian symmetry provides constraints beyond Abelian subgroups.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The set of non-zero Yukawa couplings under D₆ symmetry is a subset of or equal to the union of non-zero couplings under all maximal Abelian subgroups. Every coupling forbidden by D₆ is also forbidden by at least one maximal Abelian subgroup. Non-Abelian discrete symmetry provides no additional geometric constraint beyond its Abelian factors.
experiment.statistical_test: Binomial test across N=10 models with success defined as absolute value of N^H greater than or equal to 2. Count successes S and test H₀: p=0.5 versus H₁: p>0.5 at alpha=0.05, two-tailed. Additionally, paired t-test on absolute value of Δθ₁₃: H₀: mu(absolute value of Δθ₁₃)=0.02 versus H₁: mu(absolute value of Δθ₁₃)>0.05, one-tailed, alpha=0.05, power=0.80.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Δrank greater than or equal to 1 in Yukawa matrix. For lepton mixing: absolute value of Δθ₁₃ greater than or equal to 0.05 in radians. For coupling expansion: absolute value of N^H greater than or equal to 2 per subgroup. For robust statistical claim: at least 7 of 10 models must exhibit this signature (binomial S greater than or equal to 7, p<0.05).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size N=10 independent CY₃ examples spanning diverse automorphism groups. Assumed effect size for binomial: p_alternative=0.75 (75 percent of models exhibit non-Abelian-unique constraints), p_null=0.5. Binomial power at N=10, alpha=0.05 one-tailed: approximately 0.63. For 80 percent power, would need N=15 to 18. Mitigation: require multiple consistency checks (Δrank, Δθ₁₃, coupling expansion) all simultaneously true, reducing effective alpha to approximately 0.01. For paired t-test: assume sigma(Δθ₁₃)=0.03, effect size mu=0.05, alpha=0.05, power=0.80 requires n_pairs greater than or equal to 15. With 10 models and 4 to 5 subgroups per model, approximately 40 to 50 pairs yield power greater than 0.90.
limitations: Picard-Fuchs systems unavailable in closed form for all CY₃s; numerical monodromy computation may accumulate floating-point errors. Mitigation: cross-check monodromy matrices against known automorphism group presentations using GAP.

Integration of (2,1)-form wedge products is numerically expensive; precision of Y_ijk limited by quadrature error approximately 10^-4. Mitigation: use high-precision integration libraries (e.g., mpmath, quadrature schemes with adaptive refinement) and validate against algebraic bounds from Picard-Fuchs residues.

Not all CY₃ models have explicit automorphism group data available; selection of 10 models may be biased toward geometries with known symmetries. Mitigation: prioritize models from Kreuzer-Skarke and CICY databases with published automorphism group studies.

Lepton mixing angle extraction from Yukawa matrices assumes a specific flavor basis and Frobenius ansatz; results may be sensitive to basis choice. Mitigation: test multiple basis choices and report range of θ₁₃ predictions.
Comparison to experimental θ₁₃ range assumes standard three-generation fermion spectrum; extended models with vector-like families would require separate analysis.
Computational bottleneck: high-precision numerical integration of (2,1)-forms over CY₃ becomes intractable for very large Hodge numbers. Restriction to h^(2,1) less than or equal to 100 recommended.
experiment.requires_followup: No wet-lab experiment required; this is a purely computational test. However, follow-up work should include: (1) Explicit construction of matter curve matter multiplets on the CY₃ for promising examples, coupling them to the computed Yukawa textures to verify fermion mass predictions; (2) String theory model building: embed the CY₃ geometry into a full heterotic or Type II compactification and check whether the Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism naturally emerges from the geometry (e.g., instanton effects or fluxes); (3) Precision test: compare predicted CKM and PMNS matrices for each CY₃ example against latest PDG constraints using statistical Markov chain Monte Carlo parameter scans.

hypotheses.source_question: Can discrete flavor symmetries arising from CY3 automorphism groups predict the neutrino mass eigenstate ordering (normal vs. inverted hierarchy) and the specific mass splittings Δm²₂₁ and Δm²₃₁ through constraints on the Yukawa texture that generates neutrino mass eigenstates?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings from the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau threefold automorphism group, when used to construct the type-I seesaw neutrino mass matrix in the flavor basis, predict the normal neutrino mass hierarchy and θ₁₃ > 8° through geometric constraints on the mass matrix eigenstructure, without requiring secondary Froggatt-Nielsen breaking.
hypotheses.mechanism: The 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings κ_abc and superpotential terms Y^(ν)_ijk restrict the flavor-basis neutrino mass matrix M_ν = Y^(ν)_L Y^(ν)_R (Y^(ν)_R)⁻¹ (Y^(ν)_L)ᵀ to a discrete set of allowed textures. D₆ symmetry acts on the three-dimensional lepton flavor space by permuting and phase-modulating the (e, μ, τ) basis, thereby constraining off-diagonal mass matrix elements relative to diagonal ones. This constraint propagates to eigenvalues (mass splittings Δm²₂₁, Δm²₃₁) and eigenvectors (mixing angles via PMNS matrix), deterministically selecting normal hierarchy and specific θ₁₃ values as the unique or dominant solution when diagonalized over the allowed moduli space.
hypotheses.prediction: When the neutrino mass matrix is constructed using all 26 D₆-invariant couplings and diagonalized across 10⁴ random points in the moduli space, >70% of valid solutions will exhibit normal hierarchy (m₁ < m₂ < m₃) with θ₁₃ ∈ [8°, 12°], overlapping the experimentally measured θ₁₃ ≈ 8.5° ± 0.2° to within 1σ, and the predicted mass splitting ratio Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ will differ from the measured ratio by <20%.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If <30% of solutions over the moduli space exhibit normal hierarchy, or if the distribution of predicted θ₁₃ is centered below 5° or above 15° (outside the experimentally compatible range), or if the mass splitting ratio Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ deviates by >50% from the experimentally measured value (Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ ≈ 28), then the hypothesis is refuted and secondary symmetry-breaking (Froggatt-Nielsen or other) is required.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Explained variance of predicted θ₁₃ > 60% (coefficient of determination R² > 0.60 when comparing predicted to measured values); >70% of solutions in normal hierarchy; mass matrix texture rank constraint reducing degrees of freedom by ≥50% relative to unconstrained case (from 9 complex entries to ≤5 independent parameters).

experiment.approach: Construct the type-I seesaw neutrino mass matrix using D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings extracted from CyTools for GL=12/D₆, then systematically diagonalize across moduli space to predict neutrino mass eigenvalues and mixing angles, comparing predictions to NOvA/T2K experimental data to test whether geometry alone encodes the observed hierarchy and θ₁₃.
steps: Use CyTools to compute the 26 D₆-invariant triple intersection numbers κ_abc and extract the 20 complex structure moduli; apply D₆ projection to identify D₆-invariant linear combinations of (2,1)-forms χ_i.
For each modulus point in a 10⁴-point random sampling of the Kähler cone, compute the D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling matrix Y^(ν)_ijk ∝ ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k using the 26 constrained couplings.

Parametrize the right-handed neutrino mass matrix M_R in terms of the 26 invariant couplings and scan over a 2-dimensional subspace of right-handed neutrino masses (M_R diagonal, eigenvalues M_1, M_2, M_3 ∈ [10¹⁰, 10¹⁵] GeV, motivated by seesaw scale).
Construct the effective light neutrino mass matrix M_ν^(eff) = -Y^(ν)_L M_R⁻¹ (Y^(ν)_L)ᵀ in the flavor basis, where Y^(ν)_L is restricted to D₆-invariant texture patterns.
Diagonalize M_ν^(eff) for each modulus and M_R point; extract eigenvalues {m_1, m_2, m_3} and compute mass splittings Δm²₂₁ = m₂² - m₁², Δm²₃₁ = m₃² - m₁².
Extract the PMNS mixing matrix U by diagonalizing the mass matrix; compute the three mixing angles θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃ and the CP-violating phase δ_CP.

Scan predictions over {(m_1, M_R)} ∈ [10⁻³, 0.1] eV × [10¹⁰, 10¹⁵] GeV to identify the subset of solutions that produce normal hierarchy and θ₁₃ compatible with experimental measurement (θ₁₃ = 8.5° ± 0.2°).
Compute the fraction of solutions exhibiting normal hierarchy, the distribution of θ₁₃, and the predicted Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ ratio; compare to NOvA, T2K, and KamLAND combined constraints.
Test whether predictions improve when D₆ is broken to D₃ or D₂ (secondary Froggatt-Nielsen scenario); quantify how much residual freedom is restored.
Perform sensitivity analysis: vary the assumed M_R scale and the VEV structure of the superpotential to assess robustness of the predicted hierarchy and mixing.
tools: CyTools (Calabi-Yau triple intersection computation and moduli analysis)
SageMath or Python NumPy/SciPy (matrix diagonalization, eigenvalue extraction, moduli space sampling)
Global Fits package (e.g., nufit v5.5 or NuFIT) for NOvA/T2K/KamLAND combined experimental constraints on Δm²_ij and θ_ij
SymPy (symbolic computation of Yukawa coupling dependence on moduli)
Custom Python code to enforce D₆ invariance conditions and construct restricted Yukawa textures
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks (1 week CyTools computation of moduli and invariant couplings; 1 week matrix construction and diagonalization code; 1 week moduli scanning and statistical analysis; 1 week sensitivity analysis and comparison to experimental data).
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database output for GL=12/D₆ (or equivalent D₆-symmetric CY3 with h¹¹=17, h²¹=20); NOvA and T2K combined fit results (public; available from NuFIT website); theoretical priors on right-handed neutrino mass scale and Yukawa coupling magnitudes from string compactification literature.
experiment.expected_positive: When scanning 10⁴ moduli points: ≥70% of valid (M_ν diagonalizable, positive-definite) solutions exhibit normal hierarchy; the distribution of θ₁₃ is peaked at 8–12° (overlapping experiment at 1σ); the ratio Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ ≈ 28 ± 6 (matches PDG value of 28.3); no fine-tuning of moduli or M_R scale beyond what string compactifications naturally allow (e.g., M_R ~ M_string).
experiment.expected_negative: If <30% of solutions exhibit normal hierarchy, or θ₁₃ distribution is peaked <5° or >15°, or Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ differs by >50% from experiment, then geometry alone is insufficient and secondary Froggatt-Nielsen breaking is necessary. Alternatively, if predictions only match experiment after fine-tuning moduli to a measure-zero subset of the Kähler cone, the hypothesis is weakened (though not falsified) because it loses predictivity.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling constraints do not determine neutrino mass eigenstate properties (hierarchy, mass splittings, mixing angles) beyond what random textures predict. Equivalently: predictions of θ₁₃, Δm²₂₁, Δm²₃₁, and the normal/inverted hierarchy are statistically indistinguishable from an unconstrained ensemble of 3×3 neutrino mass matrices with the same moduli-space measure.
experiment.statistical_test: One-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test comparing the predicted distribution of θ₁₃ to the measured NOvA/T2K posterior (α = 0.05). Hypothesis confirmed if KS p-value > 0.05 (predicted and measured distributions are consistent) AND the fraction of solutions in normal hierarchy is significantly >50% (binomial test, one-tailed, α = 0.05, assuming null = 50%). Additionally, check whether the predicted 95% credible interval for Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ overlaps the experimental 95% CI; overlap required for confirmation.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Predicted mean θ₁₃ must differ from 0° and 90° by >5° (i.e., nontrivial constraint from geometry); fraction of normal-hierarchy solutions must exceed 50% by >15 percentage points (i.e., ≥65%, one-sample binomial test with power ≥80% at α=0.05, requiring n ≥ 100 valid solutions); predicted Δm²₃₁/Δm²₂₁ must lie within ±30% of the experimental central value (28.3), i.e., ∈ [19.8, 36.8].
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size: 10⁴ moduli space points; assume ~80% of these yield diagonalizable, positive-definite mass matrices (conservatively, 8,000 valid solutions). For binomial test of hierarchy fraction: if true fraction is 70% (our prediction) and null is 50%, power to reject H₀ at α=0.05 (one-tailed) with n=8,000 is >>99%. For KS test of θ₁₃ distribution: power to detect moderate deviation (difference in CDFs ~0.1) at α=0.05 with n=8,000 is >>99%. Convergence criterion for moduli sampling: increase sample size until the predicted distribution of θ₁₃ stabilizes (coefficient of variation <5%) across successive 1,000-point batches.
limitations: Type-I seesaw is assumed; type-II or type-III contributions from CY compactification are neglected. Alternative seesaw mechanisms may change eigenstate predictions.

Right-handed neutrino masses M_R are scanned phenomenologically; their value is not predicted from string geometry (string scale and moduli dependence are not explicitly modeled). Predictions depend sensitively on M_R ∈ [10¹⁰, 10¹⁵] GeV assumption.
CP-violating phase δ_CP is not constrained by current experiment; predictions for δ_CP cannot be directly tested and represent unfalsifiable output.
Assumes D₆ is the exact flavor symmetry; if CY geometry preserves a larger group (e.g., S₃, A₄) that breaks to D₆, this analysis would miss additional constraints.
Neutrino mass basis does not include sterile neutrinos; extended models are beyond scope.
No flavor-conserving or flavor-changing decays/processes are modeled; test is purely on mass eigenstate structure, not on rare decays or lepton-number violation.
Computational cost increases with precision of moduli sampling; convergence to >1% accuracy in Δm² may require >10⁵ points.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational analysis confirms that D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings predict normal hierarchy and θ₁₃ ∈ [8°, 12°] without secondary breaking, the next step is a formal algebraic verification: prove analytically that the D₆ representation structure on the (e, μ, τ) flavor space topologically forbids inverted hierarchy or θ₁₃ < 5°. This would require representation theory of D₆ acting on the flavor basis and explicit calculation of the mass matrix rank and eigenvalue gap structure—a pure math/symbolic computation task, not requiring wet lab. If the computational scan shows tension with experiment (e.g., θ₁₃ systematically too small), the follow-up is to compute how a U(1) × D₆ Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism (with a single spurion field transforming under U(1)) modifies the allowed Yukawa textures and whether this restores agreement. Again, purely computational. Only if the computational results are inconclusive (e.g., broad distribution of θ₁₃ that barely overlaps experiment) would it be necessary to: (i) perform explicit string compactification calculations to pin down the M_R scale from first principles, or (ii) search for alternative CY3 geometries with different automorphism groups (e.g., Z₅, A₅) to see if a larger symmetry group provides tighter predictions. These are longer-term wet-lab-equivalent efforts in string theory and algebraic geometry.

hypotheses.source_question: Does M-theory compactification on CY3 with discrete automorphism groups generate different families of effective superpotentials and Yukawa textures than type IIA string compactification on the same geometry, and if so, can monodromy constraints from the M-theory lift resolve the Froggatt-Nielsen problem for realistic fermion mass hierarchies?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that M-theory compactification on the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau threefold generates a strictly smaller set of viable D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings than type IIA string theory on the same geometry, because monodromy constraints from the M-theory Picard-Fuchs system and four-form flux quantization impose additional cohomological restrictions that forbid at least 3 of the 26 type-IIA-allowed couplings, thereby enabling realistic quark-lepton mass hierarchies without invoking a secondary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism.
hypotheses.mechanism: M-theory compactification on CY3 encodes the Picard-Fuchs differential equations and monodromy group action via the Gauss-Manin connection in 11D, coupling (2,1)-form periods to four-form flux quantization (quantized over integral 4-cycles of dual K3 fibration). This additional quantization constraint filters the cohomological basis of (2,1)-forms accessible to physical Yukawa integrands, thereby reducing the D₆-invariant subspace. Type IIA, lacking the four-form flux quantization in the same way, permits a larger affine space of valid couplings. The M-theory monodromy group action on periods is therefore strictly stronger (acts with higher rank on the Picard-Fuchs solution space), yielding a smaller intersection with the D₆-invariant subspace.
hypotheses.prediction: At least 3 of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings present in the type IIA Yukawa basis will be forbidden (forbidden_in_M-theory == True, meaning the corresponding (2,1)-form integral evaluates to zero or violates monodromy quantization) in the M-theory framework. The ratio of independent Yukawa couplings in M-theory to type IIA will be ≤ 0.88 (i.e., M-theory permits ≤23 couplings). Furthermore, the texture rank (number of independent physical Yukawa matrix eigenvalue scales) in M-theory will be ≥1 unit lower than in type IIA.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the set of D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings computed in M-theory contains all 26 type-IIA couplings, or if the M-theory texture rank is equal to or higher than type IIA rank, or if fewer than 3 couplings are forbidden in M-theory, the hypothesis is refuted. Equivalently: if |Y_M-theory| ≥ |Y_IIA| and rank(M-theory texture) ≥ rank(IIA texture), reject the hypothesis.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: At least 3 forbidden couplings (>11% reduction), AND texture rank reduction of ≥1 scale, OR texture determinant ratio det(Y_M-theory) / det(Y_IIA) < 0.5 (indicating qualitatively different mass-hierarchy structure).

experiment.approach: Computationally compare D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling spaces in M-theory versus type IIA by (1) extracting the Picard-Fuchs system and monodromy basis for GL=12/D₆ via CyTools, (2) computing all D₆-invariant (2,1)-form periods and their monodromy action, (3) calculating Yukawa integrals Y_ijk in type IIA using Kähler metric data, (4) applying M-theory four-form flux quantization rules to filter the (2,1) cohomology basis, and (5) comparing forbidden and allowed couplings in each framework.
steps: Load or construct the polytope data for GL=12/D₆ CY3 (Kreuzer-Skarke or CYTools database); verify h¹¹=17, h²¹=20, KS index 37.
Compute the Picard-Fuchs differential operator system (4th order for K3-fibered CY3) using CyTools symbolic computation; extract the monodromy group action on the 4-dimensional period solution space.

Identify the D₆ (dihedral order-12) action on the 20 moduli; compute the D₆-invariant subspace via character decomposition; list all irreducible representations and their cohomological representatives.

For type IIA: compute the Kähler metric K_ab via Weil-Petersson metric on moduli space; compute all 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings κ_{abc} and Y_{ijk} using numerical integration over CY3 (via Gromov-Witten or explicit divisor intersections).

For M-theory: identify the dual K3-fibration and its integral 4-cycles; apply four-form flux quantization rule: ∫_{C⁴} G₄ ∈ 2πℤ, where G₄ couples to (2,1)-forms via ∫_{CY3} G₄ ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j; filter (2,1) basis by removing forms whose integrals violate quantization or monodromy orbit constraints.
Compute M-theory Yukawa couplings Y_{ijk}^{M-th} using only the quantization-allowed (2,1) basis; record which type-IIA couplings become zero or forbidden.

Compare sets: list couplings {Y_i^{IIA} | i=1…26} and {Y_j^{M-th} | j=1…N_M}; compute N_M (number of independent M-theory couplings); compute texture rank via singular-value decomposition of both Yukawa matrices.

Statistical test: For each of the 26 couplings, record (forbidden_IIA, forbidden_M-th) status; apply Fisher exact test for independence between framework and forbiddenness (one-tailed, H₀: independence, α=0.05).

Construct mock fermion mass matrices using Frobenius-norm normalization of allowed Yukawa textures; compute CKM unitarity-triangle angles and lepton mixing angle θ₁₃ for both frameworks; assess whether M-theory-restricted texture achieves observed values without additional Froggatt-Nielsen factors.
tools: CyTools (Python package for polytope geometry and Picard-Fuchs systems)
SageMath or Macaulay2 for symbolic monodromy computation
CGAL or Barvinok for polytope volume and intersection number computation
numpy/scipy for numerical period integration and texture analysis
SymPy for algebraic manipulation of (2,1)-form bases and character tables
Custom Python module for D₆ representation theory and invariant subspace projection
Mathematica or SnapPy for K3 fibration topology and four-form quantization rules
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks compute-time and development (4–6 weeks exploratory Picard-Fuchs extraction + 2–3 weeks monodromy basis calculation + 2–3 weeks Yukawa integral computation + 1–2 weeks texture analysis and comparison).
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools polytope database or explicit weight matrix for GL=12/D₆; Kreuzer-Skarke CY3 list; D₆ character tables (standard group theory); published K3 fibration data for dual geometry; Weil-Petersson metric coefficients or computational access to mirror-symmetry calculations.
experiment.expected_positive: M-theory-computed Yukawa coupling set contains ≤23 independent couplings (at least 3 of 26 forbidden); texture rank drops by ≥1; texture determinant ratio < 0.5; Fisher exact test p < 0.05 for dependence between framework and forbiddenness; M-theory-only mass matrix achieves realistic CKM/lepton angles without extra Froggatt-Nielsen suppression factors.
experiment.expected_negative: All 26 D₆-invariant couplings are allowed in both frameworks (N_M ≥ 26); texture rank remains identical; Fisher test p > 0.05 (no significant dependence); M-theory offers no new flavor-hierarchy constraints and requires the same Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism as type IIA.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The set of D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings in M-theory is not strictly smaller than in type IIA on the same CY3 geometry; monodromy and four-form flux quantization impose no additional cohomological constraints beyond those already encoded in the type-IIA Picard-Fuchs system.
experiment.statistical_test: Fisher exact test (one-tailed, α=0.05) for independence between framework (type IIA vs. M-theory) and coupling forbiddenness (allowed vs. forbidden). If ≥3 couplings are forbidden exclusively in M-theory, two-sided binomial test: observed k=3 (or more) forbidden out of 26 trials with null probability p₀ ≤ 0.5. Reject H₀ if p < 0.05 and texture rank drops by ≥1.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: At least 3 couplings forbidden (≥11.5% reduction from 26); texture rank reduction of 1 or more independent scales (e.g., 5 scales → 4 scales); texture determinant ratio det(Y_M-th) / det(Y_IIA) < 0.5 OR condition number of M-theory Yukawa matrix < condition number of type-IIA matrix (indicating stronger hierarchical structure).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: This is a computational experiment with deterministic output (no stochastic sampling). No power analysis needed in the classical sense; instead, convergence criterion is the numerical precision of period integral computation: periods must be converged to relative error < 10⁻⁸ to reliably distinguish zero couplings from small nonzero couplings. Achieve this by increasing lattice resolution (polytope vertex count) and integration order (Gauss-Legendre quadrature) until the set of forbidden couplings stabilizes across successive refinements. Recommend two independent implementations (CyTools + custom Mathematica code) to cross-validate results.
limitations: Assumes the K3-fibration structure of the dual CY3 is well-understood and topologically distinct; if the fibration is degenerate or unclear, quantization rules may be ambiguous.

Four-form flux quantization rules in M-theory are derived from supergravity; non-perturbative string/M-theory effects (instantons, membranes) are neglected, potentially altering the effective coupling space.
D₆ action is assumed to descend cleanly from the type-IIA string compactification; if the M-theory uplift breaks or modifies this symmetry, comparison is not valid.
Numerical period integration is sensitive to singularities near moduli boundaries; singularities must be resolved via blow-up or regularization to avoid spurious zeros.
Frobenius-norm normalization of Yukawa matrices is conventional but somewhat arbitrary; results may be sensitive to choice of normalization for texture analysis.

Mock fermion mass matrix construction uses a simplified single-coupling-per-entry model; realistic flavor-symmetry breaking patterns (e.g., Froggatt-Nielsen with spurion vevs) require a more detailed UV model that is not fully specified here.
experiment.requires_followup: If computation confirms the hypothesis (≥3 forbidden couplings in M-theory), a direct phenomenological test would be: (1) Construct a minimal supersymmetric standard model (MSSM) with Yukawa sector derived from the M-theory-allowed couplings; (2) Fit CKM and PMNS matrices to observed quark/lepton masses and mixing without additional Froggatt-Nielsen factors; (3) If good fit is achieved, this constitutes strong circumstantial evidence that M-theory monodromy resolves the hierarchy problem. A full validation would require embedding the M-theory-derived Yukawa structure into a complete 4D effective field theory with explicit gauge/supergravity mediation and checking consistency with electroweak symmetry breaking and precision electroweak observables. This latter step requires numerical SUSY spectrum calculation (e.g., using SoftSUSY or ISASUSY) and would constitute a 6–12 month follow-up project. Alternatively, a wet-lab-analogous test would be precision measurement of lepton mixing angles (θ₁₃ in particular) in neutrino oscillation experiments; if M-theory predictions differ significantly from type-IIA and match experiment better, this would provide indirect confirmation, but such experiments are ongoing and not under direct control.

hypotheses.source_question: Can the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture of the GL12/D₆ Calabi-Yau polytope be leveraged to predict or constrain the neutrino mass-squared differences Δm²₃₂ and Δm²₂₁ through a unified flavor-symmetric superpotential, and does the automorphism-induced coupling suppression naturally explain the observed mass hierarchy without invoking an ad hoc Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling texture of the GL12/D₆ Calabi-Yau polytope, when combined with the see-saw mechanism and RG running to the electroweak scale, causally determines the neutrino mass-squared differences Δm²₃₂ and Δm²₂₁ such that predictions match observed oscillation parameters (θ₁₃, Δm²) within 15 percent without invoking additional Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ dihedral symmetry reduces the 20 complex-structure moduli to 5 D₆-invariant combinations, constraining the (2,1)-form integral basis to 26 independent couplings. These couplings, when projected onto the neutrino sector via the see-saw formula M_nu = negative Y_nu v²_u M⁻¹_N Y^T_nu, induce an M_nu eigenstructure whose hierarchical ordering is causally determined by the automorphism-induced coupling suppression pattern. RG running from the GUT scale to 2.4 GeV converts this UV texture into low-energy mass eigenvalues whose splittings (Δm²_ij) are functions of the invariant Yukawa matrix rank deficiency and the polytope's Picard-Fuchs constraints.
hypotheses.prediction: The ratio of predicted to experimental Δm²₃₂ will lie within [0.85, 1.15] and Δm²₂₁ within [0.80, 1.20], with predicted sin²(θ₁₃) less than or equal to 0.031 (within 2 sigma of the PDG 2023 central value 0.0220 plus or minus 0.0009), and the neutrino mass-matrix determinant will be reproduced to within a factor of 1.5 solely from the 26 D₆-invariant couplings.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If after RG running and see-saw projection, the predicted Δm²₃₂ differs from the PDG value by more than 20 percent (predicted divided by observed less than 0.80 or greater than 1.20), or if the predicted sin²(θ₁₃) exceeds 0.040, or if the neutrino mass-matrix structure requires coupling texture zeros not compatible with the 26 D₆-invariant combinations, then the D₆ polytope geometry alone is insufficient to reproduce neutrino observables.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Predicted Δm²₃₂ and Δm²₂₁ reproduce experimental values to within plus or minus 15 percent; explained variance in neutrino mass-matrix eigenvalue structure from 26 invariant couplings greater than or equal to 80 percent; sin²(θ₁₃) prediction error less than 2 sigma from PDG central value.

experiment.approach: Extend the CyTools computational pipeline to compute D₆-invariant (2,1)-form basis vectors and their triple intersections restricted to the invariant subspace. Construct the low-energy neutrino mass matrix via the see-saw formula with RG running from GUT to electroweak scale, and perform chi-squared fitting against PDG neutrino oscillation data to test whether predicted Δm² values and mixing angles match observations.
steps: Step 1: Compute the full (2,1)-form cohomology basis for GL12/D₆ using CyTools, decompose under irreducible representations of D₆, and extract the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant subspace.

Step 2: Calculate the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings Y_ijk as integral of CY3 Omega wedge chi_i wedge chi_j wedge chi_k where chi_i are D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms; construct the neutrino sector coupling matrix Y_nu by projecting onto the neutrino and right-handed neutrino fields.

Step 3: Set the heavy right-handed neutrino mass matrix M_N as a function of the polytope's Picard-Fuchs differential operators and the Kahler metric g_ab. Assume the simplest texture: M_N diagonal with entries proportional to the volume modulus raised to exponents in {1, 2, 3}.
Step 4: Compute the low-energy neutrino mass matrix via M_nu equals negative Y_nu v²_u M⁻¹_N Y^T_nu at the GUT scale (M_GUT approximately 2 times 10¹⁶ GeV).

Step 5: Perform 1-loop RG running of the MSSM from the GUT scale down to the electroweak scale (M_Z approximately 91 GeV) and subsequently to 2.4 GeV using 3-flavor effective theory, accounting for tau-lepton Yukawa running and threshold corrections.

Step 6: Diagonalize the RG-evolved M_nu to extract eigenvalues {m_1, m_2, m_3} and the PMNS matrix U; compute the predicted mass-squared differences Δm²_ij equals m²_i minus m²_j and the mixing angle sin²(θ₁₃).
Step 7: Perform global chi-squared fit using PDG 2023 experimental values and 1 sigma uncertainties for mass-squared differences and mixing angles.

Step 8: Test whether the rank of the 26 by 26 Yukawa coupling matrix, restricted to neutrino-sector entries, is consistent with a hierarchy of mass-squared differences using singular-value decomposition (SVD).
Step 9: Systematically test whether the 26 couplings can be reorganized to respect the structure of larger discrete-flavor groups (A₄, S₄) by checking for coupling texture zeros.

Step 10: Sensitivity analysis: vary the GUT-scale boundary conditions (tan beta, Yukawa couplings) within plus or minus 20 percent and compute the range of predicted Δm² and θ₁₃ values to quantify robustness.
tools: CyTools with extended (2,1)-form and coupling computation modules
SageMath or Mathematica for Picard-Fuchs differential-equation solving
SARAH or SoftSUSY for 1-loop RG running and threshold-correction implementation
ROOT or Julia for chi-squared minimization and SVD analysis
PDG 2023 neutrino oscillation parameters dataset
experiment.estimated_effort: 10 to 14 weeks: approximately 2 weeks (CyTools cohomology) plus 3 weeks (Picard-Fuchs and Kahler metric) plus 2 weeks (see-saw and RG pipeline) plus 2 weeks (chi-squared fitting) plus 1 week (SVD and flavor tests).
experiment.data_requirements: CY polytope definition file for GL12/D₆, CyTools cohomology databases, MSSM running couplings, PDG 2023 neutrino oscillation measurements with uncertainties.
experiment.expected_positive: Predicted Δm²₃₂ equals 2.40 to 2.62 times 10⁻³ eV² (observed 2.511 times 10⁻³); Δm²₂₁ equals 6.30 to 8.52 times 10⁻⁵ eV² (observed 7.41 times 10⁻⁵); sin²(θ₁₃) equals 0.018 to 0.026 (observed 0.0220); chi² less than 3.0; SVD analysis shows greater than or equal to 3 singular values above noise threshold supporting the 3-neutrino mass hierarchy.
experiment.expected_negative: Predicted Δm²₃₂ less than 2.01 times 10⁻³ or greater than 3.02 times 10⁻³ eV²; sin²(θ₁₃) greater than 0.040; chi² greater than 10; SVD rank drops below 3; coupling texture analysis reveals zeros incompatible with D₆-invariant linear combinations.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling texture of GL12/D₆, when combined with the see-saw mechanism and standard RG running, makes no statistically significant prediction of neutrino mass-squared differences beyond post-hoc fitting (chi² greater than 10 or predicted divided by observed ratio outside [0.75, 1.33]).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided chi-squared goodness-of-fit test with 3 observables (Δm²₂₁, Δm²₃₂, sin²θ₁₃) minus 1 constraint, yielding 2 degrees of freedom. Rejection threshold alpha equals 0.05 yields chi²_crit equals 5.99. Hypothesis confirmed if chi² less than 5.99 and all three predicted values lie within plus or minus 2 sigma of PDG central values. Additionally, perform Akaike information criterion (AIC) comparison: AIC_model equals chi² plus 2k versus AIC_reference. If ΔAIC greater than 10, evidence for D₆ texture is strong.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Δm²₃₂ prediction error less than 20 percent; Δm²₂₁ prediction error less than 20 percent; sin²(θ₁₃) prediction within 2 sigma of PDG; neutrino mass-matrix explained variance from 26 invariant couplings greater than or equal to 80 percent.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Computational experiment with deterministic polynomial evaluation. No stochastic sampling: convergence guaranteed by ODE solver accuracy (relative tolerance less than 10⁻⁸). Sensitivity analysis spans plus or minus 20 percent variation in GUT-scale Yukawa couplings and tan beta between 2 and 50, sampling approximately 50 parameter points. Effective power is robustness: if the same D₆ texture consistently reproduces PDG values across this parameter space, the mechanism is validated.
limitations: The Picard-Fuchs system determines the Kahler metric only up to overall scaling; the normalization is fixed by string coupling or volume-modulus stabilization.
CyTools cohomology computations do not capture non-perturbative worldsheet instanton corrections that may modify Yukawa couplings at order unity.
The assumption that M_N is diagonal in the basis where Y_nu is defined may not hold; off-diagonal entries could emerge from a more complete analysis of the D₆-invariant heavy-neutrino sector.
RG running assumes a minimal MSSM structure; extensions could modify the running by 10 to 30 percent.
The see-saw scale M_N approximately 10¹⁵ GeV creates large threshold effects; uncertainties in SUSY-breaking mediation can shift predictions by factors of 2 to 3.
Global fits to neutrino data already constrain models to approximately 3 percent precision; any prediction must meet this bar.
The GL12/D₆ polytope is only one of many CY geometries; generalization to other polytopes is not addressed.
experiment.requires_followup: If the computational prediction matches PDG within plus or minus 15 percent, compute rare lepton-flavor-violating (LFV) decay branching ratios (mu to e gamma, tau to mu gamma) predicted by the same Yukawa texture in supersymmetric extensions. The LFV branching ratios are sensitive to the neutrino Yukawa structure and would provide a complementary test. Specifically, compute BR(mu to e gamma) using one-loop SUSY contributions with the D₆-constrained Yukawa matrix and compare against MEG/MEG-II bounds. This wet-lab search would provide definitive independent evidence for the D₆ polytope Yukawa coupling.

hypotheses.source_question: Can non-complete intersection Calabi-Yau threefolds with discrete symmetries achieve the same degree of Yukawa coupling constraint and realistic flavor textures as complete intersections, and do their automorphism groups provide access to distinct monodromy-based flavor symmetries unavailable in the complete intersection landscape?
