hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that non-complete intersection Calabi-Yau threefolds with D₆ discrete automorphism groups generate more stringently constrained D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling textures—measured by reduction in degrees of freedom and magnitude of coupling suppressions—than complete intersections with equivalent Hodge numbers, because their resolved singularities introduce additional algebraic constraints on the Picard lattice that restrict the space of (2,1)-forms available for coupling computations.
hypotheses.mechanism: Complete intersection CY3s have smooth moduli spaces with generic automorphism groups acting freely on the cohomology. Non-complete intersections inherit singular loci whose resolution introduces exceptional divisors and forces the Picard lattice to expand in a constrained manner tied to the singularity types. These new divisor classes act as 'algebraic brakes' on the (2,1) cohomology, reducing the number of linearly independent (2,1)-forms that remain invariant under the discrete symmetry. Fewer invariant (2,1)-forms ϕ directly reduces the number of independent Yukawa couplings Y_{ijk} ∝ ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k that can be built, thereby tightening the coupling texture and generating larger mass hierarchies without auxiliary Froggatt-Nielsen mechanisms.
hypotheses.prediction: For a matched pair of D₆-symmetric CY3s with identical Hodge numbers (h¹¹, h²¹) but differing singularity content—one a complete intersection, one a non-complete intersection formed by resolution—the NCI will support ≤70% as many linearly independent D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms as the CI, resulting in a corresponding ≤70% as many independent D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings; simultaneously, the largest ratio between the heaviest and lightest D₆-invariant coupling in the NCI texture will be ≥2-fold larger (more hierarchical) than in the CI benchmark.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the number of D₆-invariant (2,1)-form basis elements in the resolved NCI is ≥80% of the CI count, or if the mass hierarchy ratio (max coupling / min coupling among D₆-invariant couplings) in the NCI is <1.5-fold larger than the CI, the hypothesis is refuted. Alternatively, if resolved singularities in the NCI do not reduce the dimension of the invariant (2,1)-cohomology subspace below that predicted by the CI's symmetry analysis alone, the mechanism is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥30% reduction in number of independent D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms (NCI vs. CI); ≥2-fold enhancement in coupling hierarchy magnitude (ratio of largest to smallest invariant Yukawa coupling); statistical confidence: all basis element counts and coupling values computed to machine precision (no probabilistic threshold required).

experiment.approach: Systematically construct 5 pairs of D₆-symmetric CY3s (CI vs. NCI with matched Hodge numbers), compute their resolved Picard lattices, enumerate the basis of D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms, and calculate D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings κ_{abc} and Y_{ijk} via direct integration. Compare the dimensionality of invariant cohomology and the hierarchy of couplings between CI and NCI groups using standard linear algebra and symbolic geometry tools.
steps: Select 3–5 explicit complete intersection CY3 examples with D₆ symmetry and known Hodge numbers from the Kreuzer–Skarke database or literature (e.g., KS hypersurfaces, GL=12/D₆ cases).

For each CI, construct a corresponding non-complete intersection variant by resolving singularities via blowup sequences; identify the singularity types (e.g., ADE, cyclic quotient) and their resolution graphs using standard toric or orbifold methods.
Compute the Hodge diamond of each resolved NCI to verify h¹¹ and h²¹ match the CI; if not, re-weight the selection to ensure matched pairs.
Construct the Picard lattice for each CI and NCI by computing intersection matrix entries κ_{ij} = D_i · D_j · D_k on the resolution; enumerate divisor classes explicitly.
Derive the period vector Π and Picard–Fuchs differential equations for each variety using CyTools or manual computation; verify consistency of the Hodge structure.
Identify the D₆ automorphism group action on H²(CY, ℂ) and H²,¹(CY, ℂ); decompose cohomology into eigenspaces under D₆ representation.
Compute a basis for the D₆-invariant subspace of H²,¹(CY, ℂ) for each variety (CI and NCI); record the dimension for each pair.
Construct the holomorphic (3,0)-form Ω (unique up to scaling) and compute D₆-invariant triple intersections κ_{abc} = ∫ J_a ∧ J_b ∧ J_c for all invariant Kähler moduli.
Select a representative set of (2,1)-forms χ_i, χ_j, χ_k from the D₆-invariant basis and compute Yukawa couplings Y_{ijk} ∝ ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k for each variety.
Tabulate the full list of independent D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings for CI vs. NCI; compute the ratio of maximum to minimum coupling magnitude (hierarchy) for each.
Statistical comparison: record dimensionality and hierarchy metrics for all 5 pairs; compute median and quartile differences between CI and NCI groups.
tools: CyTools (Calabi-Yau toric geometry toolkit) for Picard lattice, period, and cohomology computation
Macaulay2 or SageMath for explicit blowup resolution and divisor class computation
SymPy or Mathematica for symbolic integration of Yukawa couplings and (2,1)-form bases
Custom Python script to parse Picard-Fuchs systems, extract monodromy, and enumerate D₆-invariant subspaces using GAP (Groups, Algorithms, Programming) for group representation theory
Kreuzer–Skarke database for CI examples; arXiv preprints or recent CY catalogs for NCI candidates
experiment.estimated_effort: 3–4 weeks: 1 week for literature survey and pair selection; 1 week for Picard lattice and resolution computation; 1 week for period/Picard-Fuchs derivation; 1 week for cohomology decomposition, Yukawa integration, and comparative analysis.
experiment.data_requirements: Explicit equations (or toric data) for 5–10 CY3 examples with D₆ symmetry; access to Kreuzer–Skarke database or published CY topology tables; CyTools installation and supporting libraries (PALP, Singular); no novel data generation required.
experiment.expected_positive: NCI group shows ≤70% as many D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms as the matched CI (e.g., 5 vs. 8 basis elements), and the coupling hierarchy ratio in the NCI is ≥2-fold larger than in the CI (e.g., NCI max/min = 100, CI max/min = 45). Resolved singularities demonstrably reduce the dimension of the invariant (2,1) subspace.
experiment.expected_negative: NCI and CI groups have equivalent numbers of D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms (within ±10%), or the coupling hierarchy ratios are statistically indistinguishable (<1.3-fold difference). Resolution of singularities does not materially shrink the invariant cohomology subspace.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The dimension of the D₆-invariant (2,1)-cohomology subspace and the magnitude of the Yukawa coupling hierarchy are independent of whether a D₆-symmetric CY3 is a complete intersection or a non-complete intersection (with resolved singularities), when Hodge numbers are held constant.
experiment.statistical_test: Paired comparison (Wilcoxon signed-rank or paired t-test) of cohomology dimensions (NCI vs. CI) for n=5 matched pairs; paired comparison of log-hierarchy ratios. Threshold: p<0.05 for rejection of H₀. Effect size: median fractional reduction in invariant (2,1)-forms (NCI / CI) ≤0.70; median hierarchy enhancement ≥2.0-fold.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: ≥30% reduction in dimensionality of D₆-invariant (2,1)-forms (e.g., from 8 to ≤5.6); ≥2.0-fold increase in max/min Yukawa coupling ratio. These thresholds are well above noise floor given symbolic computation (machine precision).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With n=5 matched pairs and deterministic algebraic computation (no sampling error), statistical power is >0.99 against H₀ if the true effect size meets the stated thresholds (≥30% reduction, ≥2-fold hierarchy). No power analysis needed for symbolic computation; convergence is determined by algebraic algorithm termination. Sensitivity analysis: vary singularity resolution strategy (different blowup orderings) to test robustness of cohomology dimension reduction.
limitations: Limited to CY3s with explicit D₆ symmetry; generalization to other discrete groups (e.g., A₄, S₄) requires separate analysis.
Picard lattice computation assumes singularities are toric or quotient-resolvable; irregular singularities may require ad-hoc methods.
Yukawa coupling integrals are symbolic and assume analytic cohomology representatives; numerical integration may introduce precision artifacts on difficult resolutions.
Matched pairs require identical Hodge numbers; not all CI/NCI pairs can be perfectly matched, potentially confounding geometry with symmetry effects.
No direct test of whether tighter Yukawa textures actually yield realistic fermion mass hierarchies without Froggatt-Nielsen; flavor phenomenology connection is deferred to follow-up.
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab follow-up not applicable (purely algebraic-geometric problem). Next computational step: (1) Extend comparison to non-D₆ discrete groups (A₄, S₄, Δ(27)) and verify generality of constraint mechanism. (2) Perform global string compactification analysis: embed leading NCI examples into full string moduli space, compute soft-SUSY-breaking masses and gaugino-mediation couplings, and compare predictions for neutrino mixing angles (θ₁₃, δ_CP) against experiment to test whether NCI Yukawa textures naturally reproduce observed lepton mixing without fine-tuning. (3) Construct explicit vector-like matter spectra for NCI geometries and compute effective flavor-symmetry-breaking scales to assess viability of realistic fermion mass matrices.

hypotheses.source_question: Do generalized complex structures on symplectic Calabi-Yau 4-manifolds preserve or extend the discrete automorphism groups (like D₆) that act on classical Calabi-Yau 3-folds, and if so, can monodromy around generalized deformations predict new flavor-symmetry textures inaccessible to classical geometry?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆ discrete automorphisms acting on classical Calabi-Yau 3-folds lift coherently to the generalized complex moduli space of their symplectic Calabi-Yau 4-fold fiber-base decompositions, and this lift causes a measurable expansion of the Yukawa-coupling constraint space, generating new hierarchical texture solutions that reduce the rank-deficit in quark-lepton mass matrices by ≥2 independent relations compared to classical D₆-only geometry.
hypotheses.mechanism: Generalized complex structures interpolate between symplectic and complex geometries via B-field deformations. When a discrete automorphism σ ∈ D₆ acts on a CY3, it preserves classical Dolbeault cohomology (∂̄-closed forms). Under lift to the generalized setting, σ must commute with the generalized complex operator J = ∂̄ + ι_∂B, where ι_∂B encodes B-field back-reaction. This commutation relation imposes new algebraic constraints on the generalized periods, enlarging the space of σ-invariant sections of the generalized canonical bundle. These expanded invariants feed into the generalized Picard-Fuchs system, creating additional linear dependencies among Yukawa couplings that are forbidden in classical geometry.
hypotheses.prediction: Generalized D₆-invariant periods produce ≥2 additional independent vanishing conditions on Yukawa couplings Y_{ijk} (beyond the 26 classical D₆-invariant couplings on GL12/D₆), measurable as rank(constraint matrix) on generalized moduli ≥ rank(classical) + 2. Equivalently: the dimension of the space of realistic Yukawa textures compatible with generalized D₆ symmetry shall be ≤ 3 (classical: ≈ 5), and at least one texture solution shall predict m_μ/m_τ ∈ [0.055, 0.058] and sin²(θ₁₃) ∈ [0.022, 0.025] within ±10% of experimental values without Froggatt-Nielsen insertion.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If generalized D₆-invariant periods yield rank(constraint matrix) on generalized moduli = rank(classical), or if the texture-solution space expands (dimension > classical), or if no realistic texture solution achieves m_μ/m_τ ∈ [0.055, 0.058] AND sin²(θ₁₃) ∈ [0.022, 0.025] simultaneously without ad-hoc matter coupling, the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Rank increase ≥ 2 in the constraint matrix (measured as corank of the Yukawa-coupling space); equivalently, at least one Yukawa coupling must be forbidden by generalized D₆ symmetry that survives classical D₆ constraints. Mass-ratio prediction: m_μ/m_τ accurate to ±10% of observed value (0.0591±0.0006) and sin²(θ₁₃) accurate to ±15% of observed value (0.0224±0.0014) in at least one solution branch.

experiment.approach: Extend the CyTools computational pipeline to track how the D₆ action on a classical CY3 (e.g., GL12) lifts to the generalized complex moduli of its K3 × T² fiber-base realization. Compute the generalized Picard-Fuchs system for D₆-invariant periods, extract Yukawa couplings as functions of both classical and B-field moduli, and compare texture rank and mass-hierarchy predictions.
steps: Step 1: Construct the K3 × T² fiber-base model for GL12/D₆, parameterize the fiber K3 by classical moduli (h¹¹=20) and base T² by generalized moduli (B-field + symplectic structure), with explicit D₆ action on each.

Step 2: Compute the generalized complex structure operator J = ∂̄ + ι_∂B for a family of B-field backgrounds (e.g., B ∈ H¹(CY3, ℝ)/H¹(CY3, ℤ)) and verify that D₆ commutes with J; extract commutation-relation constraints on generalized moduli.

Step 3: Extend CyTools to compute generalized periods ∫_Γ Ω ∧ e^{iB} (including B-field correction) and D₆-invariant combinations thereof; build the generalized Picard-Fuchs system (differential equations in classical + B-field moduli).

Step 4: Extract the full set of D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings from the generalized geometry (κ_{abc} and Y_{ijk} as in the domain context) across a 2D slice in the B-field moduli space; compute rank of the constraint matrix at each B-field value.

Step 5: Identify ≥2 Yukawa couplings that vanish in the generalized setting but survive classically; verify they are not artifacts of incomplete basis expansion by cross-checking with higher-dimensional basis sets.

Step 6: Fit mass-ratio predictions (m_e, m_μ, m_τ and m_u, m_c, m_t ratios, plus lepton mixing angles θ₁₃, θ₂₃) for Yukawa textures satisfying both classical AND generalized constraints; compare with experimental targets.
Step 7: Repeat steps 3–6 for 3–4 alternative CY3 bases (e.g., degree-(4,4,4,4) in ℙ³×ℙ³ with D₆ action) to establish robustness and generalizability.
tools: CyTools (modified to track generalized complex structures and B-field moduli)
SageMath / Macaulay2 for Picard-Fuchs computation in extended moduli
Singular/Gröbner basis for constraint-matrix rank calculation
Custom Python pipeline to extract D₆-invariant periods and Yukawa couplings
Fitting harness (scipy.optimize) to map Yukawa textures to physical mass ratios
SEMIDEF solvers to verify monodromy invariance around loops in generalized moduli
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks: 2 weeks for generalized-structure formalism; 3 weeks for CyTools extension; 3 weeks for Picard-Fuchs computation and basis validation; 2 weeks for mass-ratio fitting and comparative analysis; 1–2 weeks for alternative bases and robustness checks.
experiment.data_requirements: CY3 mirror database (Kreuzer–Skarke); Hodge diamond data for GL12 and alternative bases; experimental values: m_μ/m_τ = 0.0591±0.0006, sin²(θ₁₃) = 0.0224±0.0014 (PDG 2023); standard GUT normalization conventions for Yukawa-to-mass-ratio mapping.
experiment.expected_positive: The generalized Picard-Fuchs system produces ≥2 additional linear dependencies among Yukawa couplings (rank increase ≥2); at least one Yukawa coupling Y_{ijk} (classical: ≠0 under D₆) vanishes under generalized D₆ symmetry. Mass-ratio texture achieves m_μ/m_τ = 0.0591±0.0059 and sin²(θ₁₃) = 0.0224±0.0034 (±10% and ±15% respectively) without Froggatt-Nielsen insertion.
experiment.expected_negative: The commutation relation [σ, J] = 0 cannot be satisfied for any B-field background (indicating D₆ does not lift); rank(constraint matrix) on generalized moduli equals or decreases vs. classical case; no Yukawa texture simultaneously achieves m_μ/m_τ ∈ [0.055, 0.058] and sin²(θ₁₃) ∈ [0.022, 0.025]; mass-ratio predictions require Froggatt-Nielsen or other ad-hoc mechanisms.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆ discrete automorphism of a CY3 does not lift coherently to its generalized complex moduli space (i.e., the commutation [σ, J] ≠ 0), OR the lift yields no new linear constraints on Yukawa couplings (rank increase = 0), OR mass-ratio textures from generalized D₆ geometry are statistically indistinguishable from classical D₆ predictions.
experiment.statistical_test: One-tailed test: rank(generalized constraint matrix) − rank(classical constraint matrix) > 0, evaluated via Gaussian elimination with numerical rank tolerance (relative singular-value cutoff = 1e-10). For mass-ratio fitting: χ² goodness-of-fit test comparing predicted vs. experimental mass ratios/mixing angles; null rejected if χ²/dof < 1 (indicating fit quality ≥ classical case) and at least one texture branch achieves both mass-ratio targets simultaneously within ±10% and ±15% respectively (two-tailed 1-σ bands). Significance threshold: rank increase statistically significant if Δrank ≥ 2 and verified across ≥3 independent CY3 bases.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Rank(constraint matrix) increase of exactly 2 (the predicted causal effect); equivalently, 2 or more Yukawa couplings must be identifiably forbidden by generalized D₆ symmetry in a way that is not possible in classical geometry. For mass-ratio texture: improvement in fit quality (reduction in χ²/dof by ≥20% vs. classical D₆) OR achievement of m_μ/m_τ and θ₁₃ targets simultaneously (both within stated error bands) by ≥1 texture solution branch.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Computational experiment with deterministic algebraic operations (Gröbner basis, rank computation). Power is determined by numerical precision (basis expansion order N, where N ≥ 100 monomials per modulus; convergence verified by varying N and confirming rank stabilization). No probabilistic sampling; expected variability comes only from choice of base CY3 and B-field parameterization. Robustness = ≥3 independent bases + ≥2 independent B-field parameterizations per base, all yielding Δrank ≥ 2 and consistent texture improvement.
limitations: CyTools currently does not natively track generalized complex structures; extension requires hand-coded B-field dependence in Picard-Fuchs computation, introducing risk of implementation error—mitigated by cross-validation with symbolic computation (Macaulay2).

Generalized Picard-Fuchs system is over-determined and may not have solutions for all B-field backgrounds; restriction to a lower-dimensional B-field slice (e.g., H¹(K3, ℝ) ⊂ H¹(CY3, ℝ)) may exclude physically relevant regimes.
Yukawa-to-mass-ratio mapping assumes minimal supergravity; non-minimal models (e.g., with multiple Higgs doublets, matter asymmetry couplings) could alter predictions and require separate analysis.
Experimental mass-ratio targets (m_μ/m_τ, θ₁₃) are from running-mass schemes; conversion to CY-geometry scale (μ ≈ M_GUT) introduces GUT-normalization dependence and ~5% uncertainty.
Generalized monodromy around loops in B-field moduli space is computationally expensive; only 2D slices tested, not full 5D generalized moduli space.
Alternative CY3 bases may have smaller automorphism groups or less structured D₆ actions, limiting generalizability of rank-increase mechanism.
experiment.requires_followup: If computational predictions are confirmed (Δrank ≥ 2, m_μ/m_τ and θ₁₃ within target bands), construct an explicit string-theory model (e.g., Type IIA or Type IIB compactification) on the predicted generalized CY geometry and verify Yukawa couplings via worldsheet CFT or T-dual heterotic calculation. This step is essential to confirm that the algebraic predictions of generalized D₆ symmetry manifest physically in string-coupling amplitudes and are not artifacts of the period-integral formalism.

hypotheses.source_question: Can discrete flavor symmetries arising from CY₃ automorphisms (particularly D₆ symmetries) predict or constrain the CP-violation phase δ_CP and mass hierarchy signatures measurable in long-baseline neutrino oscillation experiments?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆-invariant Yukawa textures derived from GL=12/D₆ CY₃ polytopes, when embedded in type-I seesaw neutrino mass models with minimal Froggatt-Nielsen charges, predict a specific correlation between the leptonic CP-violation phase δ_CP and the neutrino mass hierarchy (normal vs. inverted) that is distinguishable from random texture zeros at >3σ significance in long-baseline oscillation parameter space.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ automorphism group acts on the 20 complex-structure moduli, reducing the space of allowed Yukawa couplings to 26 D₆-invariant combinations. These couplings, when constrained by Froggatt-Nielsen suppression factors, generate specific zero patterns in both the Dirac neutrino mass matrix (m_D) and the right-handed Majorana matrix (M_R). The interplay between texture zeros and seesaw mass generation (m_ν = -m_D M_R⁻¹ m_D^T) deterministically maps the geometric constraints onto neutrino mixing parameters. Crucially, the pattern of allowed non-zero couplings—which is geometry-dependent—restricts the possible δ_CP values compatible with a given mass hierarchy to a lower-dimensional subset of oscillation parameter space, making δ_CP and mass ordering correlated rather than independent.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12/D₆ polytope with minimal Froggatt-Nielsen charges (ε-charges: 0, 1, 2 per generation), the predicted δ_CP values for normal hierarchy will cluster in the range [180°, 270°] with width <80°, whereas for inverted hierarchy the allowed range will be [0°, 100°] with width <80°, such that the two mass-hierarchy scenarios occupy non-overlapping δ_CP intervals at 95% CL. This 1D correlation will be absent in generic texture-zero models without CY geometry constraints (where δ_CP distributions for NH and IH will overlap substantially, >50% overlap in 2σ bands).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the predicted δ_CP intervals for normal and inverted hierarchy computed from D₆-invariant Yukawa textures overlap by >50% in their 2σ confidence bands (i.e., >50% of the allowed δ_CP region for NH is also allowed for IH given the same Froggatt-Nielsen charges), then the hypothesis is falsified. Alternatively, if the distribution of δ_CP values across all 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling combinations produces a p-value >0.05 in a two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test against random texture zeros with the same sparsity, the geometric constraint is not the source of the δ_CP-hierarchy correlation.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Non-overlapping δ_CP intervals for NH vs IH with <50% overlap in 2σ bands; equivalently, a separation between the medians of δ_CP(NH) and δ_CP(IH) distributions of ≥60°, detectable with n≥20 independent Froggatt-Nielsen hierarchies per mass scenario at 80% power.

experiment.approach: Computationally enumerate D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling patterns on the GL=12/D₆ polytope using CyTools, embed them into a type-I seesaw framework with Froggatt-Nielsen suppression, systematically scan the space of allowed ε-charges (0–3 per generation), and for each valid texture extract neutrino mixing parameters (including δ_CP and mass hierarchy) to quantify the δ_CP-hierarchy correlation. Compare the observed correlation strength against an ensemble of random texture zeros with identical sparsity to establish statistical significance.
steps: Step 1: Use CyTools to compute the full set of 26 D₆-invariant Kähler triple intersections κ_{abc} and period integrals ∫ Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k for the GL=12/D₆ polytope, verifying D₆ invariance under all automorphisms.

Step 2: Enumerate all Froggatt-Nielsen charge assignments (ε_i, ε_j, ε_k ∈ {0,1,2,3}) and construct the effective Yukawa coupling matrix Y_eff = Y_raw × exp(-Σ_α ε_α λ^n_α) for 500+ distinct hierarchies, ensuring each generates a valid neutrino mass matrix (positive-definite Majorana block).

Step 3: For each valid Yukawa texture, diagonalize the seesaw mass matrix m_ν = -m_D M_R⁻¹ m_D^T; extract the PMNS mixing matrix U and identify the physical mixing angles (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃) and CP phase δ_CP using the PDG parameterization. Record the predicted mass hierarchy (sign of m₃² - (m₁² + m₂²)/2).

Step 4: Partition the 500 textures into two cohorts: (A) those predicting normal hierarchy (NH), (B) those predicting inverted hierarchy (IH). Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function (ECDF) of δ_CP for each cohort and compute the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) statistic d_KS between ECDF_NH and ECDF_IH.

Step 5: Generate 1000 random texture-zero matrices with identical sparsity (26 non-zero couplings out of 27, corresponding to 1 zero per generation) by randomly zeroing one coupling per generation. Repeat Steps 3–4 on this ensemble to obtain a null distribution of d_KS under the hypothesis that texture zeros alone (without CY geometry) produce the observed δ_CP-hierarchy correlation.

Step 6: Compute the p-value as the fraction of random textures yielding d_KS ≥ observed d_KS. Test the hypothesis that δ_CP distributions for NH and IH are distinct (two-sample KS test, α=0.05, one-tailed). Additionally, compute the percentage overlap between the 2σ confidence bands of δ_CP(NH) and δ_CP(IH) using bootstrapped quantiles.

Step 7: Identify the 5–10 Froggatt-Nielsen hierarchies that produce δ_CP predictions closest to the current PDG best-fit value (δ_CP ≈ 222° with 1σ error ~40°) and check whether they cluster in NH or IH. Map these benchmark textures to specific CY₃ polytope data to facilitate future experimental follow-up.
tools: CyTools (https://github.com/ariostas/CYTools) for Kähler metrics, periods, and automorphism group actions on GL=12/D₆ polytope
SageMath 10.0+ for matrix diagonalization, PMNS parameterization, and eigenvalue decomposition
Custom Python pipeline (scipy.linalg, numpy) to implement Froggatt-Nielsen charge scanning, seesaw mass matrix construction, and mixing parameter extraction
PDG neutrino mixing benchmark data (arXiv:2212.11100 or later) for comparison of predicted parameters against current best-fit values
Wolfram Mathematica or SymPy for symbolic verification of D₆ invariance of 26 Yukawa couplings
ROOT or matplotlib for visualization of δ_CP distributions, KS test results, and overlap regions
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–6 weeks: 1 week for CyTools polytope data extraction and D₆ invariance verification (~100 CPU hours); 2 weeks for Froggatt-Nielsen charge enumeration and seesaw diagonalization across 500+ textures (~500 CPU hours); 1 week for null-model random texture generation and KS statistics; 1 week for visualization, benchmark selection, and validation against PDG data.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database of GL=12/D₆ polytope (freely available); PDG neutrino oscillation parameters (θ₁₂, θ₂₃, θ₁₃, Δm²₂₁, Δm²₃₁, δ_CP central values and 1σ errors from recent global fits); standard model Yukawa couplings and fermion masses (used to set the overall scale of m_D and M_R); optional: previous CY₃ Yukawa texture studies (e.g., Denef & Douglas 2005, Cvetic et al. 2011) for comparison of allowed coupling patterns.
experiment.expected_positive: The KS statistic d_KS computed between ECDF_NH and ECDF_IH for D₆-invariant textures is ≥0.35 (corresponding to >95% separation in the Kolmogorov distribution), with p-value <0.05 in a two-sample KS test. The overlap between 2σ confidence bands for δ_CP(NH) and δ_CP(IH) is <50%. When compared to the null distribution from random textures, the observed d_KS is at the 95th percentile or higher, indicating that D₆ geometry—not generic texture sparsity—drives the δ_CP-hierarchy correlation. At least 3–5 of the top 10 benchmark textures closest to PDG δ_CP values cluster in a single mass-hierarchy scenario (NH or IH) with >80% probability.
experiment.expected_negative: The KS statistic d_KS between ECDF_NH and ECDF_IH is <0.20, or the two-sample KS test yields p-value >0.05. The overlap between 2σ bands exceeds 50%. When compared to the null distribution, the observed d_KS falls below the 50th percentile, indicating no significant difference from random textures. In this case, the D₆ automorphism does not constrain δ_CP independently of mass hierarchy, falsifying the hypothesis.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The distribution of δ_CP values for normal-hierarchy textures derived from D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings is equal to the distribution of δ_CP values for inverted-hierarchy textures (i.e., δ_CP ⊥ hierarchy). Equivalently, the texture-zero pattern imposed by D₆ geometry induces no correlation between δ_CP and mass ordering beyond what is expected from random texture zeros with identical sparsity.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test (one-tailed), α=0.05, comparing ECDF_NH vs ECDF_IH across n₁=number of NH textures and n₂=number of IH textures (expected n₁, n₂ ≈ 200–300 each from ~500 valid Froggatt-Nielsen hierarchies). Significance threshold: KS statistic d_KS ≥ 0.35 (corresponding to p<0.05 for n₁=n₂≈250). Secondary test: two-proportion z-test for the fraction of textures with δ_CP overlap <50° vs >50° between NH and IH scenarios.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: A difference in median δ_CP between NH and IH distributions of ≥60° (equivalent to ~1.5 standard deviations of the current PDG uncertainty in δ_CP ≈ 40°), detectable with n≥200 textures per mass scenario at 80% power using a two-sample t-test (Cohen's d≈0.5). For the KS test, this corresponds to d_KS≈0.35 with the same sample sizes and power.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Expected N: ~500 valid Froggatt-Nielsen hierarchies total (~250 per mass scenario). For two-sample KS test with α=0.05 (one-tailed), n₁=n₂=250, the test has >90% power to detect d_KS≥0.35 (corresponding to a clinically/physically meaningful separation in median δ_CP of ≥60°). Convergence criterion: stop Froggatt-Nielsen enumeration once ≥250 distinct valid NH textures and ≥250 valid IH textures have been generated, ensuring the 2σ confidence bands on δ_CP medians have stabilized (i.e., adding 10 more textures changes the median by <3°).
limitations: The calculation assumes a type-I seesaw framework; other mechanisms (e.g., inverse seesaw, linear seesaw) may yield different δ_CP-hierarchy correlations. A follow-up hypothesis would need to test whether the observed correlation is robust across seesaw variants.

Froggatt-Nielsen charges are assumed to be real scalars (ε ∈ ℝ); if complex phases are introduced, the texture-zero pattern and thus the δ_CP predictions will change. The hypothesis does not constrain the origin of ε charges (whether from spurion vevs or other mechanisms).

The study assumes that higher-dimensional operators (dim ≥6) are negligible compared to the renormalizable Yukawa couplings extracted from CY₃ periods. If higher-dimension operators are sizable, they could modify the effective texture and correlation.

The hypothesis is sensitive to the precise definition of 'D₆-invariant': it assumes the 26 couplings are those invariant under the full D₆ group. If only a subgroup of D₆ is active (due to explicit breaking at lower scales), the prediction may not hold.

The extraction of δ_CP is model-dependent (assumes the standard PMNS parameterization); if non-standard CP violation sources exist (e.g., Majorana phases), the predicted observable in long-baseline experiments may differ.

No information about the relative coefficients of the 26 D₆-invariant couplings is used beyond their positions in the Yukawa matrix; if CY₃ geometry also constrains these coefficients (via worldsheet instanton corrections), the true texture space may be smaller and the prediction stronger or weaker.
experiment.requires_followup: After computational confirmation (p<0.05 in KS test with d_KS≥0.35 and <50% overlap), a wet-lab follow-up would require: (1) Precision measurements of δ_CP using DUNE's neutrino and antineutrino beams (~10 years of data for 1σ measurement of δ_CP if the true value differs from 0° or 180° by >30°), combined with (2) mass-hierarchy determination via the electron-antineutrino appearance rate and muon disappearance at DUNE and T2K. If the measured δ_CP and hierarchy are consistent with CY₃ predictions for ≥3 benchmark textures (within 2σ), it would provide tentative evidence that discrete flavor symmetries from string geometry constrain low-energy neutrino physics. Conversely, a measurement of δ_CP and hierarchy that is inconsistent with all 500 predicted textures (at >5σ) would rule out the D₆-based family of models. This measurement is expected to mature within ~10–15 years based on DUNE+T2K schedules.

hypotheses.source_question: Can the Movable Bend and Break Lemma be extended to classify rational sections of Calabi-Yau fibrations whose automorphism groups preserve discrete flavor symmetries, thereby predicting which CY3 models admit non-Abelian symmetry constraints on Yukawa couplings?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the Movable Bend and Break Lemma, when reformulated for equivariant rational sections of Calabi-Yau threefold fibrations over D₆-invariant moduli bases, yields a complete classification of deformation obstructions that determines exactly which Yukawa coupling textures are geometrically realizable without fine-tuning, thereby reducing the 26 D₆-invariant couplings of GL=12/D₆ to a smaller rigid subset that naturally reproduces quark-lepton mass hierarchies.
hypotheses.mechanism: The Movable Bend and Break Lemma constrains deformations of rational sections by enforcing that sections moving within a base curve B must satisfy intersection-theoretic rigidity at fixed loci of the automorphism group. When applied to CY3 fibrations with D₆ symmetry acting on both the fibers and the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant moduli subspace, the deformation obstruction locus becomes equivariant, reducing the space of freely movable sections and thus the number of independent Yukawa couplings that can vary. This geometric constraint directly encodes the Froggatt-Nielsen mechanism: sections that cannot move within D₆-invariant loci correspond to suppressed (or forbidden) Yukawa couplings.
hypotheses.prediction: The equivariant Movable Bend and Break classification will reduce the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings to at most 12 independent, non-deformable couplings (≥50% reduction), and at least 8 of these surviving couplings will exhibit hierarchical patterns (differences ≥2 orders of magnitude) consistent with observed quark and lepton mass ratios (e.g., m_u/m_c ≤ 10⁻², m_e/m_μ ≤ 10⁻²) when evaluated on the GL=12/D₆ polytope.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If computation of equivariant deformation obstructions using intersection theory on the D₆-invariant moduli locus yields fewer than 8 independent Yukawa couplings with hierarchical structure (i.e., <50% of the 26 couplings reduce, or >90% of survivors have similar magnitude), or if the surviving couplings violate observed mass ratios by more than one order of magnitude (e.g., m_u/m_c > 10⁻¹), the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥50% reduction in independent Yukawa couplings (from 26 to ≤13), with ≥8 couplings exhibiting hierarchy (ratio ≥100×), reproducing at least 3 of the 6 observed mass ratios (u/c, d/s, e/μ, ν_e/ν_μ, or equivalently m_e/m_μ, m_u/m_c) within a factor of 3 of experiment.

experiment.approach: Develop an equivariant version of the Movable Bend and Break Lemma by computing intersection-theoretic obstructions for families of rational sections of CY3 fibrations under the D₆ action, then apply this framework to the GL=12/D₆ polytope to predict which of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings survive as geometrically rigid, and validate by computing actual couplings via CyTools and comparing mass hierarchy predictions.
steps: Step 1: Reformulate Movable Bend and Break for equivariant sections. Construct the universal family of rational sections S → B_inv, where B_inv is the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant moduli subspace, using explicit basis of invariant divisors and sections from CyTools.

Step 2: Compute the fixed-point subvarieties F_g for each generator g ∈ D₆, and compute their codimensions in S and B_inv using equivariant intersection theory (via Borel-Moore homology and virtual fundamental class).

Step 3: For each of the 26 D₆-invariant monomials Y_{ijk} in the Yukawa superpotential, determine whether the corresponding section (or product of sections) can be moved away from the invariant locus. Use Picard-Fuchs monodromy invariants to certify global rigidity.

Step 4: Filter the 26 couplings by deformation rigidity: classify as 'movable' (can be deformed away from invariant locus, suppressed), 'rigid' (cannot move, survives), or 'marginally rigid' (boundary case requiring numerical refinement).

Step 5: For each rigid and marginally-rigid coupling, compute the explicit numerical Yukawa coupling κ_{ijk} using CyTools on the GL=12/D₆ polytope, evaluating the integral Y_{ijk} ∝ ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k.
Step 6: Extract mass ratios by assuming a simple Froggatt-Nielsen ansatz: m_i/m_j ∝ exp(−λ_{ij}) where λ_{ij} is the suppression exponent encoded in the deformation obstruction order.
Step 7: Validate predictions on two additional CY3 families with non-Abelian symmetries (e.g., A₄ or S₃) to test generalizability.

Step 8: Cross-check results using monodromy group representation theory: verify that sections classified as rigid are eigenvectors of D₆ monodromy with eigenvalue 1 (invariant under full monodromy action).
tools: CyTools (Kähler and Yukawa coupling computation for CY3 polytopes)
Singular/Macaulay2 (equivariant intersection theory, Gröbner basis for invariant computation)
SageMath/GAP (D₆ representation theory and character table computation)
Mathematica/Python (symbolic integration of Picard-Fuchs periods and monodromy group computation)
Custom Python module for equivariant Movable Bend and Break algorithm (construct obstruction locus, classify sections)
Magma (verification of rational section curves and genus computation)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks computation. Weeks 1–2: equivariant reformulation and algorithm design; Weeks 3–5: CyTools coupling computation for GL=12/D₆; Weeks 6–8: equivariant intersection theory and obstruction locus computation; Weeks 9–10: validation on two additional families; Weeks 11–12: cross-check via monodromy and write-up.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database entries for GL=12/D₆ polytope (divisor classes, Chern classes, Picard lattice); explicit generators of D₆ action on moduli; Picard-Fuchs equations for the mirror family; mirror symmetry data (periods and monodromy matrices). Two additional CY3 families with non-Abelian symmetries (A₄ or S₃) from published databases or literature (e.g., CICY database or Calabi-Yau catalog).
experiment.expected_positive: Equivariant obstruction computation yields ≥8 rigid Yukawa couplings (out of 26) with hierarchical suppression factors ≥100×, and mass ratios computed from these couplings (e.g., m_u/m_c, m_d/m_s) match observed values within a factor of 3, confirming that D₆ geometry alone encodes realistic flavor hierarchy without ad hoc Froggatt-Nielsen assumptions.
experiment.expected_negative: Obstruction analysis yields <8 rigid couplings with hierarchy, or surviving couplings exhibit ≤10× suppression, or mass ratios deviate by >1 order of magnitude from experiment, or monodromy eigenvalue analysis shows that many 'rigid' couplings are actually monodromy-variant (eigenvalue ≠1), indicating that the lemma in its reformulated form does not constrain the texture.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The Movable Bend and Break Lemma, when applied to equivariant sections of CY3 fibrations, does not reduce the dimension of the Yukawa coupling space beyond what is already accounted for by D₆ invariance of the moduli basis; i.e., all 26 D₆-invariant couplings remain independently deformable, and flavor hierarchy arises only from accidental numerical coincidences or additional unmodeled physics.
experiment.statistical_test: Exact symbolic computation (no statistical test): verify that (1) the codimension of the equivariant obstruction locus in S × B_inv is ≥2 for ≥8 of the 26 couplings (ensuring rigidity); (2) monodromy eigenvalues for rigid sections are exactly 1 (not approximate, using exact algebraic verification); (3) at least 3 of 6 quark/lepton mass ratios match observed values within a factor of 3 (deterministic comparison, no p-value). For the two validation families, verify consistency of the obstruction-reduction ratio: prediction±10% of the GL=12/D₆ ratio.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: ≥2-fold reduction in independent Yukawa couplings (26 → ≤13), with ≥8 couplings showing ≥100× hierarchical suppression (log₁₀(κ_i/κ_j) ≥ 2), and mass ratios recovered within a factor of 3 of experiment (e.g., computed m_e/m_μ ∈ [3×10⁻³, 3×10⁻²], observed = 5.1×10⁻³).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: This is a deterministic algebraic computation with no random sampling. Success is determined by exact symbolic verification: the obstruction locus dimension and monodromy eigenvalue spectrum are computable with exact arithmetic (no floating-point approximation). Convergence criterion: all equivariant intersection numbers stabilize to integer values, and Picard-Fuchs periods converge to at least 50 decimal places (confirming correct monodromy action). For the two validation families, the reduction ratio (# rigid couplings / # total invariant couplings) must agree with GL=12/D₆ to within 10% to confirm the lemma is family-independent.
limitations: The equivariant Movable Bend and Break Lemma is novel and has not been previously published; its correctness depends on rigorous algebraic-geometric proofs that must be formalized during the project.
CyTools coupling computation is limited to polytopes with manageable Hilbert series; very large polytopes may exceed computational resources.

The simplified Froggatt-Nielsen ansatz (m_i/m_j ∝ exp(−λ_{ij})) is a crude model that ignores flavor-mixing matrices and electroweak symmetry breaking; refined mass predictions require coupling to electroweak theory, which is deferred.
D₆ is non-Abelian but relatively small; generalization to larger discrete groups (A₄, S₄, PSL(2,F₇)) may require algorithmic refinements not explored here.
Validation on only two additional CY3 families limits confidence in universality; a larger sample (5–10 families) would strengthen the claim.
The Picard-Fuchs monodromy computation assumes the mirror is an explicit hypersurface; some CY3 models lack explicit mirrors, making this step infeasible.
experiment.requires_followup: To fully validate the hypothesis, the following wet-lab or observational steps would be needed: (1) Heterotic string compactification on the predicted GL=12/D₆ geometry with explicit computation of gauge coupling unification and proton decay rates; (2) phenomenological analysis of fermion mass matrices, CKM and PMNS mixing matrices, and CP-violation phases arising from the rigid Yukawa couplings, compared to electroweak precision tests; (3) if the computed mass hierarchy passes benchmarks, construct the full D₆-invariant heterotic model and compute anomaly-free gauge group and matter spectrum. For this computational stage, these steps are deferred; the experiment above focuses on validating the geometric prediction of coupling texture reduction and mass-ratio hierarchy using only algebraic geometry and CyTools.

hypotheses.source_question: Can the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture of the GL=12/D₆ CY3 polytope, constrained by its 26 surviving couplings, dynamically generate the large solar mixing angle θ₁₂ ≈ 35° without requiring ad-hoc Froggatt-Nielsen hierarchy, and does the monodromy group of this specific CY3 impose additional constraints on θ₁₂ that are measurable in oscillation physics?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture of the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau polytope, constrained to exactly 26 surviving holomorphic couplings, dynamically generates the solar neutrino mixing angle θ₁₂ ≈ 35° through a structure of texture zeros in the effective neutrino mass matrix that is imposed by D₆ automorphism symmetry and the Picard-Fuchs monodromy group, without requiring ad-hoc Froggatt-Nielsen hierarchy.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ automorphism group acts on both the space of complex-structure moduli (reducing 20 to 5 D₆-invariant combinations) and the holomorphic (3,0)-form Ω, which appears in the Yukawa coupling integral ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k. This symmetry action forbids or enforces specific coupling matrix elements, creating a rank-deficient and sparse texture in the neutrino mass matrix M_ν. The Casas-Ibarra parametrization maps this constrained texture directly to mixing angles: regions of Kähler and complex-structure moduli space where the D₆-invariant structure naturally produces a 2×2 block-like form in M_ν (with suppressed (1,3) and (2,3) entries relative to the (1,2) block) will yield sin²(2θ₁₂) ≈ 0.866 independently of tuning, because the monodromy group's period integrals restrict the allowed couplings to those satisfying this geometric constraint.
hypotheses.prediction: Numerical scanning of the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant Kähler moduli subspace and the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant complex-structure moduli subspace will yield sin²(2θ₁₂) ∈ [0.846, 0.886] (3σ around PDG best-fit 0.866) in at least 40% of the sampled moduli volume where all 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings remain within physical bounds (coupling matrix eigenvalues bounded by |λ| < 1), without requiring modification to individual coupling values outside CY geometry.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If numerical scanning of the full constrained moduli space (all 5 D₆-invariant Kähler directions × all 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure directions, covering at least 10⁴ grid points) yields sin²(2θ₁₂) outside [0.846, 0.886] in >70% of physically valid regions, or if the distribution of θ₁₂ values shows no statistically significant clustering (Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, p < 0.05) around the observed value compared to a flat random distribution over [0, π/2], then the hypothesis is refuted: the D₆-invariant structure alone does not explain θ₁₂.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: At least 40% of the moduli scanning volume must produce sin²(2θ₁₂) ∈ [0.846, 0.886] AND the median θ₁₂ value across the sample must differ from a uniform [0, π/2] distribution by more than 2 standard deviations (KS test p < 0.05, or Kuiper test for directional data). Additionally, the variance in θ₁₂ across valid moduli must be reduced by at least 60% compared to the case where D₆-invariance constraints are removed (i.e., all 20 complex-structure moduli are allowed to vary independently).

experiment.approach: Implement a two-stage computational pipeline: (1) extract the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings from CyTools for the GL=12/D₆ polytope and parameterize them as functions of the 5 D₆-invariant Kähler moduli and 5 D₆-invariant complex-structure moduli; (2) construct the effective neutrino mass matrix M_ν as a linear combination of these couplings weighted by CY moduli values, then use Casas-Ibarra inversion to compute θ₁₂ for a dense sampling of moduli space, comparing the resulting distribution against the observed value sin²(2θ₁₂) = 0.866 ± 0.02.
steps: Download or generate the polytope database for GL=12/D₆ from CyTools; extract the Hodge diamond (h¹¹=17, h²¹=20) and confirm D₆ automorphism group action.

Compute or retrieve the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings Y^D₆_{ijk} via the integral formula ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k for all (i,j,k) pairs that are D₆-invariant; express each coupling as a polynomial or rational function of the 5 independent Kähler moduli t_a and 5 independent complex-structure moduli z_α.

Identify the subspace of Kähler moduli that maintains geometric stability (positive intersection form, large-volume regime) and the subspace of complex-structure moduli that keeps the Picard-Fuchs system well-defined (away from discriminant loci).

Construct the neutrino mass matrix M_ν^(leptonic) as M_ν = ∑_{ijk} c_{ijk}(t,z) Y^D₆_{ijk} ⊗ (lepton flavor basis projector), where c_{ijk} are CY moduli-dependent coefficients derived from supergravity Lagrangian structure.

For each point in a 5×5 grid of (t_a, z_α) moduli coordinates (minimum 100×100 = 10,000 sample points), compute the light neutrino mass matrix via type-I seesaw m_ν = -m_D M_R^{-1} m_D^T, where m_D and M_R are sourced by the Yukawa texture.
Diagonalize m_ν and extract the lepton mixing matrix U via singular value decomposition; compute θ₁₂ from U_e2².
Construct the empirical probability density function (PDF) of θ₁₂ across moduli space; compute the median, 68% confidence interval, and Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic against the observed distribution.
Repeat the scan with D₆-invariance constraints relaxed (all 20 complex-structure moduli free) and compare the resulting θ₁₂ distributions to quantify the variance reduction.

Test whether the θ₁₃ angle is generically suppressed by the same D₆ structure by computing the distribution of sin²(2θ₁₃) and checking if <5% of valid moduli configurations yield sin²(2θ₁₃) > 0.01 (the measured upper bound).

Cross-check by computing the monodromy group generators of the GL=12/D₆ polytope (via Picard-Fuchs differential equations) and verify that the period integrals entering the physical Yukawa couplings are consistent with the D₆-invariant subspace.
tools: CyTools (Calabi-Yau triple-intersection and Hodge diamond computation)
SageMath / Macaulay2 (polynomial algebra for Yukawa coupling extraction from Picard-Fuchs system)
RECOLA / FeynCalc (neutrino mass matrix construction in supergravity framework)
Mathematica / Python scipy (numerical root-finding and diagonalization for θ₁₂ extraction)
ROOT or custom Python (statistical hypothesis testing, KS/Kuiper tests for directional distributions)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks: 2 weeks for CyTools polytope data extraction and D₆ group action setup; 3 weeks for Yukawa coupling parameterization and Picard-Fuchs validation; 4 weeks for moduli space scanning (10⁴ points with seesaw computation per point; ≈1–2 sec per point on standard HPC → ~3 compute-days on 100-core cluster); 2 weeks for statistical analysis and comparison against relaxed constraints.
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database (public); Calabi-Yau polytope definitions and automorphism group tables (from CICY and Kreuzer-Skarke databases); neutrino oscillation parameters from PDG 2023 (θ₁₂, θ₁₃, θ₂₃, Δm²₂₁, Δm²₃₁); supergravity Lagrangian coefficients (literature standard). Computational resources: ~100–500 CPU-core-days or equivalent GPU acceleration.
experiment.expected_positive: The empirical distribution of θ₁₂ across the D₆-invariant moduli subspace peaks near 35° (sin²(2θ₁₂) = 0.866) with ≥40% of valid configurations falling within the observed 3σ range [0.846, 0.886]. The KS test p-value against the observed distribution is p < 0.05. When D₆ constraints are relaxed, the same scan produces a flatter, broader distribution of θ₁₂ with statistically indistinguishable median from uniform [0, π/2], demonstrating variance reduction by >60%.
experiment.expected_negative: The empirical distribution of θ₁₂ is uniform or bimodal over [0, π/2], with <20% of configurations in the observed range. The KS test p-value against observed data is p > 0.20, indicating no significant clustering. Removing D₆ constraints produces a distribution statistically identical to the constrained case (variance reduction <10%), suggesting D₆ symmetry plays no role in fixing θ₁₂.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The distribution of θ₁₂ values computed from the D₆-invariant Yukawa texture, sampled uniformly over the constrained moduli space, is indistinguishable from a uniform distribution over [0, π/2] (i.e., the D₆-invariant structure does not preferentially select the observed solar mixing angle).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test: compare the empirical cumulative distribution function (CDF) of computed sin²(2θ₁₂) values against the CDF of the observed value (treated as a spike at 0.866) and a reference uniform distribution. Use α = 0.05 (two-tailed). Additionally, compute the Kuiper test statistic V for directional data on θ₁₂ ∈ [0, π/2] to test clustering. Report 95% confidence intervals on median θ₁₂ via bootstrap resampling (n_boot = 10,000).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: A shift in median θ₁₂ of >8° from the center of the [0, π/2] range (i.e., 45°), or equivalently a median sin²(2θ₁₂) within ±0.02 of the observed 0.866. With 10,000 sampled moduli points and an expected standard error in θ₁₂ of ~3–5° (typical for neutrino mixing), this effect is detectable at 80% power with α = 0.05.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size justification: Monte-Carlo sampling of 10⁴ moduli points (5D uniform grid, 100 points per dimension) provides coverage of the constrained moduli space with ~10³ effective independent samples (accounting for correlations). For a normally-distributed θ₁₂ with estimated σ ≈ 4° and an effect size (shift from 45° to ~35°) of Δ = 10°, Cohen's d ≈ 2.5, requiring n = 2(σ/Δ)²(z_{α/2} + z_β)² ≈ 12 samples at 90% power (one-tailed). Our sample of 10⁴ greatly exceeds this, giving >99% power. Convergence criterion: scan is deemed complete when the empirical CDF of θ₁₂ stabilizes to within ±1° change across consecutive 1,000-point increments.
limitations: The computation assumes that the effective neutrino mass matrix can be reliably constructed from CY3 Yukawa couplings via type-I seesaw; however, the right-handed neutrino masses M_R also depend on CY geometry (not fully characterized here), introducing an uncontrolled source of variation.

D₆ symmetry in this polytope acts on complex-structure moduli, but the actual string compactification may admit additional Abelian or non-Abelian factors (e.g., Z₂, Z₃) that also constrain couplings; the experiment isolates D₆ only.

The Picard-Fuchs system and monodromy group are computed algebraically, but their numerical evaluation at specific moduli values may suffer from floating-point precision loss, particularly near singular loci.

Casas-Ibarra parametrization assumes three light neutrino species and that mixing arises purely from the mass-basis transformation; scenarios with sterile neutrinos or non-unitary mixing are not tested.

The mapping from CY3 Yukawa couplings to the leptonic sector depends on the specifics of the gauge-group embedding and modular symmetry, which are not uniquely specified by D₆ alone; results may vary under different E₆ or SU(5) GUT embeddings.
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab / observational follow-up: If the computational scan identifies moduli regions that robustly produce θ₁₂ ≈ 35°, the next step is to determine whether these regions are phenomenologically preferred by other observables (e.g., proton decay rate in GUT models, dark matter relic abundance, gravitino mass). This would require fitting the string compactification parameters (string scale M_s, coupling g_s, overall volume τ) to real cosmological and particle-physics data, which is beyond the scope of this computational experiment but would be essential to falsify or confirm the hypothesis in a physical setting. Additionally, precision neutrino-mixing measurements (e.g., from JUNO, NOvA, or next-generation oscillation experiments) could test whether θ₁₃ shows the predicted suppression pattern, providing indirect evidence for the D₆ texture structure.

hypotheses.source_question: Can arc consistency filtering be formally integrated into the CyTools constraint satisfaction pipeline to efficiently prune the space of D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings and automatically identify which among the 26 surviving couplings are forced to vanish by consistency constraints on the Picard-Fuchs system?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that implementing arc consistency filtering on the constrained moduli space of the GL=12/D₆ Calabi-Yau polytope will identify structurally forbidden (vs. merely suppressed) Yukawa couplings at least 3–5× faster than Gröbner basis evaluation, and will automatically reduce the 26 D₆-invariant candidate couplings to a smaller, geometrically rigid subset whose texture reproduces the observed quark-lepton mass hierarchy without requiring secondary Froggatt-Nielsen suppression.
hypotheses.mechanism: Arc consistency filtering operates by propagating constraints through the domain of complex-structure moduli: each period relation (Picard-Fuchs equation) and D₆-invariance condition eliminates infeasible moduli values iteratively. This domain reduction is logically prior to coupling computation—a modulus value is removed only if it violates a constraint for *all* possible values of its neighbors in the constraint graph. Consequently, couplings that vanish at *all* remaining feasible points are structurally forbidden, not accidentally suppressed. Gröbner basis methods, by contrast, solve the ideal globally without prioritizing constraint propagation, missing the opportunity to detect early infeasibility and thus requiring exponentially more polynomial manipulations.
hypotheses.prediction: When arc consistency (AC-3 algorithm) is applied to the 20 complex-structure moduli and 5 D₆-invariant combinations subject to Picard-Fuchs constraints and D₆-invariance rules, it will reduce the feasible moduli domain by at least 40% (measured as volume contraction or cardinality reduction in a polytope discretization), identify at least 8 of the 26 candidate Yukawa couplings as structurally zero (i.e., vanishing at all remaining feasible points with zero residual domain volume), and complete this filtering in <10 seconds on a single CPU, compared to >60 seconds for Gröbner basis elimination.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: The hypothesis is refuted if: (1) arc consistency filtering reduces the feasible domain by <15%, indicating constraints are already weak or redundant; (2) <3 couplings are identified as structurally zero, suggesting the coupling texture is primarily determined by geometry rather than D₆ and period constraints; (3) runtime for AC-3 exceeds 30 seconds (indicating algorithmic overhead outweighs speedup), or (4) the remaining non-zero couplings do NOT reproduce a realistic quark-lepton mass hierarchy (mass ratios m_τ/m_μ, m_c/m_u, m_s/m_d, sin²θ₁₃ within 1–2 orders of magnitude of PDG values) without fine-tuning, implying the filtering has not revealed structural hierarchy.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Domain volume reduction ≥40%; ≥8 structurally zero couplings detected; wall-clock speedup ≥3× relative to Gröbner basis; mass hierarchy texture matches empirical ratios to within 1–2 orders of magnitude (e.g., m_τ/m_μ ≈ 16.8 vs. exp ≈ 16.8, m_c/m_u ≈ 0.35 vs. exp ≈ 0.36) without additional Froggatt-Nielsen suppression factors.

experiment.approach: Formalize the GL=12/D₆ moduli space as a constraint satisfaction problem (CSP), encode Picard-Fuchs differential equations and D₆-invariance as arithmetic constraints, implement standard arc consistency algorithms (AC-3, AC-2001), and compare filtering efficacy and runtime against Gröbner basis-based coupling enumeration using the CyTools pipeline.
steps: Step 1: Extract the 20 complex-structure moduli {z₁, …, z₂₀} and 5 D₆-invariant combinations {w₁, …, w₅} from the GL=12/D₆ polytope geometry (using CyTools polytope.dat or direct computation from Kähler form intersection numbers κ_{ijk}).

Step 2: Discretize the continuous moduli domains: sample the feasible region of each z_i and w_j on a fine lattice (e.g., 10³ grid points per modulus), or use exact interval arithmetic to define continuous domain bounds from polytope constraints.

Step 3: Encode Picard-Fuchs differential equations as arithmetic constraints: for each period integral π_α(z), add the form dπ_α/dz_i = (polynomials in z, π_α) as a constraint; discretize or solve symbolically to obtain feasible (z, π) pairs.

Step 4: Encode D₆-invariance as unary/binary constraints: Y_{ijk} = ∫_CY3 Ω ∧ χ_i ∧ χ_j ∧ χ_k must be invariant under D₆ action on moduli; represent as ρ(g) · Y_{ijk} = Y_{ijk} for all g ∈ D₆, translating to polynomial inequalities in moduli values.
Step 5: Build constraint graph: variables = {z₁, …, z₂₀, w₁, …, w₅, Y₁, …, Y₂₆} (coupling indicators); edges = period relations, D₆ invariance, Kähler volume constraints.

Step 6: Implement AC-3 algorithm: iteratively remove domain values that violate any constraint by checking if ∀ neighbor domain value ∃ consistent assignment. Record domain size before/after each pass.

Step 7: Identify structurally zero couplings: for each Y_i, check if its domain after AC-3 contains only zero, or if the measure of non-zero domain is <10⁻⁶ (numerical threshold for structural vanishing).

Step 8: Compute Yukawa couplings from remaining feasible moduli using CyTools Gröbner basis solver; construct 3×3 mass matrices for up, down, charged-lepton sectors; diagonalize and extract mass ratios (m_τ/m_μ, m_c/m_u, m_s/m_d) and mixing angles (sin²θ₁₃).

Step 9: Compare with CyTools baseline: run standard Gröbner elimination on the same moduli constraints without arc consistency; measure runtime, number of detected zero couplings, and coupling texture.
Step 10: Benchmark: compute wall-clock time for AC-3 filtering, Gröbner basis evaluation, and hybrid approach; assess speedup factor and domain reduction percentage.
tools: CyTools (polytope geometry, Kähler intersections, Gröbner basis module)
python-constraint library or custom CSP solver (for AC-3/AC-2001 implementation)
Macaulay2 or Singular (symbolic constraint encoding and Picard-Fuchs solving)
SageMath (moduli space discretization, D₆ representation matrices, period integral computation)
custom Python pipeline (constraint graph construction, domain filtering, mass matrix diagonalization)
PDG (Particle Data Group) tables for empirical mass ratios and mixing angles
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–6 weeks compute time (including CSP formalization, AC-3 coding, Gröbner baseline runs, texture analysis, and comparative benchmarking; expected <100 CPU-hours total for polytope of dimension 20).
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12/D₆ polytope data from CyTools (vertices, facets, Kähler form basis); Picard-Fuchs equations derived from mirror symmetry (available in CY database or computed via Griffiths-Dwork); D₆ character table and action on periods (group-theoretic data); PDG mass hierarchies and CKM/PMNS mixing angles for texture validation.
experiment.expected_positive: Arc consistency filtering reduces feasible moduli domain by ≥40%; ≥8 of 26 couplings are identified as structurally zero (vanishing at all remaining feasible points with <1% domain support); AC-3 completes in <10 seconds; the 18 non-zero couplings produce mass ratios m_τ/m_μ = 16–17, m_c/m_u = 0.34–0.37, m_s/m_d = 0.18–0.22, sin²θ₁₃ = 0.0020–0.0025 (matching PDG to 1–2 orders of magnitude) without Froggatt-Nielsen fine-tuning.
experiment.expected_negative: Arc consistency reduces domain by <15%; <3 couplings identified as structurally zero; AC-3 runtime >30 seconds; remaining couplings fail to reproduce mass hierarchy (e.g., m_c/m_u < 0.1 or sin²θ₁₃ > 0.01), requiring additional fine-tuning or secondary suppression mechanisms.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Arc consistency filtering provides no efficiency advantage over Gröbner basis methods on CY moduli spaces, and does not reveal structurally forbidden couplings beyond those already detected as accidentally suppressed by Gröbner elimination. Equivalently: (domain reduction <15%) ∧ (AC-3 runtime ≥ Gröbner time) ∧ (structurally zero couplings <3) ∧ (mass hierarchy requires Froggatt-Nielsen fine-tuning regardless of filtering method).
experiment.statistical_test: One-sided comparison of runtimes (paired t-test if multiple polytope samples; Wilcoxon signed-rank test if non-normal), α = 0.05; effect size measured as Cohen's d for runtime difference, and as Cramér's V for proportion of structurally zero couplings detected by each method. For mass hierarchy texture, compute χ² goodness-of-fit between predicted and PDG mass ratios, α = 0.05 (reject H₀ if χ² < critical value corresponding to acceptable texture match within 1.5 orders of magnitude).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Domain reduction ≥40% (equivalent to ~2.4× polytope volume contraction in log-scale); ≥8 structurally zero couplings (≥30% of 26-coupling set); wall-clock speedup ≥3× (AC-3 <10 sec vs. Gröbner >30 sec); texture match: max relative error in mass ratios <50% (e.g., predicted m_c/m_u within 0.34–0.37 vs. PDG 0.36).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: For runtime comparison: assume Gröbner baseline mean = 60 sec, SD = 15 sec; AC-3 target mean = 15 sec, SD = 5 sec. To detect 3× speedup with 80% power and α = 0.05 (two-sided), requires n ≥ 25 independent runs on distinct polytope sampling schemes or parameter variations. For coupling detection: assume baseline (Gröbner) finds 3 ± 2 structurally zero couplings; target (AC-3) finds 10 ± 2. Binomial test (H₀: p = 0.12, H₁: p ≥ 0.38) with 80% power and α = 0.05 requires n ≥ 50 sampled couplings. For mass texture: assume 18 predicted vs. PDG mass ratios; χ² GOF with 5 degrees of freedom and α = 0.05 achieves 80% power to detect texture mismatch >1.5 orders of magnitude.
limitations: CSP formalization assumes moduli domains can be represented as continuous or fine-grained discrete intervals; higher-dimensional polytopes may require coarse discretization, reducing filtering precision.

Arc consistency is a local pruning heuristic; it may not detect global infeasibility (requiring higher-level consistency methods like path consistency), so some feasible points may remain even if structurally inaccessible.
Picard-Fuchs equations are transcendental (differential); direct encoding as arithmetic constraints requires symbolic solving, introducing numerical error and computational overhead.
D₆ invariance is enforced only at discrete symmetry level; continuous Kähler metric and gravitino mass contributions are absorbed into effective coupling suppression, which AC-3 cannot isolate.

Validation of realistic mass hierarchy is qualitative (1–2 orders of magnitude match) rather than quantitative (fine-tuned Froggatt-Nielsen factors); small deviations could indicate hidden higher-order effects.
Replication across other polytopes (e.g., K3-fibered CYs with non-Abelian groups) is not tested; generalizability to broader class of Calabi-Yau automorphisms is assumed but unverified.
experiment.requires_followup: If AC-3 filtering successfully identifies a rigid Yukawa texture matching PDG values, the next step is to verify this texture by constructing an explicit Type IIB flux-compactification model on GL=12/D₆, computing the effective superpotential W_eff by integrating out massive modes, and checking whether the D₆-invariant couplings from CyTools are reproduced in the low-energy action. This requires solving the F-term and D-term equations for the full moduli-stabilized vacuum, which is a moderately intensive numerical task (1–2 month wet-lab equivalent effort) but tractable with available software (e.g., SageMath + specialized CY solvers). Alternatively, a shorter follow-up is to sample 5–10 other polytopes with non-Abelian automorphisms (e.g., S₄, A₅) and check whether arc consistency filtering generalizes, providing evidence for the universality of the method across discrete symmetry groups.
